items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s wonderful to welcome the Prime Minister Scott Morrison live in the studio. Welcome to the programme how are you doing?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m doing great Fairsy and thanks for having us in here today. It’s great to be back in Launie.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s nice to see you down here. Let me ask you off the top, hey, you’ve really got in and met some of the locals, including I believe one of my favourite places, Sporties last night? Is that true?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah, we were at Sporties last night with Johnsy who cleaned me up on the pool table, he’s a bit of a local legend there as I understand. It was great to spend some time there last night, just chatting with people with Bridget Archer, our Liberal candidate here in Bass.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Ariarne Titmus of course, a Tasmanian local really kicking serious backside nationally and internationally too now, which is wonderful. Alright Prime Minister, there’s a lot to get through and I know your time is tight and I really appreciate you popping in.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: People won’t have to wait too long to find out. But obviously, there were three dates, the 11th, 18th and 25th  and those options are now narrowing, so I don’t think people will have to wait too much longer.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yes.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And you can just feel it. I mean just talking to people at Sporties last night, talking to local tradies, talking to people in the building and civil construction industry.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I totally agree with you Prime Minister on that for sure. There are a lot of concerns as we know, health being one of them.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah that’s right. It’s going to focus on elective surgery, it’s going to focus on mental health care, maternity services, breast cancer diagnoses.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, one thing, looking at this in a nutshell; aged care. We’re an ageing population, it’s a sector that I believe from personal experience is drastically underfunded.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The Government has been putting a $1 billion extra into aged care every single year, $1 billion extra. We do have an ageing population and a priority for us particularly over the last 18 months has been has been in-home care places.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, cost of living. In a recent poll, it’s come out on top as the key election issue.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Tax cuts, that’s what. We’ve already legislated our first tranche last year and we’ve taken more tax cuts for this year.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, I did ask my listeners to submit questions.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Sure

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Just to put to you to get a response from you and I know that time is flying, so I’ll keep it as short as possible. One of them is talking about the NDIS.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The NDIS is a massive social programme, it’s the biggest change since Medicare. We’ve got 10,000 people, 10,000 people working either within the NDIA or ancillary services working to solve all of those problems.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister bulk-billing, that’s another one. There’s basically no bulk-billing doctors here in Launceston and in fact probably across northern Tasmania.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we have record bulk-billing rates right across the country.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Not here

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, it’s bulk-billing right across the country and including right across northern Tasmania that we’re achieving these rates, that’s the information that I have. We’re achieving those bulk billing records.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So there’s no issue with bulk-billing in your opinion?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: What I’m saying is we’ll continue to ensure that we deliver on this. It’s always going to be a challenge around the country, but what I’m saying is, at the last election, Bill Shorten said that we were going to sell Medicare.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister very quickly, this is another question. Daniel thanks for this one; “When the Libs took power 6 years ago they were claiming a budget crisis when the debt was around $250 billion.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, when you’re in deficit your debt goes up and it has taken us the last 6 years to get the Budget out of deficit and get it back into surplus. I mean that was the legacy the Labor Party they left us.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister in saying that, in the polls it shows  if an election was held now you’d be wiped out. The only shining light is your popularity, obviously  over Bill Shorten as preferred Prime Minister.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I think it’s pretty clear since we’ve come to Government, we’ve got the Budget  back into surplus. We’ve reduced unemployment to levels we’ve not seen in a decade.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Alright well Prime Minister Scott Morrison thank you so much for your time, really appreciate you dropping in.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thank you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thank you very much Michaelia. This is part of our plan for a stronger economy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Is this dependent on the federal election result?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: This is in the Budget, this is in the Budget papers and the funding is there. The only risk to this would be a Labor government that would reverse it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: These funds will only be available for people wanting to go into specific skills, it won’t be for all trades?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The Skilling Australians Fund – Michaelia might want to speak to this as well – that is already funding the additional training arrangements for the traditional skills and things like that. On top of that, we also have the apprenticeship program we announced, the half a billion dollar skills package in the Budget last week, which goes to a range of different apprenticeships which will also, I think, be of great input here in Tasmania.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What skills specifically are they for Tasmania, that are lacking here?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It’s a very customised plan. We have a plan to keep our economy strong and we have a plan to keep the Tasmanian economy strong.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: [Inaudible] allocated for a second interconnector?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well this is what the business case does. The business case, we wouldn’t be doing the business case on the second interconnector, if we weren’t serious about actually following through and implementing that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mr Morrison I understand that [inaudible] the same [inaudible] so are you going to be funding that?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s the same answer to the question that was just put. We would not be doing the business case and putting investment into the Marinus Link project if we had no intention of then following through with a positive result.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Today’s announcement, you said you’d be having a discussion with the Tasmanian Government, so has Tas TAFE been involved in that?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’ll be done by the Tasmanian Government, to the extent to which they’ll bring in other partners. That’s up to them, but really it’s about the industry.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Just moving on Prime Minister?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Before we go into other issues, we’re joined by some great people from VEC, so if we’re going to move to political issues, I won’t draw them into those things. So I want to thank you very much and good luck, thanks for joining us today.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can I just get a general comment, yeah, what do you think of today’s announcement, how will that help you in the skills shortage you face?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What skills do you think Tasmania is lacking?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They’ll be working closely with us to identify those, thanks very much, thanks for being here. Okay other questions for the day.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Malcom Turnbull said you can’t wave off the revelations about Peter Dutton’s private [inaudible] as the bubble and the buck stops with you. What are you going to do?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I’ve spoken with Peter Dutton about this and there are no issues here that trouble me at all. I mean there’s no suggestion that Peter, in any way shape or form, has a sought or been provided with any benefit here.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Have you sought an explanation from Mr Dutton?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes, I have and I’m very satisfied.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: About how he came to be in a lunchtime meeting with [inaudible]?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Members of Parliament have meetings with people all the time, the suggestion here is that something inappropriate was done. There’s no basis for that whatsoever, absolutely none.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So what do you make of Malcolm Turnbull’s advice then?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I don’t make anything of it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Was the Environment Minister ever pressured to get those Adani agreements done, will this free you up in your decision to call the election? And you’re a religious man, does Easter factor into any plans for an election date?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Let me say a couple of things about the last issue. On Easter Sunday and on Easter Friday and on Anzac Day, the Liberal and National parties won’t be running any political advertisements if we’re in an election campaign at that time.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’ve got another tough Western Australian behind me and they just stay focused on what their job is and what their responsibilities and their accountabilities are. I want to thank Minister Price for the very good job she’s done in managing her responsibilities and exercising them the way she has.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: When are you going to call the election?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It’ll be in May, we’ll call it in April.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister Scott Morrison thanks for your time.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks Paul.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: This is a very natural couch setting that we’ve set up for you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Welcome to my couch.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Appreciate it. Just a couple of questions, I was planning to go to the footy on the 11th of May, the 18th of May or the 25th of May.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I think you should go to the footy every opportunity you get.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah, right okay.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That's my policy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What if there was a Saturday night going and I really had to cover an election? The 11th, the 18th, or the 25th?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Mate you can always do it from the stands, I think it’d go really well with the coverage. I think your viewers would love it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay, I was asking for Speersy and he just wants to know whether we can have a night off, is it the 11th, the 18th or the 25th?

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: He can take his pick. Maybe he could decide and he can tell me.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay, the reaction to the Budget seems to be pretty positive, but there's a couple of things that I wanted to jump into that aren’t as obvious a headline to everyone else. I think that regardless of who is Prime Minister or what Party is in power, I love that we live in a country that yesterday made a decision that leukemia drugs shouldn't cost $140,000, they should only cost $40.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah, or even less on a concession that's right, $6.50.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But it's something that just as a bloke, it’s got to feel good. You look at your time in office, reaching the highest office in the land and you've been able to help those people?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I mean last year when we did the Budget - I think I remember talking about spinal muscular atrophy and how that's changing the lives of young Australians and their parents - the letters I've had, the stories I've heard, I mean Greg Hunt has the best job in the world I think as the Health Minister to be able to make these changes. But I got to say the other one that I felt very strongly about and I put at the top of the list for what we had to do in this year's Budget, that was our $461 million investment in tackling youth suicide and youth mental health.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s it, clusters of as you say, clusters of teenagers, kids as young as 12 and even younger. The fact that you are so hopeless.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They decide not to live, that seems to them the right option for you. Now there's mental illness that's attached to that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: One of the knocks that seems to be coming from the obvious sections of the media, most likely informed by your political opponents, is the only way you get to surplus is because somehow you're skimping on the NDIS. I'm assuming this is something you believe not to be true.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, it's a lie and it's a stupid lie. Look, there's a reason why Labor clearly haven't been able to deliver a surplus since I had long curly hair and I understand Josh had a mullet.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And I was thin.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It’s because they don't even know how Budgets work. The NDIS is fully funded.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But do you care that something as clearly inaccurate as that, takes hold in the media as quickly as it does? It frankly flushes out the people that, it wouldn’t matter if you gave people $100,000, they still would have found a way to say; “Terrible Budget, they're on their way out”

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I mean if that's what the Labor Party have to rely on - and I thought their response today to the Budget was the most feeble I've seen in a long time. If that's all they could talk about, some concocted story like that which was misusing politically the National Disability Insurance Scheme which is supposed to be a bipartisan initiative - if that's how desperate they are, well I think that reflects very poorly on them and anyone else who was suckered by it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A lot of people watching us are involved in small business. This is going to be one of the big fights of the election, not just about the impact of minimum wage changes, but most importantly for one of the big boosts - and you could feel it a few years ago when the Government did it - which was the asset write off.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yep.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The fact that even more companies will now be able to claim up to $30,000, This means you get to, people reinvest in their business and now they get to keep even more of their own money.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that's how the economy grows; small and family businesses employ people, they invest, they develop new products, they open new stores. They buy a new coffee machine, they buy new fridge, they get a new toolmaking unit or whatever it is.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Good luck with that.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah, good luck with that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So this is the thing; the commentariat, the polls whatever, we all know the game that exists now. But isn't it interesting that when the NSW election was 50/50 in the polls, the media covered it in a completely different fashion that meant Michael Daly blew himself up in the last week, it mattered.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No I don't think – increasingly - that people do think that it’s clear. I think as we get closer to the election, the issues will be come into sharper focus.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: To those people that, either in the past have strayed, or find it hard to go as hard as they may have in previous years, what do you say not to the paid-up and proud members of the Liberal Party, but the person who has voted more than not for the Liberal Party, about why they should fight just as hard in the next couple of months, as they did six years ago?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Because the country they're going to live in for the next 10 years is going to be determined by this election.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Just finally, Married At First Sight sadly beat the Budget in ratings last night. Any plans on putting those couples into the Senate just at the last minute?

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, but I suspect there may be other parties that will give them a run.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And one as we mentioned before about the PBS, that was actually able to help people last night.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister congratulations and thank you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks mate, cheers.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I can only guess that he’s here to call the election now, live on the air in what would be a 2GB exclusive – that’s just a guess I might be wrong - Scott Morrison good afternoon to you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’day Ben – there’s a fair chance you might be wrong. Fair chance.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Oh, what?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No mate I’m here in Sydney and it’s nice to be back home after a big week down there Canberra with the Budget.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’re kidding, hang on a moment, you're letting me down here. I was convinced, hang on a moment, he’s going to buck all tradition here, he’s going ignore tradition and he's going to call the election live on my show.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: As it's usually done by most prime ministers?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Then you’ll go and see the Governor-General on Saturday or Sunday.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well the election will be called in April and it will be held in May, that's as much of the detail I can tell you about today Ben.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’ve just missed out on one of the biggest scoops of my life.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it wouldn’t be the first time.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Alright, well look we do have a few minutes to talk to you, so if you change your mind, I’m here. First things first, reaction to the Federal Budget, let's get to that.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yep.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How do you reckon the Budget has been received by Australians? You’ve already had a chance to get a bit of a sense of that?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah the feedback I've had, I was down in Nowra this morning just chatting to people down there and obviously I’ve been getting a lot of feedback through the phones and people's electorate offices all around the country. I think people do see it as a good balance between responsibility and reward for people's effort, but also the reality of what we're facing in terms of the economic challenges ahead.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I was watching Q&A at the start of the week.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Why?

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I had a problem with the remote control, I got stuck. Anyway, I tuned in on Monday night and there was someone asked a question  - this this whole thing about power bill relief – “Why don't people on Newstart get it?” I mentioned the next day I really quite liked how Arthur Sinodinos said; “Look, I don't know.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I wanted Australians – and we did this a couple years ago for pensions, you see pension welfare payments are different to the others, pension payments are permanent welfare payments. If you’re on a Disability Support Pension, the Age Pension or a widow's pension, these are living welfare payments.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Fair enough.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Let's just get it done.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And when you consider what Newstart is, it's not a lot of money so I don't –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, it’s not Ben. So it was about the Budget, I was happy to do it and it was just being quite practical and sensible.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Alright, Bill Shorten had his reply last night, among other things he's promising $2.3 billion to slash the cost of cancer treatment for Australians.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We all stand with people with cancer, I mean we've got $9 billion of funding going towards 130 separate drugs under the affordable medicines program, the Pharmaceutical Benefit scheme. Where these drugs can cost $150,000, or $200,000 a course, we bring that down to $40.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: In the interest of flexibility, like on the Newstart thing, if you do look at it, if you look at it and go; “Alright we're in a pretty strong position as far as finances are concerned, we might be able to do a few more things for people with cancer considering the number of people impacted by it,” you're willing to take a look at that?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'm always interested in how we can help people with cancer. I think what was potentially a bit misleading last night was the suggestion that there aren’t free treatments now.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That's what most of my callers have been saying to me today.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, it’s true.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Not all of them, but most of them today have saying; “Well you know, when I went through my own cancer battle, I didn't pay for any of this stuff”.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah and that is true. So, the suggestion that somehow our health system doesn't provide this for free, now, I think is misleading.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And you’ll go above politics on cancer if you feel you can do more, you will?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Sure, of course.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now, of electric cars. Have you got one?

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I don’t, but I know it takes more than six to eight minutes to charge, I mean crikey. Seriously, I joked today at a lunch event, I was speaking there today; he must have been talking about those little cars you give to your kids.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Oh, a Scalextric electric car set? He might have been talking about them.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I don’t know what he was talking about.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I should just play for people what we’re referring to. This is Bill Shorten talking to Kyle and Jackie O on KIIS FM.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How long does it take to charge one up?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Oh, it can take, it depends what the original charge is. But it can take eight to ten minutes, depending on your charging.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Oh, is that all?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well it depends how flat your battery is.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now, what he’s saying is right … because if you charge an electric car for eight minutes, it will get you from Cronulla to Caringbah.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I don’t think it would get you from Northies to North Cronulla, I don’t think it’d get you that far.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: There’s a mob called ‘Aussie Farms’ you may have seen these guys. They’re the people who put that map up of farm locations and they've been invading farm land, even though they've been told not to come on them.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Throw the book at them - and there are some other measures that the Government has been looking at, I've been working with the Attorney-General on this and the Minister for Agriculture. I think this is disgraceful, I'm sick of it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Speaking of people going to war with Australians, you had said earlier in the week that you're not going to put any Australian life at risk to extract people from conflict zones?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Correct.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Talking about people who go and sign up with Islamic State, you've also made some comments in relation to the children of Khaled Sharrouf, one of our most infamous terrorists. You’ve spoken about these children, you’re saying in the case of the children who were the innocent victims of those who took them into this atrocious place, they have a responsibility here.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It all depends where they are. I mean they're there in a conflict zone currently, so I'm not going to put any Australian diplomat or any other Australian in a position of risk to go and extract anyone from these situations.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I'm really torn on this and I feel so sorry for these children. There are so many children out there PM, who find themselves in circumstances based on the decisions made by their mum or dad, rightly or wrongly.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: True.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But I really worry too when you got 16 and 17 year olds, I worry whether you’re importing a problem here. If they grow up feeling like their father's life was taken by, you know, Australian-backed forces, are they going to seek revenge or retribution? I mean someone said earlier on the open line, just lastly; “Look, you know, it’s terrible for these kids, but let's face it, is anyone going to want them sitting next to their kid in the classroom here in Australia?”

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Look to be fair, particularly when you're talking about younger children, I mean, kids are kids I think. I think we all respect the innocence of children.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You think we need to show a bit of love. We need to show we’re humane?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We’ve got to get the balance, I mean these are kids. These are kids and what their parents have done is criminal, going in there and fighting against Australia and against likeminded countries.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It is a risk though isn’t it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We won’t compromise it, but one thing that happened in the Parliament this week Ben – you may be keen to know –  there are a lot of these foreign fighters and now they've lost that fight, some of them think; “Oh well, I was all confused and I wish I hadn’t,” and all the rest of it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bringing the children of terrorists here is a risk, isn't it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well look, I don't think you can generalize to be fair Ben, I think you just take each and every case, you apply your process, the discipline, the intelligence, the judgment and which there are very experienced people working on in this area. So you know, we've just increased for example, our funding in this Budget by $560 million dollars for resources for ASIO and for the Australian Federal Police to bolster their counter-terrorism work.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Really appreciate you sparing some time to call in this afternoon, I know I've probably gone over the allotted time. What have you got on tomorrow?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That Sharks are playing the Eels mate, so I’m excited about that. I think its going to be the game of the round and down in my beloved Shire it's the opening of the shield season, so some of the district’s boys will be running out for the first time and there's a rumour that the Prime Minister is going to be doing the kickoff.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What have you got on Sunday?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I go to church on Sunday mate.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you’re in Sydney on Sunday?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I go to church in Sydney, yeah.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Not planning to go to Canberra on Sunday?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh, we’ll see.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You are?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It’s a mystery Ben.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you need the address of the Governor-General’s joint?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well he’s going to be here in Sydney too, so you never know.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you can just go to the Sydney residence?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Mate he might be out there at the stadium on Saturday night, mind you he’s a Roosters fan. But Lady Cosgrove is quite keen on the Sharks.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Alright, so we’ll be at the polls really soon, but you’re not saying when?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, of course not Ben. I mean the election will be called, there are three dates, 11th, 18th or 25th and we’ve just released our Budget.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well I was hoping for the scoop, you haven’t given me one but it's always nice to chat, thank you so much for coming on.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good on you Ben, cheers.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, good morning to you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’day.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Plenty of sweeteners in the Budget for working Australians. Is it a bit too soon though? We’re still in budget deficit, $4 billion this year, $7 billion next year.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, because what this is about is entering Australians that keep more of what they earn. The reason we’re back into surplus, is yes, we’ve kept spending under control, yes we’ve kept taxes under control, but it has been about the hard work of Australians.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay tax is one side of it, but the other side is wage increases. Look, you’ve have had record jobs growth, no denying that.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well as the Reserve Bank Governor only said only this week, what we have seen is an improvement in real wages, but there’s still a long way to go and you're not going to get better wage increases without a stronger economy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: See, these budget surpluses, which look impressive in the years going forward, just terrific, they’re all dependant on maintaining a strong economy. But the Treasurer even in his speech said we're facing really difficult economic conditions in the next few years, particularly from overseas.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we can. I mean the last two Budgets were better - when I was standing here last year, we bettered what we said we were going to do by $10 billion.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Big infrastructure spending. What, $100 billion over the next few years? I’ve got to say, you must be a fan of Utopia, the TV series because you’re creating a National Fast Train Authority.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s right, this infrastructure plan is all about two things. It’s about managing population growth for the future.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yep.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It’s about connecting our regional areas with our major centres. It’s also about making our roads safer.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So this is obviously a marketing document for the upcoming federal election, it’s dependent on you getting re-elected. You can almost say anything at the moment and then backtrack later if you are re- elected.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, no.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Are you going to guarantee all these measures? We have heard fast train plans for the last 20 years and none of them have ever got up. Are you guaranteeing everything in this Budget if you get re-elected?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Absolutely. At the last Budget, I said we were going to do the Melbourne Airport Rail Link and we have signed the heads of agreement with the state government there in Victoria to achieve just that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yep.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: This is something all of us I think –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Totally agree.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: One in four Australians struggle with mental health issues and for our young people, we’ve got to take this on. That’s what a strong economy and a surplus Budget does; it means we can take on these challenges, while funding drugs for leukaemia.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Couldn’t agree more with you on that point. Prime Minister you’ve got a very busy day ahead selling the Budget, appreciate you doing it live and first here on Sunrise, have a good day.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks a lot David.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Prime Minister joins me now from Canberra, Prime Minister thank you very much for being with us.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’day Leigh.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: When the Coalition was elected in 2013 it was on the back of promises to end Labor's debt and deficit nightmare and to rein in what you said was Labor's out of control spending. When we look at your record of six years in office, you've had deficits every year you've been in power, net debt when you were elected was 13.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No Leigh, we’re bringing down the first Budget surplus for next year and it's taken 12 years to get there. We have reined in -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Projected.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s what the Budget surplus is next year, that’s what the forecast Budget surplus is. That’s how Budgets are done, the year in advance.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What about my point on debt?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: So no, I wouldn't agree with your rather negative view of our performance.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What about my point about the size of net debt?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: When you're running deficits, obviously your debt continues to increase Leigh, that's why it's so important to get the Budget back into surplus. That's what we've been working hard to do for the last six years.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Has the Coalition given up on cutting the company tax rate for large business? You were telling us a couple of years ago that our international competitiveness was being destroyed by the comparatively high company tax rate.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We're not taking that policy to the next election, no.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Why have you given up on that, given as I say, that you were making the point a couple of years ago that it desperately needed to be cut for all businesses?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Because I don't believe it's supported and I think one of the things we learnt through that process is that there's a lot of work to be done by large businesses in this country to regather the trust of the Australian people that would see them support such an initiative. So what we have done is focus on those businesses that actually employ more than half of all Australians in our labour force and that is businesses up to 50 million in turnover.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let me ask you a question that I also asked Treasurer Frydenberg last night; isn't it a sign of policy failure of this government, that you're giving people a one-off payment to help with expenses, rather than at this point in the life of your government being able to say; "Look, we've put in place policies during the past six years that have consistently driven down your medical bills, consistently driven down your insurance premiums and consistently driven down your power bills?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: What we've done over the last five and a half years is increased funding for hospitals by over 60 per cent. We've increased funding for schools, public schools, by over 60 per cent.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Last night when those payments were announced, or it was actually on the weekend, they weren't going to apply to people on Newstart. At the National Press Club today the Treasurer said that last night you, he and Mathias Cormann had a discussion and decided it would be appropriate to extend it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well let’s deal with the whole measure. A couple of years ago we introduced pretty much exactly the same measure and it applied to pension payments.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I understand that, but just what changed your mind last night?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Leigh, Leigh just allow me to finish the answer to the question. So that's the measure that we announced on Sunday, that previously received the support of the Parliament.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Captain's call?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: So I took the decision together with the Finance Minister and the Treasurer to extend that payment so it would simply pass the Parliament, as it did today without any fuss and without any trouble. I'm happy to do that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, just a final issue before you go. You used to appear very regularly on Ray Hadley's radio program, what is your reaction to the allegations that 730 has aired this evening regarding Mr Hadley's workplace conduct?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I haven't seen the report Leigh, so I’m just going to leave that to 2GB. I'm answerable for many things, but I'm not responsible for private broadcasters.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: As a guest or subject of commentary on Mr Hadley's program, did you yourself ever feel bullied by him?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, I'm not easy to intimidate, Leigh.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What do you say to the comments from Imre Salusinszky who is the former advisor to the New South Wales Premier Mike Baird, that conservative politicians have a tendency to cave on policy decisions due pressure of broadcasters like Ray Hadley?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I think it's rubbish.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You've never caved or changed your mind on anything due to pressure from commercial radio broadcasters, commercial television presenters?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, not even the ABC.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: PM, thank you very much for joining us. I look forward to talking to you on the election campaign.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks, Leigh great to be with you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Scott Morrison joins me now. Good morning.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Hi Deb.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I thought Tina Arena was your singer of choice and yet we’ve got ACDC Back in Black - not quite back in the black though, we're still back the red at the moment this year, aren’t we?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No we’ll be back in the black in 2019/20, that’s what the Budget is, it’s 2019/20. I'm pleased that in the current year we’ve actually beat what I said the Budget would be last year by $10 billion.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Surpluses have been promised though and not delivered in the past. Labor's Wayne Swan failed to deliver four of them, very famously.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Absolutely, as I just said, in the last two budgets we bettered what we said we would do, by $10 billion each year.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: In the Budget though, last night the Treasurer did point out that there were headwinds the economy is facing - the slowdown in the global economy, the housing market is in a slump and forecasts of further house price falls to come?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: True.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Those are beyond your control, a lot of those factors, commodity prices too. So how can you guarantee a surplus when you can't control those factors?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well our commodity price forecasts for example are well below, right now, what the price is. So we've been very conservative about those things, as we have in the past, which is why we have outperformed.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Budgets are always political documents but this is especially so with the election looming, do you think that this will be enough to win votes?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: This is a plan, an economic plan, that's what Budgets are. I’ve done quite a number of these and that’s what the Budget is, it’s your economic plan for how you’re going to see an economy over the next decade that’s going to be the economy Australians want to live in.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But will it win votes though? Because you need those.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that's for Australian to decide, but what I believe they’re looking for is for unemployment to stay low, for investments in infrastructure and investment in services – as I said – already, 60 per cent increases in funding for hospitals and for schools. That will continue and even more so into the future.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A lot have been in marginal seats.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They’re right across the country, they’re in Labor seats, they’re in Liberal seats, they’re all across the country. Because a whole city functions better when you deal with these chokepoints in the city.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Is it wise though to be spending the extra money that we do have when there are those headwinds that are facing our economy? Should we be putting this surplus in the bank?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: What we’re doing is allowing Australians to keep more of what they earn. I don’t consider tax relief to be spending a dollar.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well it’s spending our dollars to give the dollars though.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, it’s not. No, it's their money.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The tax cuts you’ve announced equate to about $19 a week extra for the average Australian income. Do you think that will be enough to sway voters, do you think that amount of money in the pocket will be enough to make people think that’s a good policy?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: This is the biggest tax relief we have seen since the Howard Government. For a middle income family, that's more than $2,000 a year.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: To get that tax cut though, they will have to vote for you in the election because it won’t be introduced into Parliament this week, will it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it won't make a difference whether it’s introduced this week or not. What Labor did last year –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well the election is looming, so?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: But the Tax Office – if the Labor Party says they support our tax cuts, then the Tax Office can administer it on that basis. Last year, when I put a full tax plan into the Budget, Labor tried to play games with it, break it up and try to strip it away.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Will you be visiting the Governor-General this weekend to call the election?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: There’s three dates for the election, the 11th, 18th or 25th, they're the options we have.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Have you decided?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: When I decide to go out to the Governor-General, the people will see that car drive to Yarralumla.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Have you made a decision yet on the date though?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No not yet.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Not yet?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And what are the factors you’re considering?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, they’re matters for a Prime Minister to determine.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mother's Day is on May 12th.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes it is.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So will you and the girls be delivering Jenny breakfast in bed, or will you perhaps be too busy on the campaign trial?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, we’ll all be together, I can assure you of that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’m trying! I'm trying to get the date out of you.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Absolutely, as they should.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If you've been a good government though, how do you respond when people say why have you needed three Prime Ministers?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The real choice is who is going to be the Prime Minister after the next election. My Party changed its rules, so if at this election the Liberal Party and National Party are returned, then I will be returned as the Prime Minister and I will serve as Prime Minister over the next parliamentary term.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Alright, and Sunday? Should I put a mark around Sunday and expect to be on air announcing an election?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m sure you’ll always be on air, I’m sure your viewers will be demanding that you be on air all the time.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, we thank you for your time this week.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks Deb.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister thank you very much for joining us.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good morning Fran.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It's taken twelve long years to get the Budget back into surplus. That's due next year.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I don't want to hand out anything. I just want people to keep more of what they earn Fran, that's what tax relief is.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But is $158 billion of promised tax cuts on top of $144 billion already legislated, this Budget tells us there are danger signs ahead for the economy. The global outlook is slow, the growth forecasts have been cut, employment growth has been downgraded, consumption growth is slowing too.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well again Fran you’re seeing it as expenditure. We don't see it as that, we see it as an investment in Australians to keep our economy growing.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah but you’re also saying you're going to stay in surplus.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And we are going to stay in surplus over that entire period. We will pay the debt down to zero, just like John Howard and Peter Costello did, which is what the Budget set out last night.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, but you don't get to surpluses and maintain them with slowing growth and slowing global outlook and tax handouts, do you?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s already taken to account in the Budget. That's why the Treasurer was able to say last night that we achieved these surpluses while maintaining the discipline of keeping our taxes below the speed limit of 23.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay well speaking wages, Bill Shorten has declared the election will be a referendum on wages. Wages are forecast in your Budget to grow 2.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well our forecasts are always conservative. As you know unemployment is now at 4.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, they’re not always conservative, we haven't hit the wages forecasts for the last five budgets.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And what we have achieved are $10 billion and better improvements on the Budget bottom line in the last two Budgets we delivered, Fran. So we've been overachieving on what we've put in the Budgets for years now.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah, but where is the wages growth going to come from?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'll tell you. The wages growth is going to come from businesses continuing to expand, more people accessing more markets investing in their businesses, because of the low tax environment we're creating for them.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But you’ve got unemployment growth slowing in this Budget.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Employment growth continues because we've got unemployment down to the lowest level in the last decade, Fran. So we're going to get more people in jobs, 80,000 more apprentices we're going to train.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let's come back to your Budget, let's come back to your tax package. The most immediate measure - a lot of moving parts in this tax package - the most immediate measure is the proposed doubling of the low and middle income tax offset, which is worth up $1,080 for every single Australian and double that for dual income families.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Four and a half million taxpayers would receive that tax cut from the 1st of July. But you're essentially matching, a little bit more, the promise Labor has have on the table for a year.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No. This is the big lie of what Labor's been saying about their tax plan.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: In the short term, in the first four years, you’re providing tax relief for the same group Labor is.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, no there’s tax relief going right across the board. Now, that tax relief is designed to encourage Australians to go out there and keep doing what they're doing.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah and in a real comparison over the forward estimates, over the next three to four years, middle income and low income Australians would get the same immediate tax hit from you as they would from Labor.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, because we're not going to put on 45 per cent reckless emissions target, which is going to put a further tax on the economy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well that’s not about your tax cuts.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We're not going to put a $5 billion retiree tax on Australians. We're not going to increase taxes for half the population, this is what Labor plans to do, Fran.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay, okay.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They have $200 billion dollars and more, plus the reckless emissions target, which will put up the costs of absolutely everything and cost wages by independent analysis of $9,000. That’s what Labor's plan is.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I want to talk about your Budget.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That is my Budget.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I want to talk about your tax plan.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m talking about schools, hospitals and Medicare, Fran, and it’s all gone up.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah, but most of the money in your Budget is going on this tax plan. You'd be happy to hear last night, I think, that Labor would support this initial part of your tax plan, the $1080 for individuals.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Because Fran I'm going to put this Budget to the Australian people. Labor played this game last year and they tried to split our tax plan in the Parliament and played games to try and put up taxes for other people, while pretending to help others.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He did said a lot of times, eight times in fact in that speech. Prime Minister you’re essentially though, to put it bluntly, weaponising this $1,080 dollar tax cut to help you win the election, aren’t you? Haven’t low and middle income earners become hostage to the election campaign?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, I don't believe so at all Fran, I think I just outlined it perfectly well. If the Labor Party supports the tax cuts, well, they have to do is say so and the Tax Office can administer it on that basis.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister I know your time is tight this morning and you must go, so one final question. Last time people voted for the Coalition too they voted for a different prime minister.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Because that is our economic record, Fran. It's our economic record and the strength of the economy that matters to Australians going about their business today.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, that's what they thought last time and then didn't turn out that way at the end of the term.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And the Liberal Party has changed their rules to ensure that successful at this election, then if you vote Liberal at this election, you get me as Prime Minister. If you vote Labor at this election, then you get Bill Shorten as prime minister.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister thank you very much for joining us.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks a lot Fran.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister good morning.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good morning Alan.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I don't want to take any air out of your tires but can I tell you that the switchboard and emails have been on fire here, not about the Budget, but about Mr Shorten's energy policy.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I've said, this is a bigger economic statement that anything you said last night, because people are genuinely frightened. I’ll just read a couple; David said to me, “Please pass on our thanks to Bill Shorten.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it is Alan. I couldn't agree with you more on this, I mean frankly, they want to tell you what car to drive? This will put up the price of everything, it comes down to that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yep.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: $36 billion will leave the country to go over and get carbon credits from Kazakhstan or wherever else they think they're going to get them from. That is money that is taken out of these companies that they would use to invest in their business, to employ people or increase their wages.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well coming back to the energy - because as I’ve said I actually sent a message to Josh Frydenberg, I said look, congratulations and so on, but I'm sorry, you haven't released the most important economic document this week. This was Labor's energy policy.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: He did.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah, no doubt about that. This is dangerous stuff now.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, it's going to be about a half a trillion dollars overall, we believe, as a result of what Bill Shorten wants.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’re getting this costed, aren’t you?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We have and that BAE economic study that you’re familiar with, which I know you you’ve spoken to, their estimated cost of what Bill Shorten is talking about with his reckless carbon tax, carbon target - call it whatever you like, all I know is it’s going to increase the price of everything - that is going to cost the economy around half a trillion dollars. Now that's you know that's just under $500 billion or ‘five thousand million dollars’ as you would say.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’re dead right. Dead right.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: There is a reason we're going into a surplus Budget next year is because of the hard work of Australians. Sure, our Government has done the right thing getting expenditure under control, taxes under control, investing in things that drive the economy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’m sorry to turn you around here, thank you for that point. The businesses, okay.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now, how the hell does he manage? There’s no electric ute on the market.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So what does this poor coot do when he uses a utility? Either he reduces his earnings and cops it, or alternately he puts someone off, or he jacks up the price of his product. I mean, this is a nightmare for these people.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That is all true. And by contrast what do we say? We're saying that the instant asset write off goes from $25,000 to $30,000.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yep.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That it goes to businesses up to $50 million, that we’re going to spend over half a billion dollars training among that new apprentices, 80,000 new apprentices. So that tradie not only has a cheaper car, is paying a lesser cost for what he has to put in the tank, but on top of that he's able to get apprentices with additional incentives that helps him or her pass on their skills to another generation and we can keep building Australia and keep building our economy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I just want to come back to this point, because I know you live in the undiluted luxury of Cronulla, or else Kirribilli. But there are people who actually live in areas of Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and whatever, where they have no off-street parking facilities, they park on the street.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: True, yep.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now again, Bill Shorten is saying that all these roads, new roads, new houses, new office developments, will have to have charging facilities. Now if this is the case –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The cost.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s right! The cost of your car goes up, your house goes up, your office goes up and the cost of the road goes up. Where is this being costed? I mean, are you going to prosecute this?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well there's no doubt we're going to prosecute it. One of the ones that we haven't talked about yet, is what they’re going to say to farmers.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They're going to tell farmers, pastoralists and graziers what they can do on their land. Now, you know about this up in Queensland, those dreadful native veg laws that the Labor Government put in place up there.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yes, I do.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: You know, it's bad enough that you've got to deal with droughts and floods.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s it, good on you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: You’ve also got to deal with this numpty legislation, which basically tells farmers what they can do on their own land. Now, Bill Shorten wants to take that really bad idea and take it to the entire country.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Right, just a couple of things here because there is thousands of pages this stuff. Just amplify for our listeners, 94 - of course you've got to get through an election to enable any of this to happen - but 94 per cent of Australians - you’ve got to say this slowly - will pay no more than 30 cents in the dollar of course, if they re-elect you people.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: This is so important and we're changing when you set the threshold as well. So that means that the highest marginal tax rate that 94 per cent of Australians will pay, is just 30 cents in the dollar.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, $200 billion of tax, I mean -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Exactly, $200 billion including the $5 billion on retirees. The most insulting thing I've heard - and they said it again yesterday in the Chamber when they were jeering at me - I said that these are Australians who are going to have to pay this retiree's tax under Labor who paid tax all of their lives.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Don’t forget death duties, don’t forget death duties. Does anyone sort of save and invest in whatever, to have the government take it? Julian Burnside, the glamour candidate down there in Kooyong, says death duties, the CFMEU say death duties, the Labor unions say death duties.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It’s savage. What Julian Burnside and the Greens say, it’s absolutely savage.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now look, just a couple of things. I trust you're on top of all of this, I'm not suggesting you're not, but a couple of things that were important to our listeners here last night which won't be talked about today.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes, I met with two sufferers, and they were in remission, on Monday. They have had access to that drug.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Good on you, so $40 a script now?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: $6.50 for a concession card holder.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: On breast cancer I just want to raise for our listeners. That’s Ibrance which they've been writing to me about, it’s used to treat inoperable breast cancer.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That's right. As all cancer sufferers tell you when you talk to them, they also want to see more money going to research and treatment facilities.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s Bavencio. Well now I'll let you go because you've now got to talk about the most important economic statement of the week; the Shorten energy statement and I hope you'll prosecute that on behalf of everybody out there.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I will Alan. Can I just mentioned one last this thing that I'm most pleased about in this Budget; that's the $461 million we're putting into combat youth suicide and mental health challenges in this country.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Good on you, well done and thank you for your time Prime Minister.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Prime Minister Scott Morrison, Mr Morrison Good afternoon.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Hey Tom.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I watched Josh Frydenberg’s first Budget last night, is it going to win you the next election?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it’s about it being a plan to actually grow the Australian economy and bring us into surplus and invest in the essential services Australians rely on. The answer to your question is in the hands of the Australian people and the plan we once again put to them last night, I think demonstrates that you run a strong economy, you bring the Budget back into surplus and it means he can guarantee the funding like hospitals and schools that they rely on.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But do you think the surplus matters in itself to everyday Australians? Because that was the most conspicuous thing in Josh Frydenberg speech last night, the surplus, the surplus, we’re back in black, we've got a surplus. Do you think your average person really cares?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, that wasn't just what Josh said last night, that's certainly where he started because getting the Budget back into balance means Australia is paying its way. It means now we can pay down the debt and it means that there’s around $18 billion dollars in interest payments that goes on the debt and you've got to get rid of that, so you can invest more in things like hospitals and schools.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay so will the ends, you know, the various spending programmes you outlined or Josh Frydenberg outlined, will they win you the election?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well again Tom, that's for the Australian people to determine, I'm not complacent about this. What my job as Prime Minister is and the job of our team is to put forward our plans for how we're going to keep the economy growing and keep the Budget in balance.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I was recently wandering around the seat of Kooyong. I don't live there but my daughter goes to school there and I noticed most of the candidates who are running against Josh Frydenberg seemed to be running on environmental platforms, Julian Burnside, Oliver Yates.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We’ve got $3.5 billion dollars worth of initiatives we announced in the Budget last night, because we're meeting our targets for 2030, 26 per cent, we're meeting them.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Is it true that you will go to the Governor-General tomorrow and ask that Parliament be dissolved and an election be called?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, as in it's definitely not true?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, the election will be called in April and it'll be held in May. I made it really clear last year when I said the Budget would be on the 2nd of April that the lead in and all the normal things would be allowed to take place and the Leader of the Opposition gets their reply.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But it is April now.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I know, but I also said that the Leader of the Opposition would be able give their reply. When the election is called, well that will be done in April and it'll be held in May.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Which date in May?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I'm not saying at this point, because when I've made that final decision, when I go out to see the Governor-General, that's when that will be public.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: All right, we'll look forward to that. Now, the energy Newstart policy, I happened to watch Q&A accidentally on Monday night and I saw that Arthur Sinodinos was tackled on why the $75 to $125 energy subsidy wasn't going to people in receipt of Newstart.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I wanted to see the payment passed through the Parliament and the Labor Party and others, you know, we were aware of the position and I wanted to see passed. I think we were in a position to be able to accommodate that and so it became part of the Government's bill.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, no, but it was only a week ago that the energy subsidy was announced and it looks like…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, it was on Sunday.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well exactly, so it was a mistake that Newstart recipients missed out?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, I wanted to see it passed through the Parliament and that's what you have to do to be pragmatic.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I see, so you made the change so it would be passed through Parliament?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK, very fast trains.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Better than very slow trains, Tom.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well that's true, if they’re a reality.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that's a very good point.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So, I mean, I spoke at a Budget breakfast this morning and I mentioned I'd seen a picture of Malcolm and Tammy Fraser in 1978 getting on board a Japanese bullet train and saying, “This is what we need for Australia.” That was over 40 years ago now.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well our form is there for people to see. There are two other very big generationally-delayed projects which we’re now getting on with.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sorry which one is that? The one to the airport or the one to Geelong?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: This is Geelong to Melbourne, the Fast Rail. The Melbourne Airport Link, that's already happening, we're moving ahead on it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK so the very fast train to Geelong and back, that's a reality? Or will soon be a reality?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah it will be, both the State Government ourselves have been working towards that. It'll follow a very similar path.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You can understand the cynicism though?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh, sure.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Because we've talked so much over the years about fast trains, they've never, I don’t think we’ve ever had a train go faster than 100 kms an hour.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we're not talking about the bullet trains like they have in Tokyo, by the way.  That's not what this proposal is.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now today in Parliament you said something I found a little bit odd. We'll just have a listen to it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you often quote Borat in the Federal Parliament?

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Not very often but I thought it was very appropriate, because under… this is what Labor's emissions reduction policy is - half of their carbon emissions reductions is actually forcing businesses to buy carbon credits from other places outside Australia. Honestly, I've never been a fan of these arrangements, these foreign - I mean that you've got futures carbon traders, you've got all these sort of merchant bankers moving around these sorts of things.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Very quickly you popped up on Snapchat in the past couple of days and we in fact played one of your videos yesterday. You got a lot of likes a lot of new friends on this social media platform.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah look you've got to be everywhere to talk to Australians these days and of all ages. I'm happy to do that, I'm happy to meet people in the pub, I'm happy to meet them at the footy, I'm happy to meet him in a nursing home, I'm happy to meet them on Snapchat.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay, speaking of footy, last time you and I spoke in person I gave you a Carlton football jumper and made you a member of the club. How do you think the Blues will go against the Swans at Marvel Stadium this Saturday?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh, well I think the Swans will win, but I'm no expert mate.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m no expert. We’ll put the tips in but I was there for the Swans game against Richmond, but they had I say seem to be coming good in that that second quarter and the third quarter, it unravelled a bit.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: 54,000, how good is that?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well it was a great crowd, a record crowd for a women's AFL match. I know you’ve got to go, a busy day.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good on you mate, cheers.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Scott Morrison, Prime Minister of Australia.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister Scott Morrison, good morning to you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G'day, Michael.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Isn't this the most nakedly political budget in Australian history?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Michael, this is our economic plan to ensure that our economy is built strong over the next decade and that Australians have the opportunities that they're seeking for themselves, because this is a Budget that is backing hardworking Australians. It's a fair go for those who have a go, that's what underpins this Budget.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It's a promise of a surplus of $7 billion next financial year, but how robust is that promise given as we saw in the Budget documents last night, very considerable risks from overseas and risks here care of those falling house prices. How confident are you that you'll actually hit that Budget surplus next year and for that matter the years afterwards?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m very confident because that has been our form. I mean, last year when I delivered the Budget, what we’ve seen over the course of this year is that we’ve ended up $10 billion better and it was the same the year before.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How much of this Budget, though, is aimed at neutralising Labor politically? I ask that question because the Labor Party has already vowed to match the first round of tax cuts announced last night?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, Labor makes all sorts of promises when it comes to the economy but their record speaks for itself. What this is about is our plan for the decade that we're going to live in.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let's talk about lifting the poorest people up. In a Budget boasting $45 billion worth of surpluses Prime Minister over four years, why was there no scope at all to raise the Newstart Allowance?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, what we're doing for people who are looking for jobs is getting them into work. The difference about Newstart Allowance is that people on Newstart aren't intended to be there for a long period of time and they also have access to a range of other income support payments.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It is a measly figure, $277 a week. Even Arthur Sinodinos, your colleague on Q&A on Monday was saying it needs to go up.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: He didn't say now, I stress, he did not say it needed to go up now. He said that's something you consider down the track, but what we're doing is getting those people in record numbers who are on Newstart, into jobs.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay, just about out of time. Finally, Prime Minister, we're clearly about to go into election campaign mode.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I think that's what the bubble worries about. But what Australians are going to decide at the next election –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You don't think voters will look back and discount you for all the… for the muppet show, your words, we saw last year?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I think what they're going to do at the next election is decide who they want to continue to lead the country over the next three years. We changed the rules when I became Prime Minister, we changed the rules in our Party.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, really appreciate your time, thank you so much for joining News Breakfast.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks a lot, Michael.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The leader of the Liberal Party, the Coalition and Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Morrison good morning to you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’day Jon.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Is it a moral fail to build an election surplus off starving the National Disability Insurance Scheme of money, leaving disabled people without the services they need?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that's a terrible lie, Jon.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What is?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: What you've just said.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What part of it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: All of it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: None of it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: All of what you've said is untrue. Let me explain why.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The NDIS has been starved of funds and it hasn’t met –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No that’s not right Jon.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: What you yourselves said would be its allocated money and people are desperate for services and not getting them.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Let me explain what happens with the NDIS. What happens is based on estimates that are provided by the states working with the Commonwealth to understand what the expected demand is, then you pay out what the services are that are provided in response to that demand.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well no, you've squeezed the pipe.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, not at all. Jon, that’s just out and out wrong, that's not how it works.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mr Morrison, we’ve spoken to the providers, they do not have the cash flow allocated in order to meet the demand.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
