items.value: We've just increased the payment and for providers.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: For the future, but not for the past.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That's what's been done.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Not for the past, hence the surplus.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Jon I’m sorry, I've got to stop you there because you cannot tell those lies to the Australian people.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It's not a lie.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, it is a lie Jon. Because every single cent that needs to go to the NDIS, every single demand that is there for the NDIS -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: [Inaudible] go, doesn’t it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Every single service that's provided and sought -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, not every one that is sought.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, I'm sorry, Jon. I'm sorry, every demand for the NDIS is fully funded.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, they’re not. A lot of them are not hospital patients.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m sorry Jon, you’ve got this absolutely wrong.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, they're not hospital patients, they're not admitted, they're not outpatients.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: But they are paid for through the health system Jon.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: They’re not clients of hospitals at all. They’re paid through community organisations and charities and they need more money.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m sorry Jon, you cannot put that falsehood up just because that's what the Labor Party is saying -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s also what the providers are saying -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Again, if you want to repeat the lies of the Labor Party to your listeners -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s not the Labor Party, it’s the people who work their fingers to the bone for the disabled.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: You can do that, but if we’re going to have a debate, we can have a debate or we can have an interview.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well we can have both actually, I'm trying to explore one of the major issues in the Budget.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And you’ve got it wrong, Jon.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: All right well let's move on to other things but I'm basing my beliefs not on what the Labor Party have briefed us on.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well there’s an uncanny coincidence

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But the disability sector, it’s what the disability sector have put in their own press releases. Let's move on.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it’s a contest of both. It is a contest about who's best to lead the country going forward and it is also about the record of our Government, which has seen hospital funding increase by 63 per cent since we were first elected.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: All these figures of course are contested by your opponents.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No they’re not contested, they're the hard facts of what has occurred since we were elected until now. They are the financial accounts of the nation, Jon.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Desperately needed. Just a few things, we’ll come to infrastructure in a moment which is a very welcome commitment from your Government.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes, I did that ages ago.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You won't call the election this evening then?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And then Friday?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I committed to that last year Jon, why would that change?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Because the rumor mill runs hot as I'm sure you're aware.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: You shouldn’t pay attention to the bubble Jon, you’ve been around too long to pay attention to the bubble.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Every now and again there's one that goes past and you go; “Ooh, that would be interesting”. So having got that sorted, Geelong in particular.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yep.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The commitments to try and save Sarah Henderson in the very marginal Victorian seat of Corangamite. When does the money for Geelong Fast Rail start to flow?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, once we've completed the business case. When we were down there launching it the other day, we expect that to be in about 18 months to two years.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sorry, the business case?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, the business case needs to be done which works out the most effective way to do this, that's the first stage of the plan.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: When does that start?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That starts now.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: $20 million for year one, starting right now?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That starts right away.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah and then?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Then when we put that together, it works exactly like we work the Melbourne Airport Rail Link. As you know, we announced that in last year's Budget and were able to conclude the agreement, $5 billion each with Dan Andrews and the Victorian Government and ourselves.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But you’re press conference the other day with lots of people in fluoro vests and hard hats - and we're going to see more of that - you said it can start in 18 months, but in fact, the cash flow doesn't kick in until 2021?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we can. It's a function of getting the business case landed and it's a function of getting the agreement together with the State Government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So how can it start in 18 months when cash flow starts in three years?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Jon, as soon as we can get it moving, we'll begin moving. That's exactly what we're doing and we'll do it with the State Government and we're moving on all these projects.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I'm just trying to drill down, Prime Minister, because in fact it can't start in 18 months if the cash flow isn't kicking till the 1st of July 2021.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Jon, if we're in a position to start earlier, we will.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And the duplication to Waurn Ponds, allocating $50 million over four years, but it's a $750 million project.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We've allocated $700 million to the Waurn Ponds upgrade.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: $50 million in four years, the rest might follow.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: $700 million to upgrade that project, that's what we've committed in this Budget. That's what we've committed, $700 million.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So the actual expenditure is not just beyond the forward estimates of this Budget, but within them.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: There is expenditure now and there's expenditure over 10 years, it's a big project Jon. You can't upgrade the Waurn Ponds line by going through a drive through at McDonald's, you've got to do the planning, you've got to get it done you've got to work with the state government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So do you borrow the credibility that was built by the Andrews government and their model that led to them being re-elected? Do you say, well, we haven't really done that much for infrastructure in Victoria for the last few years, but forgive us, we've realised that the error of our ways and we're going to do it now?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that's not true either, Jon. I mean you've got to stop saying this stuff, we've been delivering billions of dollars of infrastructure projects in Victoria and we're going to continue to deliver billions of dollars

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sorry, your main commitment was for a tunnel the people of Victoria people voted against twice in elections.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: For these projects, so we’re just going to keep getting on with it, Jon. We're investing in infrastructure, we're investing in infrastructure in Victoria and particularly in Melbourne which is straining with the pressures of population and ensuring that we're delivering the projects.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: This is what governments do, of course Prime Minister.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We’re doing all of these things Jon.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s why we vote for governments, to do things.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That's exactly what we're doing Jon.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But do you have a credibility problem, not just on infrastructure where Victorians for years have been calling for more investment from the Commonwealth, but for instance your apprenticeships announcement. Billions cut from TAFE over years and years and suddenly now you say you'll put some of that back?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We established the Skilling Australians Fund last year Jon, that was in last year's Budget. We've been investing in these skills each and every year.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But where's your credibility on apprenticeships, if you've in fact, as you have, been cutting TAFE? You may have been putting money into private training up providers.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: State governments fund TAFE, Jon. State governments fund TAFE.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well specifically with monies allocated from the Commonwealth.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They're substantially funded by state governments. They're the responsibility of state governments and what we're doing here - I mean, I've seen people pour money into those programs and TAFE and not get the outcomes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Absolutely, rorts and rip-offs, many of them.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The great mistakes that is often made it that you just throw buckets of money into state government programs and they produce results. Now, particularly in the area of skills development, I haven't seen those results.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I don't want to make you late for your next commitment but just finally, extending the energy supplement to Newstart seems like an afterthought that was announced by the Treasurer on radio this morning, not in the Budget.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I want to see it passed through the Parliament and that's what is going to happen.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Was it an afterthought?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That will be in the Government's bill this morning when it's introduced into the House -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Was it an afterthought?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No it's in the bill and it's the Government's policy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But it wasn't in the Budget.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Jon, we’re getting it done.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: An afterthought.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'll tell you why it's important. Because this year's Budget, the year we're currently in, which was the Budget I handed down last year, we have bettered what I said a year ago by around about $10 billion and in the previous year, we did exactly the same thing.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Just finally Prime Minister, I'm trying to organise a birthday party for Jan my wife and her birthday is May the 11th, should I go ahead?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I’m going to be busy all the way through mate, be busy all the way through. When we announce the election, you'll know when it is.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well yeah, absolutely, drop on by.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s very kind.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If you've got nothing else on, you’re always welcome.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'll send a videogram.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: She would love that, thank you indeed.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good on you, Jon.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Prime Minister of Australia Scott Morrison.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So will you put One Nation last now in the seat of Cook?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I've already answered that question previously. We will be determining that at the time of nominations closing, because frankly, there are many candidates for who should go last.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Will you advise the LNP in Queensland to put One Nation below Labor and the Greens?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I just answered that question.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You didn't, Prime Minister, with respect, you didn’t.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I said we will make those decisions at the time of nominations closing, Stephen, and that’s when we’re going to do that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What will your recommendation to the Party be?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That will be made known at the time, once we see all the nominations. See, tell me this; Fraser Anning runs a candidate in Queensland in every single seat, who goes last?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Will you run him below Labor?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I’m asking. When we know who all the candidates are, then that's when I will make my decision and the Party will make its decision about where the preferences go.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: On energy in north and central Queensland, is that limited to underwriting or could subsidies be a part of that program?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: In North Queensland, what we’re looking to do is establish what is the most viable approach. There are no proposals for us to invest in those projects.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you wouldn't rule out subsidies?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We have no plans for subsidies at all, no, we don't have such a plan. What we have a plan to do, is work out what's the best project and then work out what is the best way to make that project happen.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: On social media, you mentioned the campaigns to blacklist companies. Is that a suggestion that you would ask social media or require social media to try to crack down on those kinds of ‘boycott movements,’ like Sleeping Giants?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: All I'm simply saying is that social media is often weaponised. Weaponised to damage peoples' business, damage their lives, involve themselves in hatred and any of these sorts of issues.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Prime Minister is with me, Scott Morrison good morning.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good morning. Good to be here.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Have you got little lights you can put on your car so you can come roaring down the middle of the road?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: [Laughter] I'll struggle through the traffic like every other Australian does here in Melbourne, that’s why we’ve got to bust this congestion.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay, get to that in a moment.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We're into an election campaign, can you give me four or five words, what is your pitch, what your slogan? Why should we vote for you?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Under the Australia I'll continue to lead, our economy will be stronger, Australians will be safer and I'll continue to bring Australians together. Without a strong economy, you cannot pay for the hospitals and schools that you need.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Four or five words then, it’s; “stronger economy, safer Australia, come together”?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That's it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Have you got the slogan yet? Or that’s it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: [Laughter] I'll leave that to others, but that's what I've been talking about from the day I became Prime Minister. Those three things Neil, you’ll probably recall, in that first press conference I did, that's what I wanted to do; keep our economy strong, keep Australians safe and keep bringing Australians together.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The polls aren't good, you didn't get any real bounce from that offshore processing issue and that was pushed pretty hard. Do you still recon you can win?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes absolutely, because this is the stark choice; I mean when your economy is facing stiff headwinds that we are – yesterday unemployment came down to the lowest level in seven years, 4.9 per cent, youth unemployment down to the lowest level in seven years - our economy facing headwinds is going to put all that at risk.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Still, a lot of people say it's going to happen, all the polls say it's going to happen.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, that’s what they say.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: They’re all wrong?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The polls always say this and people say this and that about the polls. But you know who gets to decide? Australians, when they turn up to vote.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We change prime minister on the basis of the polls.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, the basis of who is elected at the next election, that's going to be done by the Australian people. They will get to have their say in May.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Speaking of that, is Malcolm Turnbull going to campaign for the Government?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: He already is.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: [Laughter] No he’s not. In Flinders? Ask Greg Hunt about that.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, he's been supporting particularly Dave Sharma in Wentworth.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay, so he will be out there campaigning for you?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: In the seat, I assume he’ll be out there in Wentworth supporting Dave.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Have you asked him to keep his head down a bit, not cause trouble?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We haven't had that conversation.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you think he will?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I don't feel the need to have that conversation.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Don’t you?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, he’s campaigning against one of your ministers in Flinders.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: He’s been nowhere near Flinders.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Ohh, what about his statement? Yes, alright. One Nation, I saw ad nauseam on The Project last night, you're not going to commit to putting them below Labor in the preferences, at this stage anyway.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well hang on, we’ve just got a process Neil. We'll make that decision in accordance with our normal process, not because the Labor Party wants to go around, you know, trying to force us into making decisions.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well the union movement has also said; “put the Liberals last”.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, the union movement, yeah. Look we're not going to take lectures from the Labor Party on this.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And you won't do deals with the Shooters?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Will you preference them?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We won't do any deals with them, so that means –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you haven't decided on preferences there either.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, it'll just be done when we know who the nominees are, because we learned this; we've had people with very extreme views pop up in all sorts of seats. So you know, let's just wait to see who nominates and then we'll make the decision in the normal way.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, look at that One Nation beast. Pauline Hanson, is she a racist?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Look Pauline has expressed extremely strong views on these issues over a long period of time. I must say in more recent times particularly in this term of Parliament we've worked closely with Pauline on a lot of important issues - issues like family court issues, which I know she feels very passionately about.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But don’t they?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I tend to deal with people on the issues they present to me and Pauline has never raised or come to me over those issues. What she has been coming to me about, is things like how welfare is spent and ensuring there's integrity in the welfare system and she has very deep concerns about the way the family court system works.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: She is described today as a racist and a bigot. Is that fair?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Look what I said last Monday when I was here in Melbourne is, I don't think it helps that we constantly go back to just herding people into tribes and seeking to create further conflict around this stuff. I want us to all step back from all that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, let's look at One Nation the Party then. Do One Nation policies represent Australian values or are they at odds with Australian values?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well they’re not ones that exist certainly within my Party.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Are they anti-Australian in their values?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I said last night that I think there is a lack of knowledge, or awareness or understanding particularly when it comes to Islam in Australia. It can be sort of stereotyped, I think there's no doubt about that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Which ones?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I don't share their views when it comes to how they see a role for big government in this country. I don't share their views for intervening in so many different parts with additional regulation and things like that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Isn’t that itself racist? If you base immigration on race?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well Neil, what I'm not going to do today - which is I think what you're inviting me to do -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well I mean I’m interested, you’re tiptoeing around One Nation. Why are you being so careful?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Because I don't think it helps Neil, for us to just get into this slanging match between all of the personalities here. What happened last Friday was abominable and I think the right response in relation to that, is not to get into tit-for-tat between political parties and start with; “This person is this”, or “that person is that” and “they’re to blame for this” and “they're to blame for that”.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, do you think Pauline Hanson supports you on that philosophy?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I have no idea, I have never discussed it with her.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You don’t care?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It's not for me to have a view about that, it's for her to have a view about what she does. She is accountable, as is her party, as is every party, for their own decisions and all the things that they say.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: True, true, but you will to an extent be judged on your reaction to parties like this. I mean you were quite happy to take Fraser Anning’s head off for what he did.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Which was abominable.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Which was obscene and which was wrong, but sometimes Pauline Hanson … she won’t even condemn Fraser Anning.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I certainly don't agree with her on that, that's for sure.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But you can take his head off, you won’t take hers off.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I absolutely didn’t agree with what she did in the Parliament, when she wore the burqa to Parliament. I thought that disrespected the Parliament and you know, we made those comments at the time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The reason I did raise it by the way, is Kevin Rudd has tweeted; “It's appalling that Morrison,” you, “can't simply state Liberals and Nationals, put One Nation last. Hanson’s racism and religious bigotry is as clear as day.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, Kevin Rudd doesn't get to make decisions for the Liberal Party. We have a process for making our decisions.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Or Bill Shorten for that matter, by the way.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What has Bill Shorten done? Is he racist?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well why has Bill Shorten not disassociated himself with the comments of Michael Daly in New South Wales?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: On the Asians?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, why not? You’ll remember when John Howard many years ago was attacked for those things, a long, long time ago.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah I remember.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Labor had a lot to say about that, so where is Bill Shorten today? Tanya Plibersek? Anthony Albanese? When it comes to the leader of the Labor Party in the New South Wales Parliament –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, for the same reasons you won’t bag One Nation, it's political.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'm sorry, this is his own Party.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s politically difficult, it’s the middle of an election.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: This is the leader of the Labor Party in New South Wales who was has said Asians are going to take people’s jobs.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A fast trail to Geelong. You've talked about $2 billion dollars towards it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well this is the business case that is now going to be developed.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Oh so this is just a business case?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, it's $2 billion down, to actually make sure the project can proceed based on the business case that has to be developed. It's no different to what we did when we announced the Melbourne Airport Rail Link.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But you’d agree it’s going to have to be one of those three? It can't just arrive at the edge of the city and go from 160 to 20.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, sure.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’d either need sky rail, or a tunnel, or acquisition.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And that’s what the process will determine.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: When will we be in it, when will it be running?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well our best estimate at the moment is that within about two years we should be able to start construction. There's a lot to be achieved over that time and I know the State Government has already been working on this.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So is it ten years off?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we have to wait for the business case to be done.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So the business case is two years off?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No the business case will be done more quickly than that, then you need to get into the advanced planning works. Then you need to get the tenders and then you need to start construction.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It sounds ten years off.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well you can't go into the McDonald's drive through and get yourself a fast rail to Melbourne. You can get a few other things I notice -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: [Laughter] I did want to come back to that.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Look, these are big projects Neil, they can't just be done by yesterday afternoon and they don't start unless the Commonwealth in this case, is prepared to make this sort of a commitment of $2 billion, which we have and we'll work with the State government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you like the idea of Geelong being like a suburb of Melbourne?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, it's a satellite city and it has been.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah, they wouldn’t like that.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It's a city in its own right.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And Albury Wodonga, you want to have a look at a business case?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah, we’ve got a series of them.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: [Inaudible].

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We’ve got a series, there's Terralgon, there’s Gold Coast, there’s Wollongong and there are already projects underway that we've done, into Newcastle and out of Ballarat and a range of other projects. So we're serious about fast rail.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Matthew Guy did float this himself during the election campaign, didn't do him much good.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It is pretty much his plan, isn’t it, the one he floated?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No because what I'm announcing is an infrastructure project in the context of an entire population strategy Neil, this isn't just a one-off announcement. This is a fair dinkum plan to manage population growth, which involves migration settings, investments in social cohesion, planning frameworks with state and territory governments and local governments and congestion-busting projects of over $330 million dollars here in Victoria alone.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s the one in Cranbourne, not Flemington?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Pakenham.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Pakenham, sorry. Tax.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well they increased 3 percent, the minimum wage.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’d be hard to live on, wouldn’t they?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Of course. Of course they would be but the majority of Australians don't live on the minimum wage, the majority of Australians are actually paid above award.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So would you look at this? If you’re on the minimum wage, you’re paying $70 a week in tax. What about a ‘shandy deal’, employers pay them a bit and you increase the tax-free threshold, give them some back in tax?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We actually are delivering tax cuts. We've already legislated tax cuts.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How much will it give to someone on the minimum wage?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it can provide at that level, I think, it's around about a few hundred bucks.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A year?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I'm talking almost 70 bucks a week, you take out of them now.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that's not something that the Budget could sustain and what I also understand -  you know we also have a Newstart system, we have family tax benefits systems, we have a whole range of other payments and support that exist for people on low incomes. That's actually what the Fair Work Commission found –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, what –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Let me just, this is an important point Neil - the minimum wage isn't the only form of income that people get, who are on those minimum wages. As the Fair Work Commission has found, this work has been done, they have a range of other income supports which help them in that situation.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I loved the fact that the child who served you at McDonalds didn't know who you were.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: [Laughter] I think that’s great too.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How often do you go to Maccas?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh, occasionally yeah.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And a pot and a parma at the pub in Malvern? How often, the health police will be onto you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: [Laughter] Why would they be onto me for going to the Malvern Hotel?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Because you’re not allowed to eat Maccas, you’re not allowed to eat parmas, you’re not allowed to drink beer.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I’m pretty much like everyone else Neil –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How often at Maccas?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh, I’d probably pop in once or twice a month, maybe.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you have fries with it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I certainly do.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thickshake?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Nah, I don’t go a thickshake.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Coca Cola?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I just go the normal quarter-pounder meal or something like that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And a Coke?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah, it’s always a Coke.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A bucket of sugar and some fat.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah, bit of that from time to time.  It’s still not illegal.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It will be.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No worries Neil.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Prime Minister.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister of Australia, Scott Morrison welcome to the Project.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’day Waleed.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I want to do something I never thought I would do.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Particularly in an interview with a politician. I'm going to let you set the agenda to begin with.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It has been an extraordinary few days and you've just gotten back from New Zealand, meeting with Prime Minister Ardern, you would obviously have a keen sense of what it's like on the ground there.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It's an attack that has kind of, I was going to say ‘reset’ but it's least caused pause. Because if I can put it in such crude terms, the community that for 15 years or 18 years has been framed in the public imagination as a perpetrator, suddenly became the victim.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Sure.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Does Australia have an Islamophobia problem?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I don't know if Australians understand Islam very well and that can often lead to fear of things you don't understand. So by definition that's what it leads to, but that doesn't always translate into extremism, just like any view doesn't necessarily flow into extremism.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But not all disrespect –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: But not all disrespect of women leads to violence.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I understand your point but when I ask about Islamophobia, I don’t mean just that people don’t understand and they are a bit apprehensive. I mean effectively, an ‘ideologized’ form, an approach -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: There's no doubt that exists in Australia, there's no doubt that exists in Australia but there’s –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How big of a problem is it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: But there's no doubt that so many forms of hatred and stereotyping goes on in the Australian community. I mean my -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How big of a problem is this, do you think?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, we have been tracking through our agencies, this form of extremism. Now, people use different words, I have said right-wing extremist, others have said white supremacists or white separatists.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay. Well let me be perhaps, more focused in the way I want to ask this.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, I don't believe the Liberal Party does and I don't believe - I can't speak for the National Party, I’ll let the leader of the Nationals –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, you can though, you are Prime Minister, it is your Coalition.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, no I don’t believe so, I don’t believe so. But I’ll speak for myself -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, no, I get that you want to speak for yourself, but it is important to focus on the Coalition generally.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I think it’s important for all of us – and today is Harmony Day. Harmony Day is an opportunity for us, I think, to understand difference better.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sure, okay. So let me just run through some things and perhaps you can help me understand better or explain motives or whatever it might be.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: As leader it's my job to ensure that the tone I set, is the right tone. The tone I have set, you can you can see from my experience Waleed.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But is that happening? Especially when, with that track record … I'm trying to draw you on whether or not that track record is a problem and I haven’t -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The best way for me to address any problem is to lead by my own example and I’ve just said –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay sure, but is that track record a problem in the first place?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well there were a number of cases there that you've talked about where, you know, I've made comments on those at the time. I think there are a few in there that I'm not sure you're representing in the right light.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sure okay.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'll give you a good example. The comments you've referred to in relation to Peter  when he talked about the immigration period in the 1980s.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Only in relation to the Lebanese community?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, they learn lessons from all sorts of areas of intake –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So why single out the Lebanese community in that context?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'm simply saying Waleed that what Peter was explaining were some lessons that were learned during a period of what was a fairly tumultuous time in the world –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But he singled out the Lebanese community –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: If your question to me Waleed is this - which I believe it is - do I think that every single statement by any single member of the Liberal Party -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s not my question.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Has always been consistent -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s not it's not my question.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Maybe you might want to rephrase it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, I'll just re-ask it. Does your Party and your Coalition have a problem of Islamophobia?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’ve already –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Given that track record of behaviour –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I already said to you before that no, I don't think the Party has that problem, I don't think the Liberal Party as a total group has that problem. No, I don't and I don't think the National Party does either.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What about though, if they are speaking at a Reclaim Australia rally?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I didn't support that at the time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah, but it is a problem.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: He was a backbencher and remains a backbencher in the Government –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And an endorsed candidate I assume.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: By the LNP, but again, do we want to get bogged down in this or do we want to move on to how we actually make things better? In terms of the individuals, I talk to all of my members and as I say, I try and lead by example. My example has been to work with the Muslim community very, very deeply.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I appreciate that sentiment, I think talking about the past is important because the only way that you can move forward, reset at a moment like this, is if you acknowledge things that have happened in the past that are a problem and that need fixing.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, let me talk about –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, no, but let me talk about the future -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: You also said Peter was talking about the comment made by the Greens Senator. That comment was suggesting that I and Peter Dutton were responsible for the terrorist attacks in Christchurch.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Would I equate it with what Fraser Anning had to say? Would you?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That I personally –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Did she say literally that you personally were responsible?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That was the clear implication Waleed.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The clear implication, okay, we’re going to get into implication –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I mean –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’re comparing it to the direct statement of Fraser Anning –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No sorry, you raised the issue, so let me address it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Do you think it’s reasonable –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’m trying to answer your question.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: For any Senator to say that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Home Affairs were responsible for the terrorist attacks in Christchurch?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, I don’t.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I think –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But you’re –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It’s reasonable that Peter would have found that quite offensive –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yes.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: In the heat of the moment when people are upset –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Oh, it was the heat of the moment thing? Is that what you’re saying?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Waleed, the other night, you were very emotional and I’m sure you may have said some things about me, that based on our conservations since, you think may have been a bit over the top, about my own motives when it comes to these issues.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sorry, say that again? You think I said what?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, you were on the other night and as we discussed today, you implied that Muslims couldn’t feel safe because they had a Prime Minister who somehow had been prejudiced against them. I don’t believe that’s true.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay, you know what -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I don’t think you believe that’s true either.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I don’t, no, and that wasn’t the implication that I was making.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: People say things sometimes –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But since you, Prime Minister, no, let me ask this question. Since you raise it, we’ll come to that report, that shadow cabinet report.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I can only say anyone who may have talked to a journalist to smear me in that way. Because there have been a number of members who were at that meeting who have gone on the record to support the fact that it did not happen.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, there were some members who went on the record, some of whom weren't at the meeting. There are other members who –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Phillip Ruddock was there and he said it didn't happen.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah, no, my understanding -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Tony Abbott was there and he said it didn’t happen.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, no let me explain it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: David Johnson was there and he said it didn't happen.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I mean, I was there and I say it didn’t happen.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: With respect, Phillip Ruddock did not say it didn’t happen, he said that he could not recall. I have looked high and low -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Okay –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, but it’s an important difference isn’t it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You talk about people who have been on the record. Well, there is at least one of those people on the record saying that it did happen, that being Andrew Robb.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, no hang on –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You have multiple journalists reporting ‘multiple sources’ –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Hang on –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let me finish the question. Let me finish -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, I have to stop you there.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You can get to that point in a second. You have multiple journalists -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No Waleed, you have said that Andrew Robb said something that he did not.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Reporting from - I’ve read it with my own eyes today.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No. What Andrew –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You have – let me finish this.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’ll let you finish, I apologise.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You have multiple reporters, reporting from multiple sources that it happened and you have one on the record saying the same.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, that’s not true.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What I am interested in –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Waleed, that is not true. What is suggested is that I said that we should exploit, exploit concerns about Islam in the community to our political advantage.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Exploit I think is your word. Alright -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, that –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let me ask you this way -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Andrew Robb –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let me ask you this way -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Do you mind if I finish?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What did you say?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, I’m sorry, Andrew Robb did not say that I did that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, Andrew Robb said that you raised the issue.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah, I was the shadow immigration minister at the time and I was very concerned about these issues and the way people were feeling in the community.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So when you raised those issues in that meeting, what did you say to them?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I was concerned that we needed to address them, which is what I've been doing inside and outside of the Parliament for the last 10 years of my life.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Address those concerns?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes, to lower them.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So what your argument was in that shadow cabinet meeting was?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes, I was acknowledging that there were these fears in the community and that we had to address them, not exploit them. To actually seek to try and address them.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So the reports then of other people in the shadow cabinet concluding that discussion by saying; “We have a non-discriminatory immigration policy and that's the way that it should stay”?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes, that has always been my view.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Right, but –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I have championed that view as a Minister, as a member Parliament for my entire public life –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Why would that need to be said though, if the discussion in the meeting was about; “How can we dampen down community concerns about Muslims”?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Because I think we have responsibilities - as you were just asking me to do - that where we are concerned that people would have fears about these things, that we would seek to alleviate those fears.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: This was a meeting about campaign strategy and you were saying –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, this was just a shadow cabinet meeting.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay and you –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Talking about policy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: “We're drawing a line under this because we have a non-discriminatory immigration system.”

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes, that's my view and that was my view. It has always been my view.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But I still don’t understand why she would need to say that, if that wasn't a matter of controversy within the meeting?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No what I'm saying is that I was concerned about those fears in the community and that it has always been my practice - as I've demonstrated to you outside the Parliament and inside the Parliament - to seek to address those. Why else do you think I would have been working like I have as I explained to you before, why do you think I would be? That's been my experience and that’s why on Saturday after these horrendous attacks, I went to speak to those at the Lakemba Mosque, I was greeted with hugs and tears.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I'm not accusing you of not having ever worked with the Muslim community in Sydney, or even not having done it for a long time.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well can’t you see that what you’re suggesting –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’m not suggesting –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Is at complete odds –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: With the experience –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’m not suggesting –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That I’ve been involved in over my last ten years of public life?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister I’m not suggesting anything. I’m simply -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Doesn’t it sound odd that that report -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister I'm asking you a question about a report that is sourced from multiple people, that was reported by multiple journalists, by which all of those journalists stand.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Two unnamed sources, who have never gone public.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, one of them has.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well who?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We’ve had this discussion already, I’m asking you –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, Andrew Robb is not one of those.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister I’ve asked you to explain it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And I have.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’ve provided your explanation, fine, people will just draw their own conclusions on that. I have no problem with that.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Waleed let me just say for the record -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can I come - no, no, I’ve got to ask you this question.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You wanted to look forward and you wanted to talk about the tone.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I want to rule a line under this issue. It never happened, I’ve always been deeply concerned about attitudes towards people of Muslim faith in our community.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I have always acted consistently with that in shadow cabinet, in the Cabinet, by my policy decisions as Minister and in my own personal conduct. So such a report is so at odds with my experience and actions, that I think that speaks for itself.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Does acting in accordance with those beliefs mean that you will be henceforth – this is about the future and about the tone you want to set as a leader - that you will be preferencing One Nation last?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We are not going to do any preference deals with One Nation.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Not a deal, will you on your how-to-vote cards, be putting One Nation last?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Those matters are determined by the Party when we know what the nominations are.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You have a very strong voice within that Party.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah and we won't do any deals with One Nation -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I'm not talking about deal with One Nation. I'm talking about a decision from your Party to preference One Nation - who by the way said that Islam was a disease that needed to be vaccinated - will you be putting them last on your how-to-vote card?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well what if Fraser Anning is running candidates?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Right. So if Fraser Anning is, you will put One Nation ahead of Fraser Anning?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, you tell me -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’m just asking.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well this is the point Waleed, I don't know who is going to nominate. In the electorate of Longman –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let me rephrase –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: In the electorate of Longman – no, well you’ve raised the issue –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, no, no, let me rephrase because I know what you’re going to –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Waleed please let me answer one question.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, because I’ll ask this question -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh okay –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: This is going to the point.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'm just trying to answer your questions. I was raising the issue –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let me rephrase it Prime Minister –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: On the practical issue of Longman –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I need to get through this question. Will you at the very least committed in every seat, to putting them below the Labor Party and the Greens?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I am going to wait to see what all the nominations are and in our Party those decisions are made by the Party organisation. I know the Labor Party wants me to do a preference deal with them.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: None of this –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The election nominations will be called, we will see the candidates and we will make our decisions at that time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister why are you talking about preference deals? I'm not talking about a preference deal.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’ve just answered the question as to how we're going to conduct ourselves in relation to preferences.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But you’re talking about a preference deal, which is not what I’m talking about.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, I said we’re going to make these decisions at the time nominations close and then we'll apply those decisions at that time as a Party organisation.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you think, particularly in the circumstances that we face right now, that the Liberal Party and the National Party where relevant, should be preferencing One Nation below Labor and the Greens?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’ve said we're going to make that decision at the time of the nominations closing.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What do you think?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, you’ll know when we make that decision at that time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you have a view on it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'll be consulting with my own Party organisation, I won't be doing it through your program.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Why is it difficult? Why is it a difficult question?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Because I'm part of a Party that has a process and that Party listens to a lot of people in it's organisation who are members of our Party. That is a decision that is actually taken in each state and territory division of the Liberal Party, by the President of that Party, as part of their preferences committee on which I will have representatives.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But there is also the question of leadership, which you have raised.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And I’ll be exercising that at that time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Would it not be a strong act of leadership to say right now that you shouldn't be preferencing in One Nation ahead of Labor and the Greens? It would be an uncontroversial thing.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, all I’m saying at this stage is that we will never do a preference deal with One Nation and that we will settle those matters at the time of nominations closing, when we know who all the candidates are.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So does that mean it is possible that you will be preferencing One Nation ahead of Labor and the Greens?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, it just means what I just said.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, it wasn't clear to me on that point, sorry. Does that mean -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We will make those decisions –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You will, it’s possible?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Clear at the time of the nominations closing, Waleed.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay on the question of immigration - and here I’m not talking about the policy of immigration so much as the rhetoric of immigration, the discourse around immigration - do you think it's a problem when we talk about asylum seekers in particular through the prism of the possibility of them being rapists, of being murderers, of being paedophiles? This kind of ‘quasi Trumpian’ language? In his case applied to Mexicans.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that's only relevant if in the cases that we're talking about, that’s what is known about the actual individuals who may be subject to transfers. That was the topic of that debate at the time and that's what was said.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Right.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Should we ignore the fact that if there are persons who do have those records, or for whom those issues are present, that we should ignore that?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The question –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Like it's taboo, you’re not allowed to mention it?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, no there are multiple points to this, one of which is that it was warning that these people would be in Australia, as though they would be in the community. The bill in question never did that.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well no, the bill actually could do that, if they were put in community detention in metropolitan parts of the city, that’s exactly –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The bill made clear that they could be denied on those grounds and so they wouldn't get they into the country in the first place.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No I'm sorry Waleed, the bill didn't do that. The bill didn't do that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We spoke to numerous people who were involved in drafting the bill, there seems to have been no advice that those people, with those track records, would be able to –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well sorry, we are the Government and we have to implement it. We know that's exactly what can happen and we can't resist it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Right, so do you understand though that –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We're implementing that bill right now, it's not ours.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I understand. Do you understand –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We are taking the advice on how it has to be implemented and we'll be doing that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you understand though that when you frame the issue in that way, that creates an environment of prejudice? Or do you think that's not what happens?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, I think we're not going to sugar-coat to the public the implications of laws passing the Parliament and Waleed, it's important that you don't either.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, I’m not in the process of doing anything of the sort.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: In your commentary on these things, all journalists I think, have to be careful that they don't create a false impression of the risks that need to be managed.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I am asking you a question about whether or not describing people, Prime Minister –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The only people are described like that, are people that you could make that description of.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I feel like it’s very difficult to get through a sentence at the moment. The question really is about whether or not front-footing that description of these people, when there are so few of them in that category - and the categories that we were being warned about ended up being so vanishingly small once further questioning was applied to them – that that creates -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well actually we’re talking about a number.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That that creates a prejudice.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, no Waleed, you've got to be honest with people. If a bill that was put forward and supported by the Labor Party, was going to be creating risks for managing the transfer of people into the community, then I'm not going to tell the Australian people what those risks don't exist.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And how many people were in this category?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: My last advice on all of those of whom there were some serious concerns on character issues, I think was over about 50.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, 50 murderers, rapists and paedophiles?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Not only those but also people who had serious character assessments –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, no how many, how many murderers, rapists and paedophiles are we talking about?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They were actually published –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How many?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We had people with character concerns, over 50 people Waleed –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, no that’s not what I asked. How many murders, rapists and paedophiles? It’s an important question because that's –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They were among those 50, that’s true.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Among? Two among? Three among? 50 among?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: So how many rapists – no, let me put this to you Waleed. How rapists and murderers should be transferred to the Australian community?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I would say none, which is what the authors of the bill contend.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And they were wrong, they were wrong Waleed.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, no but let me ask you the question. Because as you say –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: There only needs to be one Waleed, that’s my answer.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And if the Minister has discretion to stop that person?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: But they don’t.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: They do.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They do not Waleed. I’m sorry, I’m the Prime Minister, I’m responsible for implementing it and I have the full availability of the Attorney General, the Attorney General’s Department, the Department of Home Affairs and their advice to me is, no, we don't have that power.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So because of that one person. Is it one by the way?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No it's more than one, it's well over that –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay can you give me that number, I am actually interested to know it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I've already told you there's, there's almost 60 actually who were identified as having serious character concerns, that in other circumstances we would never allow to be transferred to Australia. So that's enough –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You know that’s not the question I’ve asked.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I’ve asked you the same question and you’re saying ‘no rapists’.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: There were reports about murderers, rapists and paedophiles.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They exist and they are there –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How many? How many of those 60?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And those crimes have been committed actually in Papua New Guinea.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How many of those 60?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: There are a number, I don't have the numbers to hand, but this is getting into a semantic discussion. What I'm saying to you Waleed is this though; don't sugar-coat this stuff.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’m not.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It doesn't excuse it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I have no interest in sugar-coating any of it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I'm afraid mate, sometimes you could be accused of it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yes? Is that what you’re doing now?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well you're saying that there was no risk Waleed.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I'm asking you, no –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And there was there was risk and you say it didn't exist because the bill didn't allow for it. I'm telling you that's wrong.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I'm saying the bill protected against that risk.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: So I was always trying to be honest with the Australian people about the risk.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And I’m not sugar-coating anything with that. Let me ask you about one final area here.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: You mean particularly after Friday?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, exactly what I did do. The first step, call this out for what it was.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So, I fully –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Initiative Together for Humanity, which we put $2.5 million in, initiatives like the one we announced today with Bachar Houli down there at Richmond at Punt Road.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So I fully expect that when someone, one of your political opponents behaves in a way that is contrary to the spirit of that, that you will censure them. I fully expect that.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I have. So again Waleed, look to the experience that I've laid out for you tonight and don't prejudge me.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’m not prejudging, I’m asking the question. Will you henceforth -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That's my form Waleed.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So next time –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'm happy to call out people, as others have sought to call me out on things, I'm not shy about doing these sorts of things. I'm not shy about doing these sorts of things because I know what my values are and I know what I have done in my life, to try and build these bridges between communities.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister I wish you all the best with that endeavour.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I look forward to your support and we will be doing it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We’ll certainly be watching and supporting, absolutely where that does happen.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Cheers.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thank you very much for your time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, good morning, welcome.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good morning.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now, you have said it’s your job to have a plan for managing our population, we agree with you. So will you be successful in directing migrants to regional areas? And what support in these regional areas once migrants get out there?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well you’re, Australia does need a plan for population growth management, that’s one of the things I said when I became Prime Minister and that’s what we’re releasing today. The way we are encouraging people to go into the regions is through a number of points.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now the Opposition has questioned the timing of this immigration announcement, given what we’ve seen in Christchurch. Does that wash with you?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No it doesn’t. I think it’s disappointing.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK, now sweeping changes to the welfare system are also going to be announced today. Job hunters are going to be allowed to search for work on their home computer or smartphone, there is a new app coming.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we’ve already had more than 1.25 million jobs created since we were first elected and one of the reasons we’ve been able to do that is through these services.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You have appealed to world leaders to crack down on social media platforms following the Christchurch Mosque attack. What you want them to do?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I want the social media companies to use their technology to ensure that instantaneously, their platforms cannot be used as weapons by terrorists. If they can geotarget an ad to you based on something you’ve looked at on Facebook within half a second - it is almost like they are reading your mind - then I'm sure they have the technological capability to write algorithms that screen out this type of violent and hideous material at a moment’s notice.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah let’s hope they’re listening and they start using it for good and not for evil. Prime Minister, we have to leave it there, thanks for your time.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks guys, good to talk to talk to you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What's your advice today though, Prime Minister, to those thousands of Australians who are planning to go to or may already have booked to go to Gallipoli next month for ANZAC Day?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I think there's a common-sense response to that, to be mindful of the nature of these comments and to await further advice from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. But I think people should exercise common sense in relation to their travel plans.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Are you concerned that these comments by the President expose or open Australia to terror attacks?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I believe that how we respond to this - which is, frankly, in sorrow, in disappointment - is the appropriate response, and to appeal to the goodwill of the relationship that has existed for a very long time and to see that put back on its appropriate footings. I don't intend to sort of engage in that cycle I referred to, to ensure that we can keep Australians and Turks safe.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, you have a deep connection we know to the ANZAC story. Can you give us a sense of your immediate reaction when you heard these remarks from President Erdogan?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I was just deeply offended, as any Australian would be. The first thing that came to my mind was the promise of Ataturk.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What do you mean by ‘common sense’? Are you suggesting that Australians put their travel plans on hold?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I think they should exercise caution and await further official advice.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Could you expand, please, on your comment that all options are open?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Only to say that all options are open.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Is it an apology that you're demanding from Erdogan?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'm seeking a response in the good faith of our relationship.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What was the ambassador's explanation for the President's comment?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The excuses I don't accept are that things get said in the heat of the moment. The excuses that I don't accept are that things are said in an electoral context.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can I ask Prime Minister, have you seen the vision? Because they seemed to be very warmly received, these comments. People cheered, the crowd applauded, they chanted.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I choose to have faith in the tremendous relationship between the Australian and Turkish people, which has been experienced by Australians as they've travelled with Kiwis to Gallipoli for many, many, many years and the experience, the hospitality and goodwill of the Turkish people. I choose to believe in the good faith and great citizenship of Turkish Australians in this country.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Federal Government is unveiling a population policy today. It will cap the nation's permanent migration intake at 160,000 people for the next four years.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thank you Sabra.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How would you quantify the threat of right wing extremists in Australia?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I think it's serious and I think it always has been and that's why at the federal level our agencies have always taken it seriously. And the work that they've done over a long period of time I think has greatly assisted us, particularly in recent days when we've been responding to the issue, the terrible tragedy in Christchurch, the terrorist attack, to ensure that we're well prepared for the response that was needed here.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The New Zealand minister over there Andrew Little says that authorities there were only really alert to this midway through last year. What assurances can you give Australians here that their investigations are on point?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The Australian investigations picked up immediately and we've been assisting not only directly with the inquiries in New Zealand but also providing assistance and coordinating that investigation linking up with other countries around the world. When it comes to our knowledge of white supremacists or separatists or other extreme groups like this, we have got quite a bit of intelligence in these areas and it goes back quite a way on these groups.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Where would you suggest voters in the upcoming federal election put One Nation and the Shooters Party?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
