items.value: Well we're not having any preference deals with One Nation, we’re not having any preference deals with the Greens or Labor for that matter. You know, when the nominations are all set that's when our preferences are determined.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah. Will you instruct your organisation to put them somewhere?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we'll wait for who is on the list of every candidate all around the country. I mean, as we've seen in the past, there can be some individuals who present very, very extreme views even beyond those of some of those you've mentioned.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Is a censure strong enough for Fraser ending in Parliament? Some want him suspended for the rest of the term.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well look, the suspension is a matter that the Senators will consider. I understand that's being discussed, but in terms of a motion that is currently being moved by the Government with the support of the opposition I think is highly appropriate.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: In regards to assault, or in regards to hate speech?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I think there are a range of avenues open there and I'd expect people to be applying the law.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Onto your announcement today, this intention has been flagged for a long time. The rate that you want is one that Australia is currently close to.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: What today is is about a comprehensive plan for Australia's future population growth. I want to see Australians getting home safer and earlier to spend time with their families.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Chamber of Commerce and Industry's James Pearson has described this shift as an economic own goal. He says it's very disappointing that you're imposing a lower cap.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I think once James has the opportunity to actually read the policy I think he will react in a more measured way -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I've spoken to him personally this morning.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: He's entitled to his view but I think what Australians need and our economy needs is a balanced and responsible migration plan. I mean, under this plan we're seeing increased places for employer nominated skilled visas.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sure.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And his members who are tradies will want to get on site and have a good migration plan that helps them do that and infrastructure to back it up.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: This announcement comes three days out from a crucial state election where population growth and congestion are very big issues there and where the incumbent Liberal Party is in trouble. What's the public to make of this timing?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That this is an important plan that we've been working on from the day that I became Prime Minister. I took these matters to COAG last December.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What is the economic… where is the economic modelling and what are the economic benefits of your announcement, given that migration is a very strong economic stimulus?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well the fiscal impacts of this plan are no impact, it has no impact on the Budget and that's what we've been working through and that's why it is, I think, a very responsible level of intake. There are others who would have liked to have seen lower levels of intake.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: 23,000 migrants will be required to live in regional areas under this plan. How will you force them to do that and will there be jobs for them?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, look that is a misrepresentation of the plan. What it is is the opportunity for 23 classes for skilled migrants to settle and remain in regional Australia.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sure but how you can you can't compel them to live in those places.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well what the visas will do will say that if you have complied with the terms of the visa to live in a regional area, then you will be able to apply for permanent residency. Now this is what is very important at the end of the day, if you comply with the arrangements particularly for the issues around where student visas where there will be extra incentives for students to go and study in regional areas, which will be very good for regional economies, then the ticket to permanent residency will mean being able to have maintain your provisional requirements of your visa to live in those areas.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: All right. Prime Minister we're out of time.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks very much Sabra.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We're joined from Canberra by the Prime Minister Scott Morrison. Prime Minister good morning.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good morning Michael.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The current intake is not much above 160,000, that’s the new cap you're announcing. So what difference will this make?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well this is a responsible plan to manage our future population growth. It's not only about the change to the cap as you say, coming from 190,000 down to 160,000.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The economic benefits of migration are unquestioned as you know.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Sure.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We do know, as you also know, that the economy is slowing, so won't this hurt the economy down the track?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No it won't because it's a responsible cap. The employer-nominated positions under the plan will be maintained.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But equally Prime Minister how much of this congestion is due not so much to migration, but state governments of both stripes, not thinking strategically and thinking ahead, building your roads, building your rail lines many, many years ago?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: This is why our plan does address those issues, Michael. It's not just about the migration settings.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: “Your grandparents came, some of them returned in coffins. Have no doubt we will send you back like your grandparents.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I find it a very offensive comment, of course I do. I will be calling in the Turkish Ambassador today to meet with me and discuss these issues.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I also want to give you the opportunity on national TV to clear up a controversy that has been swirling in the past few days. Do you Scott Morrison, in a shadow cabinet meeting back in 2010, did you urge the Coalition to capitalise on anti-Muslim sentiment for political purposes?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Absolutely not, it is a disgraceful smear and an appalling lie.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Have you ever in any shadow cabinet or Cabinet meeting raised that thought.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Your office has threatened to sue the Ten Network which raised this allegation on Thursday, for defamation. Will you proceed with that?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I have no intention of doing that, I just simply want people to report the truth and that is an ugly and disgusting lie. I reject it absolutely.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay Prime Minister, just before we go, you speak a lot of boosting harmony, which a lot of people would agree with. In that vein, will the Liberal Party put One Nation last on it’s how-to-vote cards in the election?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We won't be doing any preference deals with One Nation. I do notice that the Labor Party did at the last election.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister you mention no preference deals, but the –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I haven’t finished Michael.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The question was, will you put the –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Michael do you mind if I finish my answer? At the last election, the Labor Party did a preference deal with One Nation that saw people like the Member for Dobell elected into the Parliament. So we will wait until nominations close and then as is always the case, we will set our preferences on the full range of tickets.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But you can't guarantee you will put One Nation last. Not -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I know that's what the Labor Party wants you to ask me Michael –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s - Prime Minister, the Labor Party hasn’t asked me to ask anything, I’m -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They’ve been putting it around the entire gallery for the last three days Michael and I think it's quite appalling that the Labor Party would be putting this about, when they themselves were the ones who did deals in the Senate with One Nation, at the last election. So I'm not going to buy into it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister Scott Morrison thank you so much for joining us on News Breakfast.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks, great to be here.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Prime Minister is on the line, Prime Minister good morning.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good morning Alan.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Firstly PM, Erdogan, the Turkish President. Do you have a comment on that?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I do. First of all I'll be calling in the Turkish Ambassador today to make my remarks directly to him.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Correct.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That our son’s could lie safely on their shores and rest in peace there. I find it a violation of that as well.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: True.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It is our job to take the temperature down, that's what tolerant societies do. I find the comments very regrettable and unhelpful.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay. To come back to this immigration thing, 160,000.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well they'll start feeling that in terms of how the intake is done from 1 July this year. Because it's not only what the overall number is - which is the cap of 160,000 - but it's about where people are being encouraged to go.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How do you get them to stay there?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well the points test will give them incentives if they want permanent residence to remain in these locations. Everyone who comes on a provisional visa, they want the permanent residence.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay. Just to use language that people can understand, the number of permanent residents is what you're talking about here.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Ultimately, to have a permanent visa, they would have to be in the 160,000, that includes family visas and those visas – which are about 45 or 47 odd thousand a year at the moment. There is no change to that, that will continue.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: 70 per cent, right.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That is very important. It's really adding value and because migration does, migrants have added value, of course, to our country.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Oh forget him, forget him.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They were appalling comments on the contribution of Asian immigrants to Australia. Bill Shorten should denounce it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He's no worry to you. Just tomorrow though, are you going to be undermined in a way because - unless you've got a bit of an insight, I'm sure as Prime Minister you most probably have - because these net overseas migration figures come out tomorrow.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, it would only reinforce the need for the plan that we've announced today. But you're right to say that temporary migration has had a very big impact on the level of population growth.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah but I mean, you've got 500,000 international students, 500,000 international students. My God.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And let me say in this plan we've announced today we're providing incentives for those students to actually go and study in regional areas by giving them an additional a year of work rights.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But supposing they get the permanent residency, supposing they get..

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I know but Alan that has to come in them as 160,000 cap. That's how these two things work together.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK good. I won't talk to you today about the infrastructure because that's part of where they will go to settle.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We'll have more to say about that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Quite. But could I just say on that, the notion that we want to get people out of the capital cities, a most laudable notion.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we're building one at Hughenden.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Not enough.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’ve been in the job for just over six months, one of the first thing that it was we we got this dam project underway up in Hughenden. We've got a half a billion dollar water fund which is designed to get a lot of these projects moving.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You could feed Asia, you could feed Asia, people would willingly live west of the Great Dividing Range and the quality of life if they knew they weren't going to be immersed and surrounded and enveloped by drought. And we have to guarantee water.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Agreed.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK, one other thing because we're both running out of time here. I'm just wondering whether you would, because governments interfere and intervene notions they interfere.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well as you already noted there has been sort of movement on this as we've seen reported today. And I think that's well…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s Coles and Woolworths, that’s not farm gate prices. These people are on contracts.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I think that's a fair point to be made to them and this is what David Littleproud and I will continue to do with those very producers and the ACCC as you rightly say should have an important role in that because they have the power to move prosecutions in these cases. And remember, it was our Government that introduced the effects test.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK, good. I'll let you go.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well there's a lot more work to be done on that. There's no doubt about that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can you report to us on what progress you will be able to make.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes I will.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Good on you. Good to talk to you, thank you for your time.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks Alan.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister thank you for your time this evening. It really is a lot to take in, quite overwhelming in fact, You’ve been briefed at the highest levels today.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well the investigation is spanning both obviously New Zealand and here in Australia. The Joint Counter Terrorism operations which investigate these matters have been stood up here in New South Wales and investigations are being undertaken now in relation to this individual.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister it is an uncomfortable, even sickening truth that this shooter is a home-grown terrorist from New South Wales. Can you reassure us on an any of the information that you may have, that he has no further links or supporters here?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I can’t offer too much comment on these things this evening, other than to say that in response to these terrorist incidents there is an automatic process which our authorities and police around the country immediately move into. That has been undertaken and that happened earlier today.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do we need to be concerned about any similar attacks here? Any extra protection for mosques in particular?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well these steps are already being taken as you’d expect them to be. The terrorist threat level in Australia remains unchanged on the advice of ASIO to me today.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s good advice of yours, to give everyone a hug on this subject, but what do we say to New Zealand, our closest friends, this will never be forgotten?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We say kia kaha, which is Maori for “stay strong”. Whanau is the word for family in Maori and that’s how we see New Zealanders and I expressed our sincere condolences to all of them, our sympathies and our prayers and thoughts and I wished Prime Minister Ardern - who I will be speaking with again - every support we can provide to them at this time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Indeed. Alright Prime Minister we really appreciate your time, thank you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, good afternoon.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’day Ben, g’day from Perth.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thank you for joining us. You went to Christmas Island yesterday.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well they've been able to stand up the facility as we asked them to do a couple of weeks ago. That's what was recommended to us after the Labor Party voted to undermine our border protection laws.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What kind of condition is it in, if it hasn't been used for a year? Is it full of cobwebs and mothballs?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, no, it was all shut down about October last year and so when they do that and decommission a facility like that, they have a procedure for actually standing it up again. That's what's called a hot contingency, so that means that they can stand it up again pretty quickly, which they've done.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you’re not expecting boats?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well not under us, no. I think our border protection regime, I think people smugglers know that when they come up against me they've got a brick wall.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Medivac thing is now reality, right? So are you thinking that there are going to be boats coming and is there any suggestion that we've seen any leave?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well what we're seeing is that people know that we're still the Government and that they know I’ll turn boats back. That's what they're certain of.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So Christmas Island yesterday, in WA today what do what are you up to? Are you on the election campaign trail already?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well for the last six months, Ben, since I've taken over as Prime Minister, it's been my task really to get out to Australians all over the country and explain what we're doing as a Government, where we're going to take Australia after the next election if we're successful. This morning I was down at the Henderson wharf facility where we're actually doing all the maintenance on all the frigates.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We had a hint of those headwinds yesterday. Were you worried about those economic figures out yesterday? They were indicating if it wasn't for population growth we'd be in recession.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well no that's not quite what it said, to be honest. I mean, the Labor Party came up with some new language on these things which was to spin, but the economy is still growing at 2.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: When I mentioned that about, you know, if it wasn't for population growth we'd be in recession. I spoke to Terry McCrann yesterday, the business writer from NewsCorp.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Income per capita, disposable income per capita, these measures show that positive position over the last 12 months and that's been an improvement. Non mining investment also grew yesterday.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I know you're tight on time so let me squeeze in a few more and I thank you very much for calling in by the way, we appreciate it. Bill Shorten says the next election will be a referendum on wages and we know wages are too low, they haven't budged in years.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that's why you need your economy to be strong and the only people are going to get a wage rise under Bill Shorten are the people smugglers. That's who is going to get a wage rise under him.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let me ask you about the reports out today about this Chinese company that is backed by the Chinese government wanting to build a massive new coal fired power plant in the Hunter Valley. One of your MPs Craig Kelly says it's fantastic.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well there are Chinese companies that already do own parts of coal mining operations in New South Wales currently and otherwise those operations probably wouldn’t even be there, which is no good for those who work in those places. But that particular project, there is no federal involvement in that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK quick one, as a rugby league fan, what do you make of the NRL players involved in leaked videos in these sex tapes? I know that Phil Gould from the Penrith Panthers says this goes beyond sport, it’s a massive issue for Australians mums and dads. What’s your message to younger people who are facing these issues, that… well, they can basically ruin lives in an instant and we’re seeing that at the moment.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I just think this is just appalling. I mean, as a fan of the game, as fans, that’s who I identify with.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We appreciate you calling in, when are you heading back our way?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’ll be back there on the weekend and I’ll be back there to be with Gladys at the election campaign launch on the weekend. I was with her on Monday when we announced the Western Sydney International Nancy-Bird Walton Airport which was very exciting.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No doubt about it. On a lighter note before I let you go, Ray Williams who is a Minister here in NSW, we have named and shamed him today for using photos on his election posters from about 30 years ago when he had jet black hair.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, no you will see current ones.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: With photoshopped shoes or real shoes?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, the Prime Minister and Cabinet Department won’t be responsible for that so we’ll make sure my real shoes are in the photo, no problem. And you’ll have to see me all in my white-haired glory.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’ll be watching, thanks very much.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good on you Ben.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: On the line is the Prime Minister Scott Morrison. Good morning.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’day Gareth, it's great to be here the west.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Appreciate your time. You’re here in Perth, we will come to that.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I've been saying for some time that these headwinds we're seeing around the world, whether it's the China-US trade issues, strategic sort of tensions. What's happening with Brexit.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK. But I guess in a way that's sort of the point.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that's… the non-mining investment was actually up, mining investment was down. When you put the two together the combined impact of mining investment with the others showed that reducing, but non-mining investment actually improved and that's to be, I think, that's to be importantly noted.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK. But households at the moment are nervous.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that's why you wouldn't go and put $200 billion of extra taxes on the economy. That's why you wouldn't abolish negative gearing and put up capital gains tax, it's why you wouldn't go and slug retirees $5 billion a year, 85,000 Western Australians to strip their franked different dividends away from them with their with their credits.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK. What's on the agenda here in Perth? You’ve been in Henderson this morning what else we up to?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: This afternoon I will be up in the electorate of Cowan, we’ve got a meeting there with a lot of the multicultural communities that are there and I'm looking forward to sitting down with them. I'll be with Christian Porter later today.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You can't afford to lose any seats in WA, can you? But the Labor Party is coming for them.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I can't afford to lose any seats anywhere in the country. And this is why our plan for a stronger economy, keeping our national security strength in place, and that is particularly the case in terms of border protection.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We’ll come back on Christmas Island, but I just I just want to focus on Perth for the moment. I mean it's.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I always am and they're always very well attended. I don’t know where you're getting your intel from but I know in terms of the federal election it's far stronger than it was going into the last federal election.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’re not going to have Malcolm Turnbull's $1.5 billion to fall back on, are you?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well no, we have actually got a lot more than that, that has come from support from businesses and individuals all across the country who understand what $200 billion of higher taxes will mean for the economy. How it will be a sheet anchor that will hold back jobs, it will hold back wages, it will hold back the growth in the business community that we need to support all of those economic outcomes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Christmas Island visit, was that a legitimate need for the Prime Minister to go there? No Prime Minister has been there before. Or was it just a political stunt so you could whack Bill Shorten over the head with the issue?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well Tanya Plibersek said this week that the Prime Minister has to explain to the Australian people how the facilities on Christmas Island are going to meet the need for what is now before us. That's exactly what I did yesterday.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The warning was that when the Medivac Bill passed there'd be hundreds of applications immediately. How many applications have there been?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it's the law has only just come into place in the last couple of days.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But the suggestion was our ready to go. So how many applications have been made?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: What we're seeing is the asylum advocates and others are putting their plans together putting their talking points together.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Has there been any applications made?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'm not going to give you a running commentary.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But have there been any applications made?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Gareth let me make this point. The reason we have reopened Christmas Island and this is working, is to ensure that those who thought they could game the system and find their way to Perth or Sydney or Melbourne or Brisbane - no, you'll be going to Christmas Island.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I can understand that there's probably some pretty significant deterrent effect there by saying you're not coming to the mainland, you’re going to Christmas Island but I'm just wondering, because the advice was that saying that the applications were ready to go. I'm just wondering have there been any yet? It sounds like they haven't.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: There will be applications, I have no doubt about it, and the asylum groups are doing what they always do and that is seeking to undermine the Government's policies. But the reason we had that advice from Home Affairs is we had to remove any incentive effect for those who were looking to game the system like always happens and it strikes me that our reaction, by reopening Christmas Island, is having the desired effect and in the same way it's having the effect of deterring boats from coming to Australia.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Could Julie Bishop have beaten Bill Shorten if she was PM?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It's a moot point.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It is a moot point I agree. But I'm just interested.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I don't offer opinions on this, it's my job to beat it and that's what I'm doing and that's what the party elected me to do.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Does it help you beat him for her to say that only she could beaten him?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No it's for you guys to talk about. I don't really engage in that stuff, other than to thank Julie for the tremendous service to Western Australia, a tremendous service to the Parliament.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You interested in helping the WACA fund their redevelopment ambitions?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it's with Mark McGowan. They're the ones doing the assessment.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So sounds like you're not that keen.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it's a Western Australian state government issue, it's not it's not necessarily a Federal Government issue. They're assessing the project at the moment, not the Commonwealth Government, and they have $1.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK. Christian Porter just told us earlier that he's been lobbying hard on this one.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Lots of members lobby about lots of things.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK, we'll have to wait and see then. Scott Morrison, I appreciate your time.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks a lot. Good to be here and thanks for having me on.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A new recovery agency will be set up to develop a long-term plan to rebuild the shattered industry, and beef producers will be offered cheaper loans, under a $2 billion plan to subsidise their debt. Scott Morrison is about to fly north to Townsville for this announcement.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good to be there Fran, good to be here.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: This is about rebuilding and reconstruction. Despite all this help though, do you think the North Queensland cattle industry will ever be the same?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I believe it will, but it’s going to take a lot of work to get there. And as you rightly said, we’ve got to do this station by station, farm by farm.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’re doing it through something you’re establishing called the North Queensland Livestock Industry Recovery Agency. Its job is to help rebuild farm infrastructure, restock the herds as you’ve just been saying.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No we don’t, because we really still don’t even know the full extent of the losses. I mean, there’s been estimates of half a million stock lost, but I’ve heard higher than that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So this comes without a budget allocation yet?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, we will do what is necessary. There are three tools particularly when it comes to the livestock industry.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Ok, according to your announcement there’s $2 billion there for loans by the government being offered through the banks - that’s how I understand it - at a lower interest rate. How cheap will these loans be? Are you fixing an interest rate and how can you be sure the lower rates will be passed onto the farmers.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well there’s two things. And look, the overall estimate there is an estimate so whether it’s that much… I mean already we’ve put $110 million out since the floods both in Townsville and across North Queensland…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: This is different though, through the banks isn’t it? Isn’t it banks are being..

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s basically… it’s a form of guarantee and which will reduce the costs to farms which means all of that cost of funds, will be passed on to each of the farmers in their restructuring of their existing debts and that is the same for the restocking loans as well. But the backstop on all this, is we can do it through the Regional Investment Corporation.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Ok

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And so, if there’s not a better deal coming from the bank, then we can offer that directly through the regional investment corporation.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And how good is that deal? What’s the rate?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, it’s going to depend on people’s holding. But it’s going to be a hell of a lot lower than they’re paying right now.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’re listening to RN Breakfast, our guest is the Prime Minister Scott Morrison on his way to Townsville to offer this reconstruction package for farmers. On other issues Prime Minister, Queensland floods, which due to unprecedented rainfall takes us to climate.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well actually, we’re down on the last one Fran.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, that last… to the year to the…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: On the quarterly result actually went down, look we should point that out.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah, but over the year to September 2018, emissions were up 0.9%.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m not disputing that, I’m just saying it actually went down in the last quarter. These numbers do jump around a bit.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Ok, but the government keeps telling us emissions are falling. Your own data shows that over the past year, up to September 2018, they didn’t fall, they went up.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well emissions fell 1.4% relative to the June quarter.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, your figures show the emissions are going up but let’s put that aside because what has happened this week is you’ve really emerged I think as almost an evangelical supporter of pumped hydro. There’s really been no mention of coal this week.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, look they’re decisions that’ll be made by investors and suppliers, and energy companies and others in terms of how they’re meeting supply to the market. What I’m saying is that is a key part of our emissions abatement.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well you are using 328 million tonnes of Kyoto credits.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, they’re Australia’s credits because we achieved them. We actually will over perform on the 2020 targets.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Ok

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And when Kyoto was set Fran, it was set on the basis that you could carry over credits.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Ok

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Why? Because they wanted to encourage countries to overachieve…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But what I’m asking you… what I’m asking you is in the government underwriting process that’s underway. You’ve already named one program today.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I’m not making any statements on that…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well why would we need to with all this pumped hydro.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, they are decisions that’ll be made within the energy market. And what we’re doing outside…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well no this is a government decision I’m talking about, underwriting the government, taxpayer’s money.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, we have a process in place for that. We’ve made no announcements on that process Fran, so I’m not going to pre-judge that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’re listening to breakfast, its fourteen to eight, our guest is the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, also this week the government hailed the departure of the last children off Nauru as a big achievement, which it undoubtedly was.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, in both countries where they’ve been found refugees, they’re living in countries that have signed the refugee convention. The refugee convention…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So that’s the plan they just stay on Nauru and Manus.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that’s exactly what Labour set out when they announced that they were going there in the first place. That they said they’d never be resettled in Australia.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So that is our government… the Australian government’s plan?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I haven’t changed the policy on that. The Labour party have sought to change it by effectively abolishing offshore processing by what they did in the Parliament.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well just on that… just on that and you know there’s hundreds doctors who argue with you on that but your Minister Peter Dutton this week has warned that Australians will be kicked off waiting lists for hospitals and public housing by an influx of transferees under that legislation. There’s so far only about 70 refugees and asylum seekers requiring medical evacuation.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: If someone needs… this is what currently happens. If someone needs very serious medical attention.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And 900 have come to Australia and that hasn’t seemed to undermine the border protection policy.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, we didn’t change the border policy. What Labour did in the Parliament was change the policy and the setting.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Isn’t it scaremongering to say this will keep people off the public waiting list?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, it’s not Fran. It’s just a simple fact.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, thank you very much for joining us.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well thanks Fran, one last thing before I go. The other thing we’re announcing in Townsville today, is the small business assistance.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, thank you very much.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks Fran. Bye.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you’ve gone from coal-aphobia to recognising a climate emergency. What’s your credibility on climate policy?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, those things are mutually exclusive, Jon. I mean, we are allowed to have reliable energy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Five years after this virtually the same proposal was abandoned, so we’ve lost five years.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It wasn’t abandoned. It hasn’t been abandoned.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sorry, what you’re announcing today?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That program has been running and we’re extending it as part of what I’m announcing today.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’re allocating more funds for more of it…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s been undersold, underprepared, underrun…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, Jon, none of that is true.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And now suddenly you’re saying, ‘We’ve got an election coming we’ve got to crank it up.’

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, Jon, none of what you’ve just said is true at all. What we’ve been…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s the ACF’s analysis of it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They’re welcome to make their commentary, like anyone is. But we have been running this program and it’s been responsible for around 200 million tonnes of abatement over the period of running those programs.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Isn’t the reality, in fact though, that you’re on a tightrope, on the one hand you’ve got the coal lobby and the resources sector, some of whom are changing their mind, mind you, on one side, what works with the coal industry is disastrous for people who want action and more action on climate change, and you’re on that tightrope trying to juggle the two.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, Jon, what I’ve got is a sensible, practical policy which is based on reducing our emissions, which we need to do and have done, and a plan to keep doing that out to 2030 and meet our targets which will see emissions per capita fall per person by more than 50 percent and our emissions intensity fall by more than two thirds. Now, only Brazil has got a target better than that in the G20.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And to those who say…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: So these misperceptions that are out there, well that’s for them to explain. All I know is our record.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Too little, too late, is the widely heard rejoinder.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: How can it be ‘too little, too late’ when what we’ve put in place means we exceed our targets by 367 million tonnes? Explain that to me.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, those targets keep shifting around, apart from [inaudible].

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, they don’t. They haven’t moved around at all.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Some of that shouting and hot air has come from your side of the ledger.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well there’s been plenty of shouting and hot air, Jon, but what I’m saying is…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, to those on your side, who have been holding up or even saying there is no need for further action on climate change, what do you say to them today?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, what I’m saying is, whatever people have been saying, we’ve just been getting on with the job. That’s what our government has been doing.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Snowy Hydro 2, still committed?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Snowy Hydro 2, absolutely, totally.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I mean, that’s all part of the plan.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You know, the Labor Party love it every time you talk about them?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The Labor Party?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mmm.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I don’t really care what they think.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But…

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But every time you reference them, every time you make them more relevant. They go, ‘Cha-ching, cha-ching, hooray, thank you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m not quite sure what you’re referring to. When I refer to the Labor Party, I talk about the fact that their emissions reduction targets are going to cost wage earners $9,000 each a year.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s contested…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I talk about how they’re going to hit retirees with a $5 billion a year tax.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, they’re announcing today a $640 million fund over four years for what they call ‘bank fairness’.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, the Labor Party’s answer to every question, Bills Shorten’s answer to every question is higher taxes. I mean, how much tax does he think the Australian economy can bear? He already has it at $200 billion in higher taxes over the next 10 years…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He’s proposing tax relief for most Australians whilst at the same time going to get rid of what he says is a rort…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Jon, that’s not true…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That some people have exploited through access to franking credits.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m sorry Jon, I’m going to do a fact check on you okay.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Excellent, we like that.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: $144 billion is the legislated tax cuts that we currently have taken through the Parliament. Labor have said they are going to halve that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mmhmm.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: So how can they be providing more tax relief when they’re actually halving the amount of tax relief that is currently legislated before the Parliament?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’ll leave that for Mr Shorten and Mr Bowen to explain but it’s going to be an interesting contest.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, you’re the one who said that they’re cutting taxes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, they, I, I’m referring to what their policy claims are, which is only reasonable.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I think they are highly dubious. Bill Shorten’s answer to every question is, ‘I’ll just tax you more.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Overnight, its been announced by the Department of Veterans’ Affairs that the Dawn Service in France at the Villers-Bretonneux Memorial Centre, the Monash Centre, which has just been completed at a cost of, I think, $100 million, they don’t want to run a Dawn Service anymore, they want to move it to a 10 o’clock ANZAC Day service, what’s your view, is it good or bad?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, that’s not gonna happen. I’ve spoken to the Minister this morning, the service will go ahead at dawn as usual.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Because?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Because that’s the right decision.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Regardless of what it costs and how many people turn up?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, I think it’s important to continue the Dawn Service in the way it’s been done. I’ve discussed that matter with the Minister this morning and they will consult with the local community there, but I believe the Dawn Service should continue in its current form and I’ve made that very clear to the Minister this morning.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That will be very welcome news in many quarters, Dawn Services are Dawn Services, they’re not 10 o’clock in the morning/morning tea services.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I agree. And when this matter was brought to my attention, I dealt with it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: They’re incredibly moving, it’s astonishing that so many people now turn up all over Australia and all around the world.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah, well it’s true. I mean, other services, you know, when we have the 11am services on Armistice Day, they are equally also very moving, there’s an importance about that time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s a cliché for journalists to ask Prime Ministers about Newspoll, and the latest Newspoll’s come out this morning, so I won’t ask you about the figures which show nothing’s changed, but border protection has been a lively issue during the last two weeks, and the figures haven’t budged. Does that mean border protection is not something that changes peoples’ votes?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, whether it is or whether it isn’t is not really my concern. What my concern is that we have strong border protection and that’s the only thing that’s ever motivated me.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And you were hoping that that would result in an improvement for your side in the polls.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, I was hoping that I would be able to stop the Labor Party from weakening our border protection. That’s what I was hoping.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So Newspoll’s result on this issue specifically, in the last little while, would suggest that the parties are level-pegging on that topic…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s not actually true…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: When peoples’ voting intention…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, that’s actually not true if you read what the polls said today. I mean, the Coalition is overwhelmingly favoured to the Labor Party when it comes to national security and the economy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Would you do the same if it cost you votes?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I would.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s hard to believe.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well Jon, you can make up whatever mind you like about this but when it comes to border protection, I don’t think anyone can doubt my conviction, sincerity on this.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I think we all want to see people not drowning…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I know how to stop that, Jon.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: … we also have a view of assessing politicians and what they offer and we always see it through the prism of what’s going to get them re-elected.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah, well you see Jon, I have a very unique perspective on this because I was the one who had to stop it. And I had to make the decisions that resulted in that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And it, also, has been a key part of your ascendancy to a leadership position and ultimately being the Prime Minister, which is, I’m not suggesting for a moment that you would only do it for those reasons but the two fit well together.  They fitted, they dove-tailed together.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: So what are you suggesting?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If those policies were unpopular, would you have still pursued them?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes.  Because some of those policies were unpopular.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you will do anything you can to get the best laws in place to advance those policies but you rejected the advice of the security agencies on the medevac laws last week …

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, that’s not true…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: and it wasn’t enacted.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No that’s not true. That report was rubbish.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: They said that you could include in Kerryn Phelps’ legislation…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We opposed the bill.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: …a provision that would allow for people to be medevaced to Australia but then returned.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, no…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: and you didn’t adopt that recommendation.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, no, Jon, you’ve got to stop reading the Saturday paper. It’s not true.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What half of it was not true? That was the advice from the security agency.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No it wasn’t Jon. It wasn’t.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Partially leaked to the Australian newspaper.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We declassified the advice so Jon, what you are putting to me…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The security agencies had to say “Hang on, that’s not what we said”..

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No Jon, what you are putting to me is just not true.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What part of it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m saying the report is not true. Ok? So we acted in accordance with our security advice, and that was, that bill should not be accepted.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That bill can be improved. That bill can be improved with a simple addition

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, it can’t actually Jon, you can’t. That bill in any form was going to weaken our border protection laws.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But if it was going to go through because you no longer control the numbers…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, I’m not going to split hairs with you Jon…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: … it can be ameliorated and improved.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: …on border protection I don’t trade.  It’s absolute.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: 13 minutes to 9, Scott Morrison, the Prime Minister is with me, we’re running out of time rapidly. There’s been several calls over the weekend for you to return to a John Howard definition of ministerial  accountability, which would have seen at least Mathias Cormann, if not others also coming into strife in the last week or two.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I think you have made a couple of leaps there Jon.  I mean, I mean, what was discussed last week was shown to be of no substance.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Which bit?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well all of it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well Mathias Cormann didn’t pay for travel.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And he paid it back.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It was offered to him, once…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Once it was drawn to his attention, he paid it back.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Once it was made public.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Bill Shorten didn’t declare a donation to his own campaign for eight years.  So I am not going to get lectured by the Labor Party.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No it wasn’t the Labor Party actually, I’m not even aware of what the Labor Party…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it was the Labor Party who pulled this out of their…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: This doesn’t pass the sniff test…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: …out of their bottom smear draw because they were under pressure in the Parliament. And that’s, look I get it, I get it how all that works…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Minister in charge of finances who doesn’t look after his own credit card transactions.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: He paid back the money and that’s the end of the matter.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Doesn’t pass the sniff test, does it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s your assertion.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Major contract goes from a government department to a …

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: There’s no link between those Jon, look Jon, if the Labor Party wants to get into those smears, look, I understand that.  But, I, I don’t think I should allow you to draw a connection between those two events because there is no connection between those events, there is none.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And Joe Hockey likewise?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Joe Hockey is not even a member of the Government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He says, ‘hang on’…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Joe works for DFAT. And so I am sure the Secretary will deal with whatever, if any, matters there are to be dealt with as she made clear to estimates last week.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Ita Buttrose, not on the list, of possible chairs, of the board of this organisation the ABC but certainly well-placed sources in today’s newspapers say even though there were no men on the list that was put to Cabinet, Ita Buttrose may leapfrog the field?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, two things, a) Cabinet have not considered this matter, Cabinet will soon consider this matter. It is true that she was not one of those who have been independently recommended.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: None at all?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: None at all.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What was your reaction when you saw the list?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Surprise…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Surprise? Disappointment?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh, of course.  But, anyway, the Government will make a decision and we will go through the normal processes that are required in terms of consultation with the Opposition and on that, the rules on that are very clear by the way.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You have meetings with Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews today…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What’s on the agenda?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: A number of issues.  I was in Gippsland yesterday, meeting with drought affected farmers, and they have raised a number of issues with me about support.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Local council rate relief?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Local council rate relief.  I spoke to local farmers yesterday and there rates are in the tens of thousands.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We are going to see a bit more of you in Victoria in the next few months…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh. I am, you certainly will.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And we’ve got seats now, Liberal seats which the Labor Party, with what are projected to be swings, seats that they now have within their their gaze, which otherwise they thought were well beyond their reach so we will see more of you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh, elections are always a contest whether it’s are in Victoria, or North Queensland, or Western Australia, we will be everywhere.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do we clone Scott Morrison’ so you can try and get around more places than you otherwise can?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: (laugh) No, I think one is enough.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: (laugh)

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I think one is enough for you Jon.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, well, we don’t get enough time…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I am pleased to be here with you today.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We may have an overinflated sense of our self-importance.  We like to see the Prime Minister here in town.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I am happy to be here.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s good when we do have the chance.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks Jon.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’ve made you late for your next appointment.  I’ve got your staff glaring at me through the glass, I’ll have to let you go.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Not a problem.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thank you for your time this morning.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thank you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister Good morning, if we are to meet our Paris targets in a canter as you have repeatedly promised why do we need to spend another $3.5 billion dollars in tax payer funds?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I always said there would be additional initiatives and there are in fact the Emissions Reduction Fund and the flagging of additional investment was set by Tony Abbott back in 2015 so this is a continuation of those programs and that is why I have always been so confident and why am I so confident because the 2020 targets we will exceed by over 400 million tonnes and when we came to Government we inherited a deficit of more than 700 million tonnes and we turned that around through these programs we will be one of the few countries in the world that will have exceeded our targets in 2020 by that type of amount well beyond many of the others who are often claimed and out to 2030 we have the plan to get us to hit those targets in a canter as well so our record speaks for itself we meet the targets that have been set for us that we have set ourselves and we will meet them in the future and they are sensible.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister do you think that the wild weather that we have seen over recent months over Summer has made you know this an even more potent issue in the minds of people in the electorate. Is that your sense of the politics of this issue?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I mean I think that is absolutely a perception that is there and as I said at the Press Club a few weeks ago obviously these things play into this issue you know the extent of that currently I think that is a matter that is often debated but let’s understand where we are right now we are meeting and exceeding our carbon emission reduction targets that we set for ourselves right now.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well this climate solutions fund as you are calling it this morning, will it be used to underwrite new coal projects of which the government, your Government with Angus Taylor has identified ten?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s not what the Emissions Reduction Fund does, no.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So there won’t be any funding from this to go to underwriting of new coal, that money will be found elsewhere and I imagine you will require legislation?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That is a separate process which continues to be underway which is agnostic about what the source of reliable energy is and that is a separate process. What I am talking about today is the Emissions Reduction Fund which is a $2 billion over the next ten years.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well that is the debate you will obviously continue over coming months but did you concede this morning that $2 billion it’s a big figure this is a carbon price isn’t it of some sort on the economy and on tax payers.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, no, no this is an investment in programs … it’s in the Budget this is the point it’s in our Budget.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s a carbon price.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It’s fully funded, no it’s not I think with great respect Keiran it shows a misunderstanding of the issues what this is investing in practices whether it’s in farms, in businesses or in other places to adopt energy efficient and improving technologies and practices which result in a reduction in carbon emissions but they also result in an improvement in productivity.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But it’s not free that’s the point.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: So everybody wins, everybody wins from this project it’s not a price it is an investment.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can I ask you about the latest Newspoll 47 out of 53 you are still six points behind after the last fortnight in Parliament are you disappointed that there hasn’t been some kind of improvement there?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I just focus on the plan we have, the plans that we have outlaid on the economy, our national security plans, the plans I’m announcing today to meet our climate change targets and that’s what we are putting to the Australian people. Now the only reference I would make to those numbers today clearly what we are saying on the economy and the national security is resonating when it comes to my plans and I welcome that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Where is the evidence of that Prime Minister with these numbers?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: You must have missed the bit that showed the difference between Bill Shorten and I when it comes to the economy and national security, we are resonating when it comes to our economic message and our national security message. The election is in May, West Coast were behind at half time and there is still a long way to go.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you feel that you have misread the mood though somewhat on asylum seekers, in terms of medical evacuations as you say in terms of the polling you are up on national security you are up on border protection that’s fine but in terms of the primary vote it hasn’t budged. Are people more sympathetic than you might have expected?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Honestly guys, seriously you are focussing on the wrong things. What border protection is about is border protection it’s about ensuring you have an integrity of border protection that’s why we do what we do that’s why we have always done what we have done.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A few final things Prime Minister, why have you cancelled the dawn services at Villers-Bretonneux is there any chance of overturning that?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that was a matter that I understand was decided by the Department and that has been brought to my attention and I will be discussing that with the Minister.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: All right and so hopefully some change or potential change on that front and finally onto China and the coal issues do you think it is believable what they have said in relation to environmental checks for our coal given the standard of our exported coal is better than most of the rest of the world and yet exports from Indonesia, Russia are still going in to that port of Dalian in China is their reason believable?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well this has happened before this is not the first time this has happened we have worked through these issues before these are local decisions that are made in these ports I should stress and they don’t represent a very large proportion of coal exports through that port into China in terms of our broader export of coal into China so we will just work through these issues as we have previously it’s not new and the Ministry for Foreign Affairs in China has made it very clear that these two things are not related and we take that at their word but I do know this I don’t think a global market for coal being impacted negatively is a wonderful thing, the Labor Party does.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister we appreciate your time thanks for that.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks a lot Kieran, see you guys.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, thank you very much for your time.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’Day.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What is the difference between your Climate Solutions Fund and the Emissions Reduction Fund created by Tony Abbott?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It guess beyond the Emissions Reduction fund. So it is embracing many others projects as well.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: When you are quoted as saying you will meet your targets in a canter, you were including this money? You had this in mind?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What is the difference for small business and farmers?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it’s continuing the projects that we already do. So it’s a reverse auction basically and what we’ve seen through this program is it does everything from improving soil productivity and boosting energy efficiency, assisting small businesses and their management practices.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How will people in remote communities be able to hold off severe bushfires was one that (inaudible)?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They are already doing that in terms of how they manage their burn management programs and that is part of the reverse auction process.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Haven’t they have done for a long time?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah and this helps them continue to do that and provides an economic basis for doing so, supporting jobs in rural and regional communities, particularly for indigenous Australians, who know how to manage the land and we are backing in them on doing that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now you are in Melbourne today to make this announcement. How much will the Victorian result from November, which climate change was a really big concern for voters, how much is that playing on your approach to climate change from now until the election?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I want to make some simple points.  Yes, we know of course we must address climate change and more importantly, we have been.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If I can just jump in on that, from the Victorian election there was a lot of criticism and blow back from previous Liberal voters who did not vote for the Coalition in Victoria because of a lack of climate change policy.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, I think because of a lack of awareness of our climate change policy and I think ..

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It wasn't sold well.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: What I’m saying today is we that we’ve got a very strong record of achievement. I was in New Zealand on Friday.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Why not aim higher if things are going so well?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well because it will crash the economy. It is not needed to have a higher target that will close industries and close jobs.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you won’t change your targets?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Labor's target at 45% would result in a loss of wages, per wage earner of $9,000 each per year. So you’ve got to have a responsible target that meets your environmental obligations, which we have been doing, but also supports our economy because our obligation to future generations is to give them a better planet, but it is also to ensure they have got an economy that supports their lifestyle.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Just a couple more on the politics of this. Malcolm Turnbull said in his final press conference, that the truth is the Coalition finds it very hard to get agreement on anything to do with emissions, emissions issues and climate policy issues.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: This program has absolute support right across the party because it deals with things that Malcolm started also on Snowy 2.0 and we are picking up with the Marinus link with Tasmania.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But are those views still entrenched in some parts?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I think the proof is the policy I am announcing today. Because this is what matters.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Are you better at bringing the party together on this issue than Malcolm Turnbull, is that what you are saying?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, I am saying we have a clear plan based on a great track record of which Malcolm Turnbull and Tony Abbott were key parts of putting together and driving that success.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Newspoll is out today.  No big shift on those numbers.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, because that was not what it is about. It was about … I mean people know many things about me but one thing I am sure they know is that when it comes to border protection I don't waiver, ever and that is why I took the strong position I did on this.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Dr Katie Allen was pre-selected as we just mentioned in Higgins yesterday.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: A tremendous candidate.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Are you relieved given a woman was not pre-selected in Stirling.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Let's go to Stirling. We have Vince Connolly who is a veteran and I would be pleased to have another veteran who has served overseas for our defence forces.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But it is also about women. What is the great disadvantage of taking too few women in the Liberal Party ranks to the next election?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Since I became leader I think it is now 19 women that have now been selected in the both the Senate and in the House and Wendy has already joined us, taking over from David Bushby's position in Tasmania.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you are not concerned you have too few women?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well what I am saying is since I have become Prime Minister the record of actually seeing women come into the ranks in very, very strong seats for the Liberal Party has been pretty good.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A couple of quick ones to finish on. Labor has announced today a levy on banks.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The Labor Party's answer to every question. Bill Shorten’s answer to every question is higher taxes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s a levy on the banks to help people who are struggling in financial circumstances and can't get good advice and it is a follow from the Royal Commission, of course.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: A good program should get support, but what we are able to do is fund Medicare to its highest rate of bulk-billing in history without it increasing people's taxes. We are able to have the highest funding for education.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well ok, we will hear from the Opposition today about that issue. Just one final one, Ita Buttrose as the chair of the ABC.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Cabinet hasn't made a decision on this matter yet and we are considering these matters and when we have made a decision we will make an announcement.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you think she would she be a good person for the job?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I don't get into commentary about things that Cabinet are considering. Do you think she would?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We have been pretty positive in the newsroom this morning about Ita Buttrose being the chair of the ABC.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I have known Ita for a long time …

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But it’s not up to me, it’s a question for you

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: … and I think she's an extraordinary Australian. An Australian of the Year and there  have been few people more than Ita that I think have lifted the standards of journalism in this country and I think that says a lot about her character and her abilities.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Joining the ranks of the great journalism of the ABC, it would be a nice fit, it seems. Prime Minister, thank you very much for your time.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks a lot.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, good morning to you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’day David.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Given this poll out today, are you disappointed with that, that you haven’t had a bounce in the polls? Because you made a big thing of the difference between your policy and also the Opposition’s in terms of Medivac and asylum seeker boats.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We stand by all of that because that was about the policy. We don’t want to see Australia’s border protection policy weakened and that's why we took the step we did.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you honestly think you can win the next election?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Of course I do.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Is it right Bill Shorten has written to you advising the Opposition front bench will be having meeting with senior public servants in the next couple of weeks to ensure a smooth transition of power?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I know that… yes, that have, they tried the same thing back in 2016. They are getting ahead of themselves.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Australians though are seeing all of these colleagues of yours resigning, Julie Bishop the latest one. A lot of women resigning from the Party.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No and Julie Bishop said exactly the opposite, as did Kelly O'Dwyer. And yesterday, we preselected Dr Katie Allen.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But you are, you have got to admit, you are pretty short on women in your ranks. Are you looking at bringing in quotas? How are you going to rectify that, because it is not a great look.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well since I became Prime Minister, we’ve has I think now 19 women selected in key roles. Whether it’s Bridget Archer down there in the seat of Bass or Jess Whelan in the seat of Lyons.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK. Let’s talk about climate change.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes. Three things.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So why are you spending an extra $2 billion if you are reaching the target comfortably? Are you going to set new lower targets?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, the 2020 targets are the one we're going to meet by over 400 million tonnes. The 2030 targets will require this additional investment in the very programs that have been…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you are a bit behind on that?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
