items.value: No, no, we always knew that there would be more that needed to be done and I have said that on several occasions and I said we’d be announcing that before the election. And today, I’m making those plans clear.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So this Climate Solutions Fund is the renamed the Emissions Reduction Fund?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No it’s more than that, because there is the work being done on Emissions Reduction Fund, there is the investment that will be going into Snowy Hydro 2.0 and also the Battery of the Nation project, another pumped hydro very significant project in Tasmania.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It sounds like you like renewables and renewable energy has a real place in this?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well of course it does. So does reliable energy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Your colleagues slammed South Australia for their batteries and renewable energies.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I just want stuff that works, David. That’s what I want to do.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK, Prime Minister, thank you for talking to us this morning. Appreciate it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks David, good to be with you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Scott Morrison joins us now from Melbourne, good morning to you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good morning Deb.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now you’ve gone in hard over the past fortnight to try and discredit Labor on border protection. This Newspoll though shows things haven’t shifted.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We’re just doing the right thing for Australia’s borders. That's why we are doing this.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You have been accused of scaremongering on this issue. Do you think that that’s not cutting with voters?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I know what the accusations are. I was accused of that when the boats were turning up thick and fast when we were in Opposition and people said I wouldn't be able to, as a team, turn it around.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now, you are taking the fight to Labor on the issue of climate and your Party we know has been tearing itself apart on this for years. It has brought down leaders on both sides of politics.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We have one and we have been achieving it is. It is a right thing to do for future generations.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Because I guess that would make people why we need to spend another $2 billion to get there, because you have said in the past as you have said now we will meet those Paris targets by 2030, and you used the language in a canter, so why do we need to do this spending?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And we will, Deb. Deb, I always knew we were going to put these policies in place and I was very clear about that all the way through and these are the policies that will continue to get us there in 2030.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We know how crucial credibility and authenticity is in politics and you were the Treasurer who came into Question Time with a lump of coal talking up fossil fuels. I guess the big question for voters is how can they trust you to turn things around on climate policy?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Because our policies have been working. We need to draw our energy from all sources, Deb, all sources.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: All right, Prime Minister, time is unfortunately against us as always. There is lots more to talk to you about.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks, Deb.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister Scott Morrison, good morning.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’day Neil, good to be with you. I’m sorry we couldn’t catch up the other day.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thank you, I understand you were ill. Thank you for your time.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I'm not commenting on where it might come from other than to say the sophistication, as I said in the Parliament yesterday, has led agencies to advise that this is a state actor but I'm not..

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What does that mean, what’s a state actor?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it means it’s a government. But we're not in any position to attribute that to any particular nation.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So we don't know who did it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We're not in a position to do that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sorry but who do you know who did it or not?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No what I'm saying is you don't go and make those claims wildly.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I'm not asking you to say.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'm not suggesting you are. So we don't have any information, I don't have any information that would enable me to make that claim.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you don't know who did it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I've said what I've said, Neil. That's a very specific wording I've used.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well clearly you've got suspicions.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it's not up to me to have suspicions and share them, it's up to me to to speak to the facts as we know them and what we can be very confident of.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can you give us a list of likely suspects?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: China says media speculation on this is heightening tensions between the two countries, is that right?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I'm not responsible for the media.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, no, but are tensions being heightened? Are tensions with China heightened?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We work constructively with China. I've met with [inaudible] as well as the President and we have a very important relationship with China and I'm very positive about particularly the economic growth of China.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, I take from what you said that you've got a fair idea who's responsible and you don't want to say it, is that right?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'm not going to get into a discussion on security matters.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But once it is established, will you make it public?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well again, whatever we might say would be a matter that I would consult with the National Security Committee of Cabinet.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Fair enough. What… what have they got on us? Whoever did it and whoever did it, what information they got now?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well yesterday Alastair MacGibbon I think sort of went into that and it's not clear what the precise purpose of this is at this stage. But those investigations continue and there is no suggestion that there is any, any at this point, any greater access to information.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If they've hacked in, there must be access to information.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I mean, people can make all sorts of suppositions. But I've just deal with the information that I have.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Is there any is there any evidence or suggestion that could have been an attempt to interfere with our democratic process?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, and I said that. There's no evidence to suggest that at this point.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Why else would you be hacking into the Parliament?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that’s supposition, that’s speculation. And what I said in the Parliament yesterday… see, as Prime Minister I've got to stay on the facts

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I understand, I understand.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The facts say that there is there is no evidence of that. But clearly one of the general areas of risk, not specific to what I'm, you know, I've identified in the Parliament yesterday is that we need to make sure Australia is protected from this.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But wasn't there a warning to upgrade the system in 2015, three or four years ago?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we did and have been.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The political parties as well?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The political parties do this under their own steam, just like any company or business does. And that's why all all businesses, all political organizations.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But would I be correct in saying the area that's been hacked has a lot of personal details and on a lot of voters?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That's not clear. I've heard that being suggested, but there's nothing to suggest, at least in front of me, that has occurred.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So it's possible, we don't really know.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well anything's possible but that doesn’t mean it happened.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK. Border protection.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well what Labor did last week was weaken them.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But hasn't Nauru fixed it now?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it's not quite clear what they've done and how that will play out. I think what's happened in Nauru is a good example of what happens and how Labor didn’t think through what playing around with border protection laws will do.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The reports are in Nauru though, limited medical evacuations and stopped remote assessment by doctors. Is that right?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I'm still getting reports in of exactly what they've decided to do and what the legal force of that is.  But look that's a matter for them and it's a reminder that it's their country.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But if they have done that, it certainly reinforces the strength and undermines your argument that it's weakened, doesn’t it? If they have done that?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: What Labor did was weaken our border protection.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And now Nauru has tightened it again.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well what Nauru has indeed done and, that it is legally able to be done, well we’ll make our assessment on that. But there's no leave pass here for Labor.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: ASIO also says the leak on their advice was incorrect and you were in part using that leak publicly to convince us the boats were coming. Are the boats still coming?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They were always at risk of coming. That never changes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But are the increased risks still there?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Of course there is. There's always that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Is it correct the US has refused entry to 265 people from Nauru who wanted to go there?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They were always not going to accept everybody, that's their own.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And why have they rejected them?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well for reasons that would suggest that they weren't welcome in the United States because they'd be concerned about who they were.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So what, matters of security?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They’re matters for the US and not for me to comment on.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But I mean I'm worried that the situation. The US could say these 265 people are not coming here but do they end up in Australia?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well not under our laws, but they can under Labor's.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So under these changes they could still come to Australia? Rejected by the US for security reasons, you’d assume.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s exactly right and this is the point we're making. Because in a lot of these cases, these people they won't have serious criminal convictions.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, I know you short for time.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh no, we’re good, we’re good.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Oh good. Why should we trust Border Force? I mean, they have mucked up this footballer, Hakeem al-Araibi.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well you know I'll be taking that up with Border Force. There had been a review into these matters internally.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But he wouldn't have been there of Border Force had done their job properly.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No I don't..

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A couple of minutes prior, are you happy Mathias Cormann, your Finance Minister, took a junket, free tickets for a family holiday from a company that had just won a billion dollar contract? Is that… it doesn’t look good.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that is not what happened.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But he did he take free tickets, didn’t he?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well no he didn't. He thought he was paying for them.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Who paid for them?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: He has paid.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He has after he got caught.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Because he wasn't aware. He wasn't aware.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He wasn't aware and he wasn't paying for the tickets?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No that's the statement that he's made and he had nothing to do with the issuing of the contract, by the way, that had been issued prior and Ministers aren’t involved in those decisions. There's a clear separation that minister… any suggestion that the two were linked would be complete rubbish.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bit it is not a good look, though.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that's why he's cleaned it up.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: After. I've just robbed a bank but I'll give the money back.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No I think that's a bit unfair to put it in those terms.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It probably is.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: There was that oversight which had been identified and he fixed it up. I mean what more can he do?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He could not have taken the free tickets in the first place.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: But he didn't take free tickets in the first place.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well they paid for his tickets.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: He was fully… they were going to bill him and he didn’t get billed and that was drawn to his attention he paid the bill.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well what about another case, a former Minister and a Minister Michael Keenan and Michaelia Cash refusing to cooperate with the police investigation. That's outrageous.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s not true.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Did they refuse to give an interview?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They were written to and they were asked to respond which they did and they provided responses and the police have not sought any further statement from them. So they have cooperated.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It's reported today they refused to give statements to federal police, is that right?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They provided a response and the police have accepted that response and they haven't sought any I'm advised, any further statement.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So the police didn't want a statement, so they..

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I'm just saying that cooperate with the investigation and nothing's been sought from them. And remember what this is about.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A political leak.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Misuse of union funds by the AWU, Bill Shorten’s union. There was a raid because the police believe they were destroying evidence that may have suggested that the Shorten’s union was sending money, allegedly, to GetUp! and even to his own benefit.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well I thought everybody should cooperate. You would hope, that didn’t happen here in Victoria.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They should, you’re dead right Neil. People should cooperate with police investigations and my Ministers have.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK speaking just quickly of Victoria, a three billion dollar cheque you us for a road down here. Are we going to get it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I will continue to work with the Victorian government. Let's just be very clear.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, you've come back in the polls. Is that the message you're getting from the ground, you’re back in the fight?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Look all I've been doing Neil is [inaudible], showing Australians what our record is on national security, on the economy and that's what guarantees essential services. People I'm finding when I when I'm relating this to them, are responding well.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I assume you're confident about being re-elected.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Of course. I mean, I didn't take the job on to, you know, to do anything else but that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If you are re-elected, given the history of the party in recent years, can you guarantee to stay Prime Minister for three years?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Because our party resolved that last year. An elected Liberal Prime Minister will now have the security of that arrangement over the next term.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well if you’re not re-elected do you want to be opposition leader?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'm not contemplating that situation. I'm contemplating being re-elected and ensuring that we continue to keep Australia safe, secure borders, and keep our economy strong.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well they’re both hypothetical

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Not in my mind. I’m dealing with the reality.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So what emoji are you going to put on your number plate?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh a big smiley face, mate. A big smiley face.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Might be grumpy.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good on you Neil, cheers mate.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good morning Alan.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thank you for your time. Could I just begin by saying that politicians rarely get praise.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It was heartbreaking. It was devastating, not just there but also over Cloncurry.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It's the fourth biggest export market.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah it is just … so we're there, that's the commitment I made. The reconstruction effort, it’s going to be significant and it's going to take a long time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can I come to that in a moment, just on basically what you saw. I mean, how long did they tell you… I know the military have got about 150 personnel on the ground.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They all are. Look, the way I'm looking at it, there's three stages to this.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yes, they don't want the councils. They're worried about the council, it’s separate from the graziers.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They're supporting them in it but they just don't want, you know, people just stomping all over their properties. They know how to do this, they're getting the support through both the safety equipment and the protective gear, which you need because I tell you, you smell this stuff long before you see it and it has to be done.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And it stays with you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The Queensland Government is working with us on that. The military are directly involved.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: There’s still an area the size of England underwater. There’s still an area the size of England underwater.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: There’s an inland sea. I saw it was making its way down through the Gulf.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Just stop there for a minute, just stop there for one minute. There’s a lot of people out there that know this bloke, Scott Morrison.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well they were very encouraged and it's great to be able to do that as a Prime Minister. Because what they really want is the plan to go forward.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: They do.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They want to rebuild and they know it's not going to be easy. And it's different station by station, Alan.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You said you'd cut red tape so that small business operators – this is at the bottom end of the market - could get $25,000 disaster relief payments. Philip Alexander, the supermarket owner, told you that no one fitted into the category and he said I can't handle this paperwork.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it means I'm working on that now. One of the things I brought back - I'm going to be working Michaelia Cash and the Queensland Government over the course of this week - my first priority was to sort out the paperwork on the $75,000 for the producers, for the graziers.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can I just raise this with you - and I wrote to you about this - but you have said quite a few times since Friday, you've talked about a 10 year rescue plan. PM, many of these people won't be here in 10 years.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well they’re completely different things. I mean the Great Barrier Reef Foundation that's money to actually apply over that period of time Alan and it's being done through one organization, so that wasn’t just today, that was for many, many years to come.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay well what do you say –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: What we’re talking about here, up in north Queensland

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: They’ve got no money, no income.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I understand that and this will cost hundreds of millions of dollars if not more.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It will, it will.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It's going to require a reconstruction plan, property by property. It's going to require dealing with existing debt.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But you see, the date today Scott, the date today Prime Minister, is the 18th February 18. Come March 1 the mortgage payments due.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No but they won't be Alan. That's the thing, the banks are already –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But for the workers, it’s due for the worker as well, it's due for the small businessman in Townsville.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Exactly and that's why we'll work on those 25,000 payments and their extension. That's why we've put the 1 million bucks into every single council.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Where does the money come from, to go out and buy the fence posts, to be able to start fencing hundreds of miles that have been destroyed?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that's what we'll do, property by property by property. One thing I'm not going to do is rush to failure on this.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay just a couple of things before you go. Kerryn Phelps has been in Parliament for five minutes, we now face 2008 revisited, when Labor abolished the Pacific solution.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And temporary protection visas.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And temporary protection visas. That cost us 16 billion dollars.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, it says we need to firm up Operation Sovereign Borders, which is exactly what I did the day after, and on the day of the vote I convened the National Security Committee. We put those measures in place.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That was recommended to you by Home Affairs.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: By Home Affairs, exactly. So you've got the Labor Party out there saying; “Oh, we will always follow the advice of agencies on this”.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What is the problem with Nauru? I don't understand what the problem with Manus is, I mean there’s 64 professionals there, half of them are doctors.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: If you had anywhere in Australia the ratio of medical professionals to people –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: One to seven?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah one to seven and 14 – 1 for mental health services. I mean, there's nowhere in the country to my knowledge that that's it's that concentrated, not even in Wentworth for goodness sake with the number of doctors they have there.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You should open a detention centre there. What's the point of going to the polls, if in fact migration policy and refugee policy is going to be determined by doctors?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That's what Labor have done. That's exactly what they have done, taking it away.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I will just confirm, you already have, sorry - it was last week, before this rubbish was passed – a Transitory Persons Committee don't you? I think within the Department of Home Affairs and they meet once a month?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Medical professionals.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s right, they assess the needs and seek urgent medical care, the mechanism is in place and there have been transfers from the Papua New Guinea or Nauru since July 2016.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: There have.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That's already being done. So basically, this is a heap of humbug.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They sought to solve a problem that didn't exist.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yep.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And as a result - you know, what I should be focusing on, only frankly, at the moment is dealing with these issues in north Queensland not having to reopen a detention centre on Christmas Island because Bill Shorten the Labor Party wanted to go and crash border protection in this country.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And implement a policy –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The money I’m going to spend on Christmas Island, I would very much like to be spending all of that up in north Queensland. That's where the rubber hits the road.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well if the Labor Party - and this very political, I know he’s pretending it’s not –

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Just on North Queensland, let me be clear, I'm still going to make sure that’s happening. But you can imagine my fury and frustration.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And I think the public feel that way as well and it is political. He’s saying; “Oh, get the politics out of it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that's right and they say they'll still turn boats back. Well, really? really? Tanya Plibersek sitting in the National Security Committee with Bill Shorten? “Trust us, we’ll still turn boats back”.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Good on you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I know, I did it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yes, I know. Well listen we thank you for that, we'll talk again and we'll keep you posted on the feedback from the farmers as well.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Can I just say one last thing Alan.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yes?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Sisters of the North; they have done an amazing job in raising funds for people up there and there's a bloke up there, Tim Pratt who runs a trucking company.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yes, the cap.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: He was the one, I wore a cap of his and people sledged me for the hat.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The cap on, good on you. Good on you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: But he's got a thing called Gumnut Designz and they're selling hats to raise money for Sisters of the North which is supporting those local charities up there. In about 24 hours they'd raised 120 grand, when I got there on Thursday night.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Leave it with me.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I'll send you the details.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’day Ben.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thank you very much for joining us on the line.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s alright, Tony was making a lot of sense there, I didn’t want to interrupt him.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I thought you might have been listening in and I know you’ve had a busy afternoon, so thank you for jumping on the line and talking to us. Look, he was suggesting that this was evidence, what we’re watching today, with Bill Shorten’s support of this medevac bill, that he’s not fit to be Prime Minister.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it is. He hasn’t got the ticker for it when it comes to this stuff.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’ve acted as Immigration Minister, you know more about stopping boats than anyone else in Australia; will people smugglers re-start their trade because of this bill?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That is the great risk we’re now facing. I’m going to do everything to make sure that doesn’t happen and the only thing standing between a boat and Australia is me and Peter Dutton and our Government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Is it right that there’s already been a reaction in parts of the world where people smugglers ply their trade, that there’s already chatter in that part of the world?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: “Guess what, they changed the laws down there in Australia, you can get on a boat now. Let’s go” that’s what they do.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I can remember a Four Corners investigation into people smugglers and some of them that were based here in Australia and that was the case.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I remember the interviews with some of the people and they were just saying; ‘They kept lying to us and lying to us and lying to us about where we were going, what we were doing, what would happen when we were on the boat.” That’s obviously what they do.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They’re criminals. That’s what criminals do, they lie.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Have our intelligence agencies actually heard any chatter though, because it’s being reported by David Speers, that he’s been told that Australia’s intelligence agencies believe that “the beast is stirring,” since the passage of the medevac bill? They’re trying to ensure that the beast doesn’t wake up, the beast of course being the people smuggling trade. Have you been told by our intelligence agencies that there is chatter?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I could never confirm that one way or the other Ben, because that’s intelligence that I receive as Prime Minister. So I can’t comment on that for obvious reasons, but what my job is, is to make sure that beast doesn’t wake up.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: One of the issues here obviously is that when people get a medical transfer to Australia then a lot of them then launch legal actions to stay. I think out of those who have come here, more than half of them have done that, engaged lawyers and said; “Righto, I’m not going back.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s exactly what happens, that’s exactly what happens. So look, this is why they play with this stuff thinking they can appease people in their own party.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I really got the sense watching you at the National Press Club that you are going to stick a stake in the ground on this and just stand to it and not budge a centimetre. And you made a call and I’m paraphrasing here, but you said; “Bill Shorten is looking for the middle ground here, but you can’t find middle ground on 1,200 people dying.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I remember the debates. I remember when that boat crashed up on the jagged rocks of Christmas Island.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And if anyone is trying to convince you to change your mind, forget about it, it’s game on.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Absolutely. I mean, I know what works.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, thanks for joining us, appreciate your time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thank you for your time.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks Alan.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Just a quick one on Townsville, I know you have been there.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I have. Look, all the best of Australia is on display in Townsville, as you’d expect it to be.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can I just tell you what they’re saying though on struggle street. They’re not harsh, we’re not harsh about foreign aid, our foreign aid bill is $4.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It goes much more than that. I mean, there is a 13 week disaster allowance payment for those whose incomes are disrupted…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But are you going to throw any money in there to restore and rehabilitate these people?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Of course we are, and that’s exactly why I was up there today and that’s the next phase of the recovery. We went to Category C today in terms of the assistance that’s provided.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: They’ve lost businesses.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I know, and that’s what this support does. It provides concessional loans for businesses to get through, it provides that additional support.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How would you like to get a concessional loan though, you can’t pay it back.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We’re going to be spending tens of millions of dollars in Townsville just on the income support payments and the emergency payments alone. That’s before we get into the infrastructure side of things on the other side of this.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Absolutely true. Look, this has come back this Kerryn Phelps bill.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: So do I.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I was under the impression… Pardon?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: So do I, it is diabolical.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You have written though Mr Shorten…

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I have.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I was under the impression that you would be voting against the bill.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We are.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’re going to vote against the bull?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Of course.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But there is an argument that that would create a constitutional crisis and you’d be frightened of going to an election.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s rubbish.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well where does this business come from about you proposing a so-called ‘medical transfer clinical assurance panel’ to quote, “Provide clinical assurance on decisions about medical evacuations.” In other words, you’re not going to outsource it to two doctors but you’re going to actually agree with the Phelps proposal.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: the way it works currently is clinicians decide whether someone should be transferred, OK? That’s not going to change. There’s clinicians who work within the Department of Home Affairs and they make the decisions about who moves and who doesn’t and that’s overseen by the Department of Home Affairs.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Kerryn Phelps… just one thing, can I sum up. The Kerryn Phelps Bill as I see it simply, in language that struggle street understands, is outsourcing immigration policy to two doctors.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And it is worse than that. Let me take you through it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well PM, he has already supported it. Labor have supported it in the Upper House.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They’ve already voted for it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Absolutely. So it’s through one Chamber of Parliament.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No he hasn’t responded to me as yet. We will see.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But just summing up simply, because you’ve got to get this message through simply. Doesn’t even such a minor change, isn’t that really an incentive to people smugglers to start up?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh there’s no doubt. It is exactly as you said with the fishing boat captain from Indonesia.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you’re not scared of the fight next week?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Not at all Peta.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: One of the messages that kept coming out in the last few days is that you’re looking to find a back door way to avoid the Phelps vote. But if it goes to a vote, you’re prepared to stand and fight on principle?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We’ll vote it down.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That will harden your support?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: If that means that the vote goes down, it will be on Bill Shorten’s head. Now, Bill Shorten wants me to blame the crossbenchers for this.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Good on you. Just on letters, to get away from all of this, you actually have written to the Prime Minister of Thailand about that soccer player Hakeem which I find a disgraceful episode, he’s gone there.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah he has, we got a response the other night. I have also written to him again, that letter crossed over on my second because I was very disturbed at the appearance of Hakeem at the hearing the other day.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We helped rescue people from a cave, didn’t we?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: This is true and they were our Australians of the Year, in fact. And so we will continue to make these representations, not just to Thailand but also to Bahrain as well, and we are.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The bloke’s in jail.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we’re in a process there but as I said on the road the other day, it’s not my job to get upset, it’s my job to get him home.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Just let me allude to a speech you made last week, you said it’s important to remind all of us that our economy cannot be taken for granted. That the economy is real, its impacts are real, and most importantly it’s about people.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: $200 billion. Or as you said the other day, $20 thousand million.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s right, $20 thousand million, I’m telling you to say it and I’ve got it mixed up myself. $20 thousand million worth of taxes.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s true and the most pernicious is this retiree tax. $5 billion a year stolen from the lives of retired Australians but also small business owners and others who are affected.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let me take you to a point that Chris Bowen has made which, if I might say to you, critically I don’t think your Government has addressed. I’ve never heard a more nonsense observation, he said, “Why are we the only country in the world who would let people claim an income tax refund when they paid no income tax in this year? It’s generous but it’s not sustainable.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well this is right. In cases when you take in all the benefits and so on, you can have cases of people earning up to 80,000 a year and they pay no net tax.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Good on you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And in comes the big dark hand of Labor to rip it out of your pockets.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well done.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We’re fighting this every day and Australians are waking up to it. And it’s not just the retirees.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s a good argument, that. They’ve paid tax all their life, that answers that argument.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They have. It was bipartisan policy and the reason they’re doing it is because they don’t know how to control their spending.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And Kim Beazley argued, and Simon Crean who was the leader said, “We must do this because it’s fair.”

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And look, they’re angry because in the 2016 Budget the Liberal Party hit them with superannuation changes when Tony Abbott and you were elected under the same banner in 2013 said there wouldn’t be. I’m going to ask you a question, put you in the hot seat, will there be any changes if you’re elected next term on superannuation or do you rule them out?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I rule them out.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No further changes?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, none. I think last time I was on the program I said the same thing.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can we just take this negative gearing thing, just very very simple. I mean, there is a bit of a housing crisis at the moment.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: 30 per cent of the housing market is rental accommodation as a result of mum and dad investors.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So if suddenly that incentive doesn’t exist, I’ll take my $600,000 and I’ll put it into BHP shares. Therefore, there is less rental accommodation.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: This is exactly as it is. This is how I describe their policy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can I just be a bit critical of you here if I might. Do you think you’re fighting on too many front? I think with an election coming, there are certain issues here which really dramatically… I mean, I’m not really worried about tariffs on kavas or whatever you were talking about in Fiji.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That was a very specific issue for them.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Right, these are powerful points. See, if you take the Capital Gains Tax.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s right.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: There’s nothing wrong with making a quid. They’re going to increase the tax on the Capital Gain by 50 per cent.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: 50 per cent on everything, not just on… it’s on shops, small businesses. See, you were talking about negative gearing before.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, it’s ordinary people.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The vast majority of people… you know, there are more people who negative gear properties in the federal electorate of Capricornia based on Rockhampton than in my southern seat of Cook in Sydney. Because people up there have worked in the mining industry, in the construction industry, and they’re creating opportunities for themselves.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We’re going to go, you’ve got to go somewhere else. You’ve been everywhere today.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it’s pretty simple. A 45 per cent emissions reduction target wipes out Australian industries.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: …investing in new, coal-fired power station this side of an election? Do we think anyone is going to get into the market?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well you couldn’t build one of this side of the election.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, I’m not suggesting that at all PM. But people have been talking underwater.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well they’ve got to make it stack up, as you know. I mean, the new ones…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You could build a dam.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we’re putting money into dams as you know, and there’s quite a number, we’re doing one up in North Queensland in Hughenden, that’s one we’ve been moving on over the last few months.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But coal today, in the ABS stats, is our number one export. It’s propping up everyone’s budgets right around the country, yet we’re treating it like it’s a demon property here in Australia, likes it’s kryptonite.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I believe we’ll see, whether it’s that or that extended life of existing stations done on a commercial basis, but it all has to be done on a commercial basis.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But can you look down the camera here before you go and just say, as the Prime Minister of Australia, you want to tell all Australians there is no future other than a future in the dark if we don’t understand the importance of coal-fired power to the economic and personal well-being of Australians.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I will say, I don’t care where the power comes from, so long as it’s reliable and it turns up every day…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And affordable.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And of course affordable. And it is going to, that is going to be a big part of the mix for a very long time to come.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Coal, you mean.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Now that is true, as is gas, as is hydro.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: There’s the camera, what do you say to the Australian people? Coal is going to be a part of mix.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’d really like them to get the gas out from under the ground, Alan, they’ve locked it up here in New South Wales and in Victoria for too long and you know what that’s done to electricity prices? That.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Coal-fired power. Listen, good to talk to you.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: You too.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thank you for what you’re doing and we’ll talk again, we hope.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah and congratulations to Johnny Morris too, I think he’s going to do a great job down with those Sharks, what do you reckon?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Hmm, well this is Cronulla of course, the Prime Minister is a Cronulla supporter. I think what the Rugby League has done to Shane Flanagan is a disgrace.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well you know my view on that, you and I are both big fans of Shane and he has got a wonderful family and he has been a great son of the Shire down there.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A good man.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: He is a good man.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He made the mistake of speaking to his players when they were really facing personal crisis. If that’s a mistake, I’m on Shane Flanagan’s side.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we’ve both always been on that side, for a long time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Go and get the cap on, we’ll see you next time.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It’s been great to here in Brisbane all week actually, we’ve had a really, really strong week and great to see so many wonderful people out and about.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Before we have a proper chat we should take care of business because we’ve been saying that we’re going to do ‘Smarter than Suse’ so let’s do that first and then we’ll have a proper chat after, see how you go against Sue.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Sure this is, you know, this is crunch time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah it’s cattle stations

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Are you aware of the stickers? There’s that one if you win.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well my secret in life is to always have assumed that I’m never the smartest person in the room. Plenty of people assume the opposite and usually get themselves into trouble.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Either with the honest part or Suse sticker-

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A lot to play for.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’m not smarter than Suse either.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Here we go.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So Suse is in the sound proof booth, you can testify to that ScoMo.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: [inaudible]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It is legit she can’t hear us in there. Now I don’t if your people behind the scenes have explain the rules or I’ll go through it here.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Go through them.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So what you’ve gone on, I’m going to ask you five questions. You’ve got 30 seconds to answer those five questions, OK? Now if you want to you can pass and we’ll come back to it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: OK.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But Suse never gets beaten on time and if it’s a draw the person with the quickest time wins.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Sure.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So don’t pass, just say you don’t know and move on.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If you say don’t know I’ll just go straight on to the next question.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Won’t come back to it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: OK let’s see how we go.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Alright, Prime Minister you’ve up against Susan. Prime Minister you’ve got 30 seconds on the clock and your time starts now.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Wellington.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Name the comedian who withdrew from hosting the 2019 Oscars?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Pass.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Spell vacuum.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: V A C U U M.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What kind of animal is the Disney character Dumbo?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: An elephant.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What is 176 minus 86?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Name the comedian who withdrew from hosting the 2019 Oscars? Dunno?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Dunno.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So stop, stop. Yeah so we had to go back because you said pass.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh sorry.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You burnt some time there, that’s what I’m sort of saying but that’s alright. Not bad, not bad on time you had five seconds left.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It was pretty good.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So if it comes down to it that could be enough-

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: She sometimes struggles on the spelling too.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Here she comes now by the way PM you are playing for Brenda from Aspley so if you beat-

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: She’s one of your constituents. Is Aspley one of your seats? I don’t know what that would be um, I don’t think is.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, no it’s a long way north.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You could win, you could a win a vote here.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Cronulla is a long way from Aspley.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah I think Aspley might be within a Labor seat.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I was just checking my previous results against ah, I beat Turnbull.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Oh did you?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I lost against Shorten.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Oh OK, alright.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m not planning to do that.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: This could be a benchmark here, let’s see how we go.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: [Advertising read out].

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Pump her up for code of conduct? In general terms don’t put a balaclava over your head when you’re in the same room as the Prime Minister but he has to do this as a thing.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Music played]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We’ve got to explain to the Prime Minister why you’re wearing what you’re wearing right now.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Susie says it distracts from the fact that I’ve got a huge nose and I’ve got a forehead, a massive forehead and googly eyes and I sometimes put her off so she’s asked for me to wear the ski mask-

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s self-explanatory you didn’t really need to explain it.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s really ugly, that’s what it is, yeah.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you do that with any of your employees, do you ask them to wear a ski mask?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: There’s one in every office.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Don’t do it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Don’t answer that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Alright, Susan O’Neill up against the Prime Minister you’ve got 30 seconds on the clock and your time starts now.  What is the capital of New Zealand?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Christchurch.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Name the comedian who withdrew from hosting the 2019 Oscars?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Jimmy Kimmel.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Spell vacuum?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: V A C double U M.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What kind of animal is the Disney character Dumbo?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He’s an elephant.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What is 176 minus 86?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Stop the clock.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Quick, that’s good on time. You had ten seconds left Suse.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well done Susie, well done.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: [inaudible]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Only in the event of a tie breaker.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh we’ve got to go again?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, no. We just go through the score, yeah.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Let’s go through it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK the capital of New Zealand, Prime Minister said it was Wellington. Suse you said it was Christchurch.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Is it? How do you know that?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Because he’s the Prime Minister.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He went to Sydney Boys High.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: If I didn’t know it would be a problem.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How offended would New Zealand be?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can you imagine if you answered that incorrectly? That would have been worldwide news today.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The New Zealand PM on the phone. You what? You said what?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s one nil to the Prime Minister. Name the comedian who withdrew from the hosting the 2019 Oscars.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Jimmy Kimmel or something.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Kevin Hart.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Oh, that’s right.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s one nil Prime Minister.  Top of the third spell vacuum, you both said V A C U U M.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well done.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well done Scott.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well-

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And we hand over the official sticker which I’m sure you’ll appreciate.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: She’s the bigger legend there’s no doubt about that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: She’s the cat’s mother [laughter] sorry that’s a private joke.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Brenda out at Aspley picked up 100 bucks too and maybe a vote for you I’d have to say.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good on you Brenda tell your friends.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And we’ll come back and chat with the Prime Minister right after this.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Advertisement/traffic advice/music break]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s what this stuff is about I mean, I mean I’m you know families are important, families should have meals together at night and not spend, you know, the evenings-

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: [Inaudible] in traffic, what you realise is how quickly Brisbane is growing, I mean Ash drives from the coast every day I did it this morning from down at Coolangatta and if you’re not past Springwood by 20 past 5 you’re done, like it’s gridlock at that hour, people are up early, there’s so many more people on the roads so it’s moving, the wheels keep moving.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s the big thing I think in Brisbane say over the last ten/15 years I mean, you know, I grew up in Sydney and it’s always been congested and we’ve got to do a lot there too and Melbourne is the same but Brisbane has been growing really rapidly and that’s been great because people’s businesses have been growing and they’ve been doing well and there’s lots of jobs and that’s all fantastic but you’ve got to keep the congestion busting happening.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Have you noticed the scooters around? Because Brisbane is like the test city for those electric scooters.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh yeah, I saw a bloke zipping along Story Bridge yesterday.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah, they’re everywhere.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: He was fanging it, he was-

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I don’t get it quite frankly.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I reckon they’re brilliant, yeah. So what do you reckon about them? Do you have an opinion on them yet?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh I don’t really care but so long as they’re safe and they don’t run into people.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I mean you could have idiots riding ‘em because that’s human nature but you know on the whole they’re getting people off the roads you know, getting people scooting-

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So is that only Brisbane?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Only Brisbane at this stage.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s a test for Australia, yeah.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Kids like Segways and these things, I mean Segways are important tools for people with disabilities.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah, yeah that’s alright, yeah.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I would never step on a Segway, it seems incredibly dangerous to me.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And the PM was telling a story, sorry Suse, PM was telling us off air that you swim every day, like you started incorporating swimming into your, into your routine now.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah I do well it’s for exercise but I’m a firm believer that politicians’ exercise should be kept very, not done in public, it’s not a pretty sight.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well how do you do that then?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh you make the time, it’s a good head space and it’s also, you know, good exercise and you know you’ve got to do that in these sorts of jobs and I’m enjoying it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: DTs or boardies?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: As I said it’s done in private.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s very much done in private.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I want to say nude?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What’s a tip Suse, what’s the tip?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Not a tip I was going to, I was actually going to say don’t wear budgie smugglers-

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s been done hasn’t it?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: [Inaudible] I love it, it’s great stress release isn’t it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah it is I just got to get the breathing right and I’m getting it there, I’ve got up to about 600 metres a day so that’s, if I can do it all in one go it will be even better.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Good on ya.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How long are you in Brissy for?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh I’ve been here all week, I’m heading back down to Sydney tonight.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thanks for coming in.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, no it’s great to be here, thanks for the fun and thanks for the opportunity to-

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You might have to race Susie in the pool next time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Oh that’s a good idea because I’d win that one.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’ll just take this one, I’m not faster than Susie right now.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And finally we all saw a picture of Shorten during the week making his kids’ lunches which I’m sure he does every day, I’m sure that wasn’t a photo op-

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The strategically placed Vegemite sitting there. I didn’t think there was anything contrived about that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, no it seemed very natural.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Really fair dinkum.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But he was making his, that was the worst picture by the way, but he was making his kids’ sandwiches with wholemeal bread. Don’t do that to your children.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I don’t make the kids’ lunches.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You don’t?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I don’t make them. They’ll be happy about that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Have you ever said when a kid goes Dad can you do something, you go gosh I thought I was the Prime Minister?

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’d be dropping that every day.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s true at most places but not my house.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister welcome to 7.30 for 2019.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Great to be back Leigh.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Coalition has been in an election losing position in the polls for virtually its entire term. You have members of your frontbench choosing not to contest the election, high profile independents are running in key Liberal seats, cashed up groups like GetUp! are targeting you in vital marginal seats, all this against the recent backdrop of Coalition disunity and instability.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, Leigh, I mean, just as well I’m a fighter when you listen to what you’ve just relayed out there which is I think is a particularly pessimistic way to look at things. I’m not looking at things like that at all.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: When you’re talking about, as you say 1.25 million jobs, also income tax cuts, more spending on health and education, return to surplus, a ten year plan to eliminate debt.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No that’s actually not true, Leigh, I mean doing what we’ve pledged today on jobs would actually not be at the peak rate of jobs growth that we’ve achieved over the last couple of years so I think that-

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But it’s the environment with all those other factors-

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, no not at all, Leigh. One of the marks of our economic management is that we’ve always exceeded expectations.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: On this point though that you’ve exceeded, that your government has exceeded expectations the Coalition record, doesn’t that pitch simply confuse voters along the lines of ‘well, hang on if your record is so good why did you need to dump Malcolm Turnbull?’

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that was last year, Leigh, and what we’re focussed on is the plan we’re taking to the next election. It’s a plan based on our policy successes as a-

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: [inaudible]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: …government over the last five, I know your point is-

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: My point is that-

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Your point is about politics-

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: [inaudible] aren’t you confusing, no aren’t you confusing voters? You’re saying our record is so fantastic, we’ve exceeded expectations it’s confusing to people, they just saw a Prime Minister get dumped a matter of months ago.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: My break over the summer involved talking to people who were sharing with me about their need for having their job secure, being able to get home in time to spend time with their families which is why today I announced another $240 million going into urban congestion busting projects here in South East Queensland and that’s what we’re focussed on; the things that actually improve people’s lives. We’ve got a great track record of delivering on infrastructure because people can see the earth machine, moving machinery on sites now.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: On policy you also have a plan you were discussing today, a ten year plan to wipe out debt, but that would mean for that plan to reach fruition the Coalition would be re-elected three times, there would be no external shocks. What do you say to the suggestion that that’s a plan at best based on rose coloured glasses and at worst a fantasy?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No what I said today is my goal is to see that debt gone, net debt gone by 2030. Now the decisions that made in the next three years in the budget will determine what happens with that budget over the next ten years.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sorry, just while you’re on debt, you’ve been in office now for six years, you point out that Labor had a debt problem. Net debt at the end of their term in office was $202 billion, net debt today is $341 billion, you’ve taken it in the wrong direction.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well because we’ve had to wind back the deficits of Labor and get the budget back into balance. You can’t reduce debt, Leigh, if you’re still running deficits.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: While we’re on Labor, you’ve said repeatedly today that the Australian economy will be weaker under a Labor government because it will impose higher taxes.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Correct.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Where’s your evidence that higher taxes weaken an economy?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I think it’s just fundamental economics 101, Leigh.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But the Howard Government imposed a very big new tax on Australia, the GST, are you saying they weakened the economy?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, they abolished taxes at the same time, Leigh. They actually lessened the overall individual tax burden on Australians.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But by your logic, if higher taxes in and of themselves generally weaken an economy, a country like Norway should be weak but it has some of the highest taxes in the world and yet the average Norwegian is richer and has a higher standard of living than the average Australian.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Australia has had 27 years of continuous economic growth. We are at the top of the leader pack when it comes to advanced developed economies in the world for economic growth, the world is looking to us in terms of how we’ve been able to succeed and how we’ve been able to succeed as a government is by keeping taxes low, backing small business, investing in infrastructure so people can get home on time and tradies can spend more time on the time and not in a traffic jam, expanding our export markets, defence industry procurement plans.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: On the 1.25 million jobs that you’re promising if re-elected, of those how many will be filled by migrants?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well migrants form part of the overall population flows into the country, we don’t have a breakdown of that, Leigh.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Of the million jobs you’ve created how many have been filled by migrants?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I don’t have those figures to hand, Leigh. What I do know is that population growth has not run as high as jobs growth.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Would it surprise you that half of the million jobs you’ve created were filled by migrants?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: What I’m saying, Leigh, is that all Australians who are living here are getting more jobs today than they were before. When we came to office, the rate of jobs growth in Australia under Labor was 0.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let’s quickly run through some other issues before we run out of time. The Banking Royal Commission, does your government commit to implementing all of Commissioner Hayne’s recommendations?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well in principle this is what our intention would be, but we’ve obviously got to see a report before we make a decision on that and that’s why the Treasurer has announced today that in a very measured process, over the weekend, once we receive that report which will be in the middle of a market day so you wouldn’t go and release it while the markets were open, the government will consider that over the weekend and provide an interim and initial, if not final, response on the Monday after the lockup after markets close. Now that’s important to ensure that there’s stability in the financial system, you don’t go shocking financial markets, you take your time on this.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We’ve seen evidence in those hearings of banks effectively stealing from customers, for example charging people for financial advice that they never intended to provide, would you expect criminal charges to flow from the Royal Commission?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m going to wait to see what he recommends, I’m not going to speculate on it. But I want to commend Commissioner Hayne for the outstanding job he has done.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Three of your ministers, as I mentioned earlier, have said that they won’t recontest the federal election. You’ve said today that it’s offensive that their stated personal reasons for leaving are twisted into politics, for a political motivation.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It is actually.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Perception is everything in politics, and three ministers quitting gives voters the perception of rats deserting a sinking ship.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well who is creating that perception? The Labor Party have.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well haven’t three ministers in a row by saying they… [inaudible]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No they haven’t, because they have made very clear their personal reasons for doing that. Just like Gai Brodtmann did, just like Kate Ellis did, just like Jenny Macklin did, just like Wayne Swan did, just like Jacinta Collins has done, and what I find upsetting is, you know me Leigh, I’m for family values and when people raise issues like miscarriages with me, I’m not going to be so insensitive as to not understand fully the reasons for that decision.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Just quickly, if the Coalition loses the election do you commit to staying on as leader of the party and therefore opposition leader?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m committed to winning the next election, and in the Liberal Party…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If you lose though? As you said before it is a tough job.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It’s a tough job. That’s not my plan.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And just finally on this programme recently Mr Shorten committed to doing two prime time interviews with 7.30 during the election campaign, would you be prepared to commit to the same?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We’ll go through the normal process of setting those Leigh, I’ve always been very available to 7.30 and always enjoy our friendly chats.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well in that vein I look forward to seeing you twice in the election campaign, thank you very much.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good on you Leigh. Good to talk to you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Scott Morrison, good morning.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Great to be with you John, I’ve always enjoyed coming in to be on your program. I remember once I called into you from Christmas Island on one occasion.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well you just reminded me it goes back to 2005.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Correct, yes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: When you were just out of school.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I was a little bit out of there I’ve got to say but mate, it’s good to be back here with you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Before we doing anything seriously, you went to Hemingway’s. Tell me, you went down there to have a few drinks with people down at Hemingway’s?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah we had a Politics in the Pub last night and then sort of moved more generally. This is the great thing about Cairns and about tourism in Cairns; it’s constantly reinventing the place.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Please tell everybody. By the way, do you keep your finger on the pulse of tourism? I mean, you were involved up to your neck for years?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah I do because I know how important it is obviously to the country, particularly in regional areas. I’ve got to say, that’s one of the things that - I mean, Labor are proposing to get rid of the second year backpacker visa, if they’re elected.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now we’ve got to get stuck into some of the matters of the day and of course there’s $60 million you’re pledging to build this so-called Cairns Tropical Enterprise Centre. We’re talking about tertiary hospital status.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well 150 beds at Cairns hospital for a start. You know that means you won’t have to go south to get treatment and this is important.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you know what we’re excited about up here? It’s the 48 day party to celebrate the 250th anniversary of James Cook and the Endeavour. Let me just read this from the Cairns post today, a likeness of the; “little old man whose gift of a broken spear to Captain Cook is considered Australia’s first act of reconciliation.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yep.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A whole lot of people, including myself, didn’t know the ins and outs of that first - not confrontation - it was a genuine expression of getting on together. It goes back 250 years, it’s a great story.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It is a great story and these are the stories we’re looking to be told with this re-enactment of that voyage. So yes, we’re putting around $5.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah, yeah.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: The historical record may say something different. But that was the most perilous part of Cook’s voyage, what happened there and their ability to be able to engage with local Indigenous peoples and have those stories was no doubt key to their survival at that time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you know - I don’t know how old you were in 1988 - but when the big event, the ships around Australia, those beautiful sails when they came into the inlet the place was chock-a-block. So many people remember that day.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
