items.value: As I was just mentioning, it’s 39 stops and we’re looking forward to that program and we’ve ensured it can go the full distance. It’s an opportunity for people to come along to each of those little towns and each of those ports.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yes, very fashionable now.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Very trendy to talk down James Cook and all that sort of stuff. But this guy was an enlightened man for his generation and his time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let’s go to a couple of serious matters now. Last time you were up here we had that incursion there up at the Daintree, people trying to get into Australia, the boat sank, you know the story.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Nothing will change under our Government because we know what we’re doing works. I know because I designed it and we put it in place.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I want to take you to another matter basically it’s self-interest, but we are talking about the future of our port at Trinity Inlet. Now there has been a lot of talk about the expansion of Naval Facilities up there at Manus Island.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: upgrading of some of that infrastructure, those issues will undoubtedly have to be dealt with. I think there is opportunity for private investment in that as well, because you create the critical mass once you once you have Offshore Patrol Boats being serviced out of here, that creates the capacity for marine-based industry to do even more.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You used this term “strategic port status” I don’t know if it is going to be strong enough to unshackle the restraints on our need long term for dredging work. Now there is a smaller project underway at the moment, it’s about say a million cubic metres, a lot of people say we need a project of four and a half million cubic metres which was planned several years ago, but we have had our future there undermined.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: At the end of the day those calls will be made primarily made by State Government. Obviously the Commonwealth can’t just go in and override those decisions made by the State and this is why it does have to be a partnership.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Look we are miles ahead of time, we’ve still got a few minutes time so if you are at home listening this and you want to talk about boarder security or you want to talk about the about the Port,you if want can to ring through and talk with our Prime Minister directly, he hasn’t got a long time so it you want to have a chat get on the blower immediately.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: All good.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can I take you to page one - and I know this is a sensitive matter, I know that, but let’s go to page one of the Australian. “Scott Morrison has urged the Indonesian President to show great respect to Australia in dealing with Abu Bakar Bashir the terrorist,” as survivors of the 2002 Bali bombings describe being quote, “disappointed and numb at the pending release of the spiritual leader of the Islamist group that killed 88 Australians.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Peter Hughes is a survivor of the 2002 attack and says he is angry at the early release.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He just hates Westerners. He just hates the way we are and he just loves the fact that they killed so many people and he was involved.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now you have expressed already, can I say, disappointment in the release, the early release of Abu Bakar Bashir. What can you convey to the Indonesian leadership about our feelings on this sensitive matter here in Australia?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: First of all I want to assure all Australians that I have already conveyed directly, at the highest level, our strong views on this topic and the fact that Abu Bakar Bashir was convicted of crimes under the Indonesian justice system. It’s their justice system and they run it and so there are calls they have to make there.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yes.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: And it’s important that this character doesn’t get the opportunity to go and spread and incite hatred if under their system - and it’s their system - he were to be released. I would obviously be very disappointed about that, like other Australians would and would register that disappointment and quite strong feelings about that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now this is a matter of some celebration up here I would imagine, this is from today’s Courier Mail the rate heart disease and premature death in North Queensland will be targeted under a $12 million Federal Government plan to send cardiology clinics to the bush. This is Greg Hunt, he’s revealing an extra mobile cardiac bus.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: This is so important to rural and regional communities. Whether it’s this issue, whether it comes to cardiac conditions or frankly on mental health.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Look I’m glad you agreed to take a couple of calls, but we have to snappy or your staff will start waving at me and winding us up. We had John on the line, he’s not there yet.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’day Linda.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Good morning, good morning. One of the biggest issues that we’re facing in north Queensland and actually most of the northern part of Australia is insurance.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah well there’s a couple of issues there. One of the issues Warren has raised with me about that is obviously the lack of competition.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah the problem is, if we had the economy that was going and that we had jobs and we could create an income for ourselves, the problem itself we could almost manage. But the problem is because the economy has ground to a halt, you know, we hear constantly that we’re going to move a government department here or we’re going to dredge the channel, we’ve got this project that’s going to start, we’re going to have a tourism hub, we’re going to have all of this.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Sure and that’s why I’m pleased that the youth unemployment rate here has fallen from 28 per cent to 15.6 per cent, just since the last election.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Linda we’ve got to move on because we’ve got almost no time, we’ve got Phil on the line. Phil, you’re talking to Prime Minister Scott Morrison.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Hello Scott and thank you for giving the time to me. I prefer to call you Scott and ScoMo just by the way.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Whatever you like.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: “I’m doing everything legally.” But they’re running people back tens of thousands of dollars.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Alright.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s just not fair.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well two points on that, we’ve been taking action on that very point to ensure that these companies do pay their superannuation. We’ve been cracking down on that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We’ve got to move on because we’ve got little time and the queue starts at Mount Isa, we’ve got John on the line. John you’re talking to Scott Morrison.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Good morning John, good morning Scott.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’day John.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Try to be brief.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I’ll make it brief. We’ve been over-promised to buggery by Warren Entsch and there hasn’t been too much achieved, I’m not real happy with him, two things but – they’re probably ways to sort everyone’s worries; the flag, mate.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: First of all, on Warren, over his time here Warren has brought about $4 billion worth of public investments here into Leichhardt, the most recent being the one I’ve just announced yesterday. There’s the $10 million I announced when I was back here last November, there’s the Aquarium, there’s the Cultural Centre, it even goes back to the original boardwalk.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: “We know that people living across north Queensland hugely value their local Medicare and Centrelink services and the decent quality jobs that exist to provide those essential services. That’s why ads are so important,” advertising, “to ensure voters are aware that these services and jobs are under threat from privatization and labour hire”?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, what a load of rubbish. I mean these are unions using union-members fees to promote Bill Shorten.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Your staff are on the verge of mutiny here so I’m going to let you go.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well, we’ve got to get up to Cooktown.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well exactly!

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’m looking forward to that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Have you met Peter Scott up there?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Not yet, looking forward to it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He’s doing a wonderful job and the other thing I’d love you to do up there if you get half an hour, go to the museum. It is such an eye-opener and you will just love what is on offer up there.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I will.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Scott Morrison, Prime Minister of Australia, thank you for your time in studio today.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks John, great to be here with you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: ScoMo, how are you?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good, Shad and Carly, it’s great to be back here and with you guys again today. We’ve had a great couple of days up here in Far North Queensland and thanks to all those who gave us such a warm welcome.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now more importantly, how is the first pup, Buddy, doing?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Buddy is doing great, he has made a number of appearances. When we had the Australian and Indian cricket teams around on New Year's Day, he took to howling every time Kohli spoke and he got himself on the news that night.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can we chuck him on the team, because I think we’re struggling a little bit out in the field.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: He’s a pretty good fielder, he gets after those quick ones towards the boundary I think. Very, very fast.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now, you’re also here for a big announcement around Cooktown and Captain Cook’s voyage around Australia. ScoMo, what is going on?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It’s an important part of our history and up in Cooktown, they’ll tell you all about it. I mean, if you go back to that day when they called him the ‘little old man” who came out of the bushes with the rest of his mates and they reconciled with Cook over a dispute that they’d had, it’s a beautiful story.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can I just be honest here, ScoMo. I was questioning whether this Government’s priorities lie, because as a woman in this country living through a domestic violence epidemic, coming fresh off the back of the latest horrific crime that has happened against a woman, I was waiting to hear kind of the next move on that and then this kind of come out of left field.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We can do more than one thing at a time. We’re investing.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I understand that, but it’s priorities.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: $350 million to combat domestic violence. That’s what we’re doing on domestic violence.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well I hope so, because we want to keep you accountable, we are all voters.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Sure.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And as a woman in this country, as a woman that watches these news reports time and time again, I just hope that this epidemic is really being taken seriously.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We have had three national action plans now on countering domestic violence in Australia. That’s been $350 million, we’re going to announce the fourth one.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, now we’ve covered the big topics, that got a lot more heated. Can we do the fun now? Let’s have some fun, ScoMo.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Inaudible]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well there is one in every MPs office.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So they’ve all got their own?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: They do.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So there’s no joint urinal?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well if you’re walking around the building, yeah there are those as well. And you can often have a quiet conservation.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Is that where some of the secrets are all done?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: There’s often the odd chat.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you ever look?

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Oh everyone has had a look?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, no.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Just a peek, just a little, even an accidental look.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I think you’re sort of self-revealing there, mate.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Has anyone ever looked at you?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I hope not.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What about Bill Shorten, have you ever..

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, we’ve never actually found ourselves in that situation to the best of my recollection. He’s probably as thankful for that as me.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Because if you were yelling at each other across the thing and you know, it’s kind of like, it almost gives you a little bit of a prop up doesn’t it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I think we’ve got to keep you out of Parliament House.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If you see me walking the halls of Canberra, I’m having a look. Go to the cubicle.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Oh look, Bill and I, many years ago, before we were in politics, we travelled to Israel together on a joint delegation.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Really?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Many years ago. And there are some pretty embarrassing photos of, you know.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Got a bit loose, did you?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Ah no, more because we were… our wardrobes back then were a little different to what they are today.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And we both had a bit of a tease of each other about that. But look, politics is a serious business and you respect people professionally.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: So would you go to the barbeque?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I mean, Chloe and Jenny get on quite well, actually, because they’re conscripts to what Bill and I do.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: My last question for you - might have more after that though - is there a red phone in your office that you’re afraid if it rings?

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No there’s not.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: There’s no such thing as that?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: There’s not. There’s one phone, and it’s this one, and it rings all the time.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That’s the one you answer straight away.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Not all the time, I’ve got to say, on occasion I have… that’s been raised with me on occasion.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well ScoMo, it’s been a pleasure having you in the studio this morning.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks guys.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Good luck with running the country.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well look, we’re getting stuff done, the economy is going well, but there is a lot of… you know, this year is going to be a tough year in the economy, so we can’t take this stuff for granted. And that’s my number one priority, because it pays for everything else.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: 100 per cent. Well don’t forget, make sure some of that money keeps coming up here.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well as you can see, Entschy has nailed that for a long time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He kills it, he is a very tall human being as well. He intimidates me every time he steps into studio.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good on you, thanks Shad, thanks Carly.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Scott Morrison, welcome to ABC Far North Queensland.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’day Kier, it's great to be here in the studio and great to be here in Cairns again.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now an election is clearly in the air when the Prime Minister comes to town bearing gifts. You brought some money for the tertiary stage of the Hospital project here in Cairns, heading to Cooktown today.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well as you say, this is not my first visit to Cairns. I’ve been here many times and last time I was here last year it was $10 million for the innovation hub out there at JCU.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And the money that you’re bringing for them, around $5.75 million I understand?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yes, it’s about that for both projects.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And do you know what the money will be spent on?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah, the $5.8 million that we’re spending up in Cooktown, that includes the reconciliation of the Rocks Precinct, the development of the Botanical Gardens, the upgrades to the Gamaay Dreaming Track and the Waymburr Story Project.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: As you fly to Cooktown today you’re going to be flying over the world heritage listed Daintree Rainforest. Now, there was a Federal Parliamentary Committee last year that recommended the Bloomfield Track be sealed.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We’re proceeding cautiously here. Warren and I had a good discussion about this, as well as with some locals.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay you have personally supported the coal industry, people might remember you bringing that piece of coal into Parliament on that occasion a few years ago?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well coal creates lots and lots and lots of jobs.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sure, now in our area though, reef, rainforest, many environmentally sensitive assets as well. Do you think the Government’s approach to environment, to climate change, could potentially cost votes in Leichhardt?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No I don’t, because we’re meeting our commitments, we’ve set our commitments. We met Kyoto 1, we will comfortably smash Kyoto 2 and I believe we will meet 2030 our targets there which we have set.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay, so in the Leichhardt fight, Warren Entsch is going up against a female candidate. Do you have enough women running in winnable seats across the country?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I’d always like more. What I want though is the best people to continue to take on the task that we have set ourselves.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But do you have enough women running in winnable seats?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I’d like to have more.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You say you’d like to have more, so that means you don’t think you have enough.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we have our candidates set as we go in and we’ve got a strong female representation and there are more seats to fill between now and the next election. You know, we've got six women in my Cabinet, that’s the highest number under our Government and they are all very capable women and doing a fantastic job.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Jeff Kennett - the oft outspoken Mr Kennett -

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah Jeff’s always good for some advice.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He suggested that people like Kevin Andrews and Julie Bishop should be stepping aside to let new talent come through, potentially some of those new women into winnable seats, potentially. Does he have a point?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I like the blend of experience. Take Warren.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Speaking of Julie Bishop, she’s talked about potentially re-contesting as well. Have you spoken to her about that and in fact, would there be a position for her on your front bench?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well I offered her one when I became Prime Minister and she decided she didn’t want to proceed with it at that time, so I respect her decision. I respect her choice, she’ll make her choices and I’ll respect those choices.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay let’s just turn our attention to the current sort of crisis happening on the Murray-Darling Basin as well. That idea that Labor is now going to work with those independent scientists, that plan that Bill Shorten put forward.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s just politics, I mean the Murray-Darling Basin Plan is a very serious and sensitive issue. It’s been a bipartisan initiative for many, many years.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So are you worried about what the scientists might discover?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No I’m not at all, I’d like to be informed by the work that we will do. But I’m not going to engage in those sort of theatrics from Bill Shorten.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let’s talk a little bit just about the impending election as well. I mean just a few days of Parliament left, the delivery of a Budget and calling the election.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: You’re right we will have a Budget, we’ll hand down a Budget on the 2nd of April. It will be the first surplus Budget this country has seen in 12 years.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We’ve had a few callers ringing in as well, asking about ABC funding. These are people from more regional locations as well, who aren’t serviced by as many other media outlets.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it doesn’t need to be restored because it hasn’t been cut, it’s funding is not going backwards it’s actually being maintained. But I particularly want to commend the work the regional ABC does.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But there has been a reduction?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No there hasn’t.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: There hasn’t been? In real terms?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: There’s been no reduction in funding. I mean we asked the ABC to actually do the same thing that every single Department and agency has to do in terms of an efficiency dividend, which they weren’t required to do for years and years and years.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So Prime Minister, can I ask about the Australia Day stuff?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Sure.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s coming up this weekend, you’re going to be out there in far north Queensland in the heat and the humidity. You know you’ve made those propositions about maintaining it - being when Councils can actually do the ceremonies – this idea of actually banning shorts, thongs, these sorts of ideas, why legislation like that? Why spending time on stuff like that?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well it’s not legislation, it’s part of code. What I’m saying is, I used to be the Immigration Minister, you know, it’s my signature on many Australians’ citizenships today.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well Prime Minister I know you need to leave so we do appreciate your time this morning.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No worries.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Enjoy your trip to Cooktown as well and we’ll be hearing more from you as you deliver your announcements there today. And I’m sure we’ll see you again right?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Thanks a lot, I look forward to it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can you put us out of our misery - everyone has to ask you at the end right – when will the election be Prime Minister?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: After the Budget.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: After the Budget, okay that’s pretty fair.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s not too bad?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thank you very much.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Okay and well done to the Taipans last night, cheers.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister, good afternoon.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: G’day Ben, happy new year to you and all your listeners.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’re back into it.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah well and truly, I’ve been back into it for quite a while now and we’re up here in Cairns. We’ve made an announcement about some new hospital funding up here which has been well received.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We spoke at the end of last year and I know that you were looking forward to having a little bit of time with your family as much as you could. Did you get a few weeks, how much time did you actually get to down tools and enjoy the family?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: We got a week off, we went down to Shoalhaven heads and I bumped into Mark Leavy actually, he was there.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I saw that, I saw a photo of you and ‘Piggy’ Riddell as well.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah they were down there, it was great. Shoalhaven Heads is a top spot, it’s sort of people from all walks of life and we had a great time down there and they had a big, the fishing club, had a huge fundraising afternoon so the family and I and friends went down and enjoyed that and they raised a bit of money for the local rural fire service and the surf club and so on.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I know we’re speaking to you because you’re the Prime Minister but I need to ask you a question this afternoon as Cronulla’s number one ticket holder. Coach Shane Flanagan has resigned today, he was deregistered for contacting the club while serving a ban related to players using performance enhancing drugs.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well Shane sent me a text actually and let me know he was doing this. I know Shane pretty well and look, Shane always puts the club first.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If I can get you to put your other hat on right now as Prime Minister, the former Prime Minister Tony Abbott told my colleague Ray Hadley today here on 2GB that “people would be better off voting Labor rather than an Independent”, he said, “because for all of Labor’s faults, at least they are a Party of government or potential government. Now, I know that you would prefer people vote for the Liberal Party or the National Party but do you agree with Mr Abbott that a vote for Labor is better than a vote for an Independent?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I don’t think you should vote for either of them. That’s my view, that’s my very strong view.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: There seems to be a lot more detail coming out about what this is going to do, some of Bill Shorten’s changes when it comes to tax. Whether it be relating to retirement or relating to negative gearing, there seems to be a lot more detail that’s coming out in the lead-up to the next election.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we’re just going to make that point really clear Ben and you’re right. I mean, people have always had their question marks over Bill Shorten.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Did I hear you right that you said that people haven’t warmed to him?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Yeah that’s a very polite and kind way of putting it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Have they warmed to you? I mean you’ve been out and about over the summer break, do you get the feeling that Australia is now used to Scott Morrison being their Prime Minister and they like it?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well that’ll be ultimately tested at the election and that’s for them to make those commentaries, not be. But I’ve been very appreciative of the kind reception I’ve had wherever I have gone.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well that’s nice to know.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Look, Jeff can make those comments. But I actually quite like the fact that we’ve got a blend of experience and new people in the team.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I got a few messages today when I promoted the fact that you were going to be calling in, from political journos who said, “Oh look, Scott Morrison kind of dodged a question today about Julie Bishop and when people asked whether or not she was going to run at the next election you said I refer you to her statement.” I have had a look at her statement, she said I am preselected as the Member for Curtin and it is my intention to run so, I’m guessing you don’t have a guarantee from Julie Bishop that she is going to run?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: That’s just what she told you herself. That’s what she said, that’s what her public statement is and that’s a matter for Julie.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The images that we saw over the summer break, and I know you’ve commented on this but I haven’t had the chance to talk to you about this. All of those fish in the Darling River, the Australian Academy of Science is now preparing a report for your opposite number Bill Shorten.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Look, we’re listening to the experts and I understand that they’ve made it very clear that it’s not a million, that’s not a factual report, it’s in the thousands. And that’s still a great tragedy and something that I know Australians find deeply upsetting.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I have spoken to, in the first hour of our program today, a mate of ours Jamie Warden who is a farmer in Walgett. He was saying the rivers are drying up around Walgett as well, there’s algae growing around rivers there.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well we’ve announced half a billion dollar water infrastructure fund. We’ve invested in farm water management with the major tax incentives and major financial support for water infrastructure on farms.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sadly, it doesn’t always flow through. The money doesn’t always flow through and I don’t expect you to be able to do anything about this and it’s a very specific case but Jamie has just taken us through Walgett, for example, where you’ve got money that’s been given to the council for a weir or an artesian board to help out with water supply and the council still hasn’t spent the money.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well whether it’s water cartage or things like that but I do know those $1 million is getting to those councils and the Commonwealth Government has been working closely with those councils so they can get it ready. And of course there is the $5 billion water future fund that I announced at the Budget, sorry at the Summit, and that is now… we’re taking that through to establish that fund through the legislation and that means there will be funding there for capacity on water management into the future for generations.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: There has been a terrible spate of suicides in Indigenous communities. We have had five teenage girls taking their lives in two weeks.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Ben, you are absolutely right. And mate, I saw those same reports as I’m sure you did over the break and I’m not pleased you’ve raised it for the obvious reasons but I am glad you’ve raised it, if you know what I mean.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: There seems to be an annual debate about Australia Day and whenever that debate comes up I think about issues like those young girls and think well this is what we really should be talking about.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Look that’s true. That is true and we have to confront our inadequacies as a country but we don’t have to be overwhelmed by them, equally.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Australia Day is Saturday, you’ve changed the rules so that local councils will be forced to hold citizenship ceremonies on Australia Day and you’re also bringing in a dress code for citizenship ceremonies. You’re banning thongs and board shorts.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well not specifically those things, but what we’re saying is there needs to be appropriate standards of dress. I mean, I wouldn’t turn up to my kid’s graduation wearing thongs.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But most people dress up for an event like this right, and if someone really wants to embrace Aussie culture by wearing traditional Aussie clobber, why stop them?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: It’s not a traditional clobber, it should be a respectful ceremony. You should dress appropriately for occasions.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You were photographed over the break wearing rainbow coloured board shorts. Have you thrown them out?

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: No, because I was at a community fundraiser at the pub. That’s where you wear them mate.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: They were shocking, they were bad mate, they were bad.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Well they stood out in the crowd. I’ve had them for a very long time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Just ask your daughters, ask your daughters whether or not they should be consigned to the Vinnies Bin will you?

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [Laughter]

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: I will, I’m sure they’ll have an opinion.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We’ll talk to you regularly throughout 2019, thanks for joining us from Cairns.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Good on you Ben. And good luck to Ash Barty tomorrow, I was down there yesterday with Jen and the girls and we got to meet her.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well said, thank you so much for joining us, we’ll talk again soon.

items.speaker: PRIME MINISTER
items.value: Cheers mate.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Opposition Leader joins us now from Mackay in Queensland. Bill Shorten, thanks for joining us.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We've got a lot to get through this morning so we will get cracking Mr Shorten. But just on that story we've heard out of China, how concerned are you about the detention of this Chinese Australian writer?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: You can't sugar-coat this. This is an Australian citizen who has been detained in China, the Embassy has just been notified.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What does it say about diplomatic relations that it's taken five days for Australia to be involved, or to have any access in regards to this, when the arrangement is that it's supposed to take place after three days to have communications?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yes it is disappointing Lisa. It's not the way the arrangements are meant to work.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mr Shorten in Queensland I imagine you're getting a real sense of the concern people have about the economy and the loss of jobs. You're in the heart of the mining area.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: There's a couple of big hypotheticals there aren't there, Lisa. But I'll go to the Adani matter, and then I'll go to jobs in Queensland.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mr Shorten, just in the last few moments, we have been hearing from your Deputy, Tanya Plibersek, who said about the Gilmore preselection that Warren Mundine has been very clear for the last 20 or 30 years that he wants a seat in Parliament, and he will take any party that will have him. For a long time - and I am quoting her, ‘he was desperate for the Labor Party to give him a seat in Parliament, there's a reason we didn't and the voters of Gilmore will discover that’.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I haven't seen those remarks. But I think what you said in the preamble is correct.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But he was the head of the Labor Party.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well we've had plenty of administrative heads of the Labor Party who haven't ended up in Parliament. The point about it, in answering your question is that he wasn't able to convince the Labor Party to back him, and it's a free country, if he wants to run for any party, I guess being in a party, that's up to him who he chooses, if he wants to change his views.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It seems to be fairly specific though Mr Shorten, that Tanya Plibersek says, there is a reason the Labor Party didn't, and leaving it up to the voters of Gilmore to discover what that reason might be?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I think you just said earlier on that it was just, in very recent moments, that Tanya made that comment so, I haven't seen them. But it's a matter of record that Mr Mundine was unsuccessful in convincing the Labor Party, over many years.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well one of the sentiments we are hearing in letters to the editor and people concerned is about the franking credits and some of the decisions you've made on taxes. Reducing what pensioners might be able to access, these small amounts.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Listen, I don't want to get into a debate about the facts, but your last statement is 100 per cent wrong. We've made it clear that any pensioner who's in receipt of a part pension is not affected by our changes, so you can't say - I mean, you can, but it's just not right, when you say that pensioners are going to be affected, that's just not correct.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But given the economy -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: So, we're committed to our reforms to make our budget sustainable.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Given the economy has already started changing since you made these announcements, and certainly on negative gearing, how committed are you to these policies, and are you ready for an election that is basically going to be a tax referendum?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: we are grandfathering our proposals. Most people don't know quite what grandfathering means.

items.speaker: ATMOS
items.value: [FEED DROPS OUT]

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Sorry about that Lisa.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can I ask you Mr Shorten, there's been a lot of talk about values and as we approach Australia Day, the Prime Minister certainly has been putting forward views. What are three values that you adhere to as a politician?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Fairness. We think that Australia Day is about Australian values.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mr Shorten, we're going to have to leave it there. Thanks for your patience with us with the link.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Every primary school student will have access to swimming lessons under a major policy announcement being made today by Labor. It follows a summer drowning toll which has shocked lifesavers around Australia, 65 deaths since the start of December.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And Opposition Leader, Bill Shorten joins us now from Queensland's Sunshine Coast. Good morning to you, Mr Shorten.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: $46 million - let's hope it saves some lives, 65 deaths since the start of December, way too many. You're on a bus tour at moment, Mr Shorten, of south-east Queensland.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yes ours is a nine day tour, although because it overlapped with the weekend, I've had a day on the Sunshine Coast. I'm here at Moffat Beach - it's in the People's Republic of Caloundra.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It certainly is a lovely spot.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: So I've had a day off the bus and I'll go back on the bus on Monday.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Prime Minister is also in Queensland at the moment. It seems like Queenslanders will be the big beneficiaries of election campaign cash-splash, and also be used for a lot of photo opportunities over the coming months it seems, Mr Shorten.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well this is my sixth January as Opposition Leader and what I'm hearing all over Australia, not just Queensland, is people are sick of the instability. So when you say what am I targeting, I don't look at Queensland as LNP or Labor, I just look at them as Queenslanders.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Clive Palmer has been copping some criticism for sending out mass text messages. Will the ALP be doing that in the lead up to the next election?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, I think that part of the reason why Clive Palmer is copping some criticism is that he used to run a nickel plant or business interest associated with it in Townsville. And that nickel plant went into insolvency and workers were left with unpaid wages and entitlements - the taxpayers had to step into the shoes of Palmer and pay the workers their entitlements.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So that's a promise not to spam our phones during the election is it, Mr Shorten? No messages from Bill?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We will only ever give you facts - important facts.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I think that might be the likelihood of receiving one.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: we won't be spending as a company director, money chasing votes when they need to go to repay the taxpayers and the workers what they are owed to begin with. It's about priorities.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I say this with respect this morning, Mr Shorten, back on the bus. Thanks for making the announcement with us this morning about the school swimming program.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Have a lovely morning guys. The swimming program is really important, it's good policy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It certainly is. 1,600ks to cover so he has got a long way to go.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mr Shorten, thanks for joining us.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Today the Prime Minister accused you of being a clear and present threat to Australia's safety. He was talking in the context of asylum seeker policy.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yes. I mean, the Prime Minister, you said something that he said which deserves answering and this is the first occasion I've had to answer it since his remarkable press conference.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: As I said, I'd like viewers to try and understand the basic facts as well as the politics. So let me ask, do you support the Government's policy that people who end up on Nauru or Manus Island will never be allowed to resettle in Australia?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We believe that anyone who comes here via people smuggler should be resettled in a third party nation, yes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Does Labor support boat turn backs and will that policy continue if you're in office?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yes, we will, we will support boat turn backs where it's safe to do so, which is existing policy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Prime Minister Morrison's point is that Kerryn Phelps' Private Members Bill, if it's passed, will allow people smugglers to say to potential clients, "listen, Australia has changed the legislation, you won't have to stay on Nauru or Manus you just get some doctor to sign off in Australia and it's all good mate." This is where he has the point of difference with you.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: There's a point of difference but not the one he's claiming to make. I think after five years this Government should be ashamed of the fact that there are still people on Manus and Nauru and they haven't been resettled.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you reject Mr Morrison's suggestion that if this Phelps Bill were to pass that it would give people smugglers an opening to restart the trade?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: The thing giving people smuggler's the best encouragement in 2018 is the constant billboard which the Government do when they say, oh if Labor gets elected, which is possible at the next election, they are egging the people smuggler's on to try their hand again. It is the Government who constantly say "oh well, if it's not us then the people smugglers will be back in business.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We know that this Bill has now been delayed until Parliament resumes next year, that's a few months away, a couple of months away, what happens to children who need medical evacuation during that period of time?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, I just hope that the treating medical advice gets taken seriously. You know, there have been some children coming here anyway.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let me ask you about another issue that came up today.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Sure.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Government's accusing Labor of being weak on national security again, because of some of your concerns about the encryption bill. This morning you did vote in of it despite saying you wanted more time to consider it, despite concerns about the way it was drafted and despite the Bill containing amendments that you hadn't seen.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, first of all, the Government a few weeks ago said that they wanted to look at how we can break through the encrypted telecommunications of people who are criminals, terrorists and the like. We said that's fair enough.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let's go to some of the other issues that were on the radar this week. The Government says it will return to a surplus from the 2019 Federal Budget.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I'm confident, based on the economic reforms that we've engaged in in Opposition, that we will a very positive position on surplus over the four years, and a much better position than the Liberals over the 10 years, because we're winding back unsustainable tax subsidies at the top end, which in fact the Government want to keep.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Does a very positive position on surplus mean you anticipate staying in surplus?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: That's our aim and the point about it, but just to come to that, we do need to see what numbers the Government have got. I know people get sick of politics but this Government is going to bring down a Budget on April 2 and then rush off to an election.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: On climate change policy, will Labor put a price on carbon?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We're not going back to the policies of the past. We're not going to have a carbon tax.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, but will you price carbon?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No. What we're going to do is prioritise, and I'll give you the key features of what we're doing.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: At the last election when Labor proposed to wind back negative gearing, the housing market was experiencing much stronger growth than it is now. Now in some places it is actually going backwards, houses are losing value.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We're going to stick to our existing policies. It's just not fair for our younger generation to not be able to afford their first home when the Government of the day is giving a tax subsidy to property investors to buy their fifth or sixth.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sorry to interrupt, but, and what's going on in the property market at the moment doesn't give you pause on that?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: What's going on in the property market at the moment is the banks are restricting credit. It's unrelated to our policy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How many times have you spoken to Malcolm Turnbull since he ceased being Prime Minister?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I've spoken to him a few times. But I notice the conspiracy of the far right against Malcolm Turnbull.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But what do you talk to him about?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: First of all, the first conversation I had for him was to thank him for his service to the nation. I've spoken to former Prime Ministers Rudd and Gillard, I've spoken to John Howard on occasion, I've spoken to Tony Abbott.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Finally, 2019, there's an election year as we've alluded to several times, for all of the campaigns in memory, the leaders of the major parties have committed to two prime time interviews during the campaign on 7.30.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yes, let's do that, Leigh. That would be great.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Look forward to seeing you next year. Bill Shorten, thank you.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Thank you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Labor landslide on Saturday will have federal implications. A number of Victorian seats held by Morrison Government MPs are now at risk despite Scott Ryan's confidence.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, the Liberals have been belted in Victoria and today's Newspoll has Federal Labor 10 points ahead of the Coalition. This next federal election impossible to lose from here?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I certainly don't think the outcome of the next election is at all decided. That will be decided by 15 or 16 million voters whenever the Government finally call an election.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: There are a number of Liberal held federal seats that could now be in play. Is that your view of it? Corangamite, Chisholm, Deakin, Dunkley - those kind of seats - maybe even Flinders and Casey.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well there's no doubt that there's lessons federally and you've mentioned a whole range of seats where there was a significant swing to Labor. There was a strong swing to Labor even in my own seat.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well those very promises that you just ran off there, that Daniel Andrews was promising, you know spending on schools and hospitals - we heard the Federal Treasurer on AM suggest that obviously the Federal Coalition is going to have to counter that kind of campaign, that kind of spending. They've now got plenty of money in the coffers we're reading.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Do we spend too much or we won't spend enough? The reality is for me, it's not - I don't view education and health -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Big spending, higher taxing, aren't you? That's according to the Government.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yeah, I don't know where the Government thinks they get the money they spend from. They don't just magic it up through their sheer genius.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Ok.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: That's where the political debate should be - the best ideas

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I want to come back to the Budget and how that might play out in a moment but in terms of ideas - there are already calls coming from within the Liberal Party for them to be less ideological on social issues and challenges such as climate change. We heard Scott Ryan say that they need to get their tone - change their tone so the Liberal electoral base doesn't feel excluded.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, I've known Scott Ryan for some period of time. He is a very sort of sensible considered Liberal.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You're listening to RN Breakfast. Our guest is Opposition Leader Bill Shorten.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well I think this is a Government to be honest, who have stopped governing. They view everything through the prism of beating Labor and winning the election.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: it says you want to impose a retiree tax. It's pretty tough line to counter, isn't it?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: It's not even true so it's not that tough to counter. If we stop -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, they've got a whole lot of analysis that says 300,000 voters in Labor electorates will be hit.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I choose to invest in schools and hospitals, reducing the aged care waiting list, making sure people can get apprenticeships, making sure that we can reduce the out-of-pocket costs in Medicare. It's all about choices and you know, we're up for the legitimate debate.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You're listening to RN Breakfast. Our guest is Opposition Leader Bill Shorten.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We want to try and get things done in the Parliament - that's why we're going to keep pushing for a national anti-corruption commission. Labor supports having a national anti-corruption commission.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So what's Labor going to do about that? Are you going to try pursue that in Parliament?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Do you know what? I think Mr Dutton should refer himself.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And if you doesn't, will you?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, you know and I know, Fran, that if we don't have the numbers, it can't be done. But what that means in the meantime is that we're jeopardising the authority's cases against 16,000 people - many of whom are alleged to be criminals from us being able to take action.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So, will you try and push this?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I think, Fran, is this the way we want immigration laws and strong borders being made by people whose constitutional eligibility has a cloud over it?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Ok, just finally -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: How does that help keep us safe and strong?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten, we've only got a minute to the news. Just finally, the latest Newspoll has Labor improving its lead, stretching its lead over the Government but not so on your standing.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well first of all, you know that when the polls are good or bad, over five years, one month and 13 days, I haven't commented. I'm not going to start doing that now.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But in all that time you haven't been preferred leader hardly at all, have you?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well no, Fran, what I'm not going to do is engage in that debate. But what I'll say to you, Fran, is if the Liberal Party thinks that on Monday, as we approach the last two weeks of Parliament, they're doing really well - well then, I've got a bridge over the mouth of Yarra I want to sell 'em.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten, thank you very much for joining us.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Our top story this morning the fall out of the Victorian election, joining us now is the most senior figure in the Labor Party from Victoria, Bill Shorten the Opposition Leader. Mr Shorten thanks so much for your time, what do you say to members of the Government who are questioning whether there are federal issues at play in the result at the weekend?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Dan Andrews was claiming the mantle of the most progressive Government in Australia, is that something you would like to be able to claim if you win?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We're certainly more progressive than the current government in Canberra. Listen, I'll let our actions speak for ourselves rather than me put tags on how we will be as a government, my aim is to get elected first but what I can promise Australians is for example, if you've got a three or four year old we'll make sure they get access to kindergarten for free.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The lead now you've got in the Newspoll is ten points, the result in the Wentworth by-election was diabolical for the Government, this result in Victoria it's yours to lose now isn't it, this election, a hundred per cent.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well Mr Morrison will have to call an election in the next five months, they have to. What we're going to do is take nothing for granted, the people haven't voted yet.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Daniel Andrews had a big spending agenda, do you recognise that there is a difference between state and federal sphere in that, do you have to have more fiscal responsibility in that sense and where is that in your list of priorities?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Fiscal responsibility is important, I don't accept the Liberal argument that somehow Dan Andrews isn't fiscally responsible, they've made some very strong decisions. But we've been making hard economic reforms, my economic team of Chris Bowen and Jim Chalmers and the others, we've been making serious economic reform proposals to explain how we pay for our changes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It looks like the Treasurer, Mr Frydenberg will go to a Budget in April, election in May, many of them see this as their last roll of the dice - to deliver a surplus and say look we're the economic guardians. How do you respond to that?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, if they have a surplus we think this is a good thing but it's because there's increased taxation on companies. The Government can take some pleasure from the surplus but the reason why we will have a surplus is because Australian corporations are paying more company tax.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What's the problem with that?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Nothing at all, all I'm saying is that when we talk about fiscal management what happens in Australia is that it's not the politicians who drive for good fiscal outcomes in Australia it is the companies, it's the people who go to work.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Daniel Andrews' mantra was 'getting things done' and he's able to do that now because Labor controls both Houses in Victoria, you might not be so lucky. How do you propose to deal with the Senate if you are Prime Minister? Will you be pragmatic, will you negotiate with the right and the left, how will that work under your Prime Ministership?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: It will work cooperatively and constructively. I always had the view, back from my days representing workers in negotiations with employers, that no one has got a monopoly on having all the good ideas.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But why didn't you do that when Malcolm Turnbull was Prime Minister?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well he couldn't even bring it to the Parliament.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But why didn't you agree to it? The National Energy Guarantee framework was all there.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yeah you're right, we did want to see it but the problem is Mr Turnbull couldn't even bring it to the Parliament and we encouraged him to, we thought this was a good thing to do but this is the big problem in Australia and I didn't want to talk too much about my opponents. But the Liberal Party in Australia has lost the ability to say anything other than no.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And do you feel emboldened by the result in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne? I guess everywhere in Victoria in relation to your position on climate change and your Emission Reduction Targets and so on, is that reflective of a broader view nationwide?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I think the nation is sick and tired after ten years of arguing about climate change that we just don't get on with it. Energy prices have just gone up and up and up, in Sydney, 26 per cent on average nationally, 19 per cent.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And just one related question on that, Adani, have you got a definitive position on that yet in terms of when you will back it or you won't?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We've said that we don't want to see any Commonwealth tax-payer money directly or indirectly go into it, we've seen the missed deadlines, we're sceptics. We've said no taxpayer money should be used in this proposition.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That's essentially fence sitting though, isn't it?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Not at all, it depends if you want federal tax money or not.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay, Bill Shorten well it's good to see you in the mothership in Canberra-

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Wow.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Will we see you again –

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You like it?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: - during the election campaign back on First Edition?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yeah, sure.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You've enjoyed yourself then?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I always enjoy talking to you guys.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thanks.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Cheers.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Opposition Leader, Bill Shorten, joins me now from Melbourne. Thank you very much for being with us.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten, you're unapologetically running for government on a big new agenda. So let's run through some of the detail of it beginning with climate change.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, I was in Whyalla today, talking to the people who run OneSteel and they made it clear that they're investing in more renewable energy. So there is a cost to investing in new technology but they're absolutely convinced that the only way we will keep making steel in Australia is by investing in renewable energy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So if there is a short-term economic cost, you have a 45 per cent target for the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, what will be the estimated cost of that to the economy over the next decade, not in dollar terms, but as a percentage of economic growth?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: It won't have a negative effect on economic growth. In fact, most of the mainstream modelling shows that our economy will continue to grow.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But if you have firms that have to be shifting and making the transition to having lower carbon emissions, that may mean that they have less money to spend on other forms of investment, it may mean they have lower profits so therefore they have less money to deliver in the form of company tax into government coffers. Those things could have a spin-off impact on to the GDP numbers?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: The problem with what you're saying is that you assume that there's no cost to doing nothing, and there is. That's why Australians wants real change at this election.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I don't assume that there's no cost to doing nothing. I accept your position there's a long-term benefit.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, my absolute conviction and belief, is that if we don't change, then the cost will be far greater than any initial investments.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But what is the initial -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: If you're asking me to specify what a particular company in a particular factory will have to do, I can't do that, nor could you, nor can the Government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Isn't it a reasonable -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Let's be fair here, Leigh. Let’s be fair.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: There's 250 companies caught by our safeguards mechanism, the same safeguard mechanism the current government applies to 120, each company will respond differently. You and I know that the reason why the government's trying to focus on how much it might cost to put in a new renewable energy system is that they're trying to distract from the fact they have no climate change policy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But if we could stick with Labor -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: It's so dishonest this debate. It is so dishonest -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You can't just pluck a number out of nowhere. You've come up with the 45 per cent target.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Sorry, I didn't pluck that out of nowhere. That was the Paris Agreement.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But if you are choosing that yes we will go with that number, with 45 per cent, you must have done..

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I'm not choosing it, the scientists say it. It's what we've got to do to stop the planet getting warmer.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But as a government you are adopting it as your policy. You must have done some projections short-term to what that will mean to GDP.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Let's go to Citibank, they're an internationally reputable bank. They say that the consequences in terms of cost, of policies on climate change like ours are immaterial.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let's turn to the Adani coal mine in Queensland. If there's a miner sitting in Rockhampton tonight watching and she wants to know, "Mr Shorten, do you reckon this mine will be a good thing for my industry and for Queensland?" What would you say to her?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I'd say that my view on this mine is going to be based on the best science, whether or not it stacks up, and if it is, if it stacks up and passes all the scientific tests, I won't engage in sovereign risk. So in other words we won't arbitrarily upend things.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If we can stick to Adani for now?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Okay sure.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We'll go to a range of other things shortly.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: By all means.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: 30 in April last year you said, "I'm a sceptic of the project, I'm not a fan of the project. I'm happy to tell people my personal opinion.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I think you'd be fair enough to acknowledge that then, Adani didn't get the finance but now they appear to have got the finance. The other thing of course back then is they were talking about a 60 million tonne mine with 10,000 jobs.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You're less sceptical of it now?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: In terms of the commercial high jump bar, yeah they've passed that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How about the environmental one?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well that's going to be a matter for the state and federal regulators isn't it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Various Labor candidates and MPs have had differing positions on Adani, it seems a little confusing what the party's actual position is. What do you say to the suggestion that you've created that situation by saying one thing to people in regional Queensland and one thing to environmentalists?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I'd say that's wrong. Our position's very clear.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: If we want to talk about conflicting positions, let's be even handed here, Leigh. You have got all these Scott Morrison Liberals down in Melbourne and Sydney, they call themselves "modern Liberals", and you've got the LNP in Queensland with a different view.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And I'll have the chance to ask the Prime Minister about some of that when he comes on the program. Let's move on to some other areas, you would have heard in our earlier story 83-year-old Chris Phillips, the retired carpenter who has $36,000 a year in income and he will lose $9,000 per year under your franking credits policy.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well he already is and this is the real heart of the issue. When you get an income tax credit, when you haven't paid income tax, it's a gift from the Government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Will your negative gearing policy make houses cheaper?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: It won't have an appreciable impact on the price of housing.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So what's the point of having it then? Because I seem to recall when it was introduced, it was partly to make housing more affordable?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well what we want to do is create a level playing field, first of all. Why should a pair of first-home buyers, you know supported by their parents, they could be in their late 20s, early 30s.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You say it won't drive housing prices down by very much. Can Australia afford to adopt a policy that drives housing prices down at the moment at all given that the Reserve Bank said in its last minutes that rapidly falling housing prices are currently a downside risk in the economy?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, that's all happened under the current government and that's at the heart of this election. This government loves to talk about a strong economy but strong for who? Corporate profits are up 39 per cent but wages are only up 5 per cent.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I'll come to some of those points in a second. I just want to ask about another of your controversial policies which is superannuation.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Sorry just to correct, when you say controversial, some in the property industry don't like negative gearing changes but a lot of people actually do like it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Superannuation I'm talking about. Paul Keating and others set up superannuation so it would entice people to save for their retirement so they would be less of a burden on Government across all demographics.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, I don't accept your assumption it's less enticing. It's preferentially taxed on the way in.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You spoke about the tax on income versus the tax on capital. Paul Keating made a point in a letter to the editor of the Financial Review last August that having 49 percent as the top marginal tax rate is way too high, especially when company tax is 30 percent.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Leigh, you know there's no plans for 60 per cent or indeed 50 per cent, but I agree that what we need to do is eventually lighten the burden of income tax across all the levels. But to be fair, we already are offering 3.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let’s talk about what you might control if you are the Prime Minister by the end of the month, you've said that you'll deliver a 20 percent wage increase to childcare workers, that it's the only sector for which you'll do that because it's unique. What's unique about childcare workers but not aged care workers or disability carers?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: First of all, when it comes to community sector, there was some wage improvement made for them when Labor was last in power. When it comes to aged care, let's see what the Royal Commission does.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Everybody would agree with that but doesn't it set a precedent -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: That's right.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Doesn't it set a precedent for the Federal Government to pay wages for other private sector workers in the form of direct subsidies?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No. Let's go to that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: When we take all of the policies that we've talked about tonight, is it fair for a viewer to conclude that a Shorten Labor Government will be at its core about the redistribution of wealth, that you want to take more from the wealthy and give more to people on lower incomes?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No, that wouldn't be right. What we want to do is have real change, because, frankly, more of the same under this government isn't good enough for Australians -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But as I said, when we go through your policies, a lot of where you're getting your revenue from is taxes on wealthy people, closing loopholes that mostly wealthy people can exploit and you're wanting to spend money on lower income people. How is that not a form of changing the economy towards a model of redistribution?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Perhaps if you bear with me for a moment, I'll answer your question.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But if you - if you reject the assertion -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No, no, hang on, Leigh. You keep characterising my policies -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, no, no, but what I want you to do is try to do it -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, I want to try and answer -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Because if I'm wrong, if I am wrong and it's the core of your government is not about taxing wealthy people to redistribute income to lower incomes, in a sentence, what is going to be the core of the Shorten Labor Government?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: A fair go for all. We're going to invest in people and invest in infrastructure.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That's a matter for me to Scott Morrison about. With all -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Ok, but I'm happy to contribute, though.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If you need to have a glass of water while I ask the question, please feel free.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: That's alright.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If - you listed out that list of things that you would like to deliver, the issue for you in an election campaign are that voters have to trust that you will actually deliver on that. Why should they trust Labor to deliver on that? You'd point, for example, just to your last thing there, to chaos.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, fair's fair. In the six years that the current government have been in, Labor has been united.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If you're elected, you're unlikely to have a majority in the Senate. If you can't get through your revenue-raising reforms - super, franking credits, negative gearing and so forth - which of your promised spending will you be dropping?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Leigh, let's see how we go in the election first. We haven't won and we haven't lost.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mr Shorten, we've covered a lot of ground tonight. I'm sure our viewers appreciate your time very much.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Thanks for the conversation, Leigh. It was great.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well welcome Bill Shorten.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now, you’re pledging to spend a lot of money through this campaign. This morning, $4 billion.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: About a million Australian families will benefit from our initiative on child care. Everywhere I’ve travelled in Australia as Opposition Leader, one of the single biggest problems that people tell me is that everything is going up except their wages and child care is in one of the biggest things which is going up in price.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Why won't child care providers just whack up their fees?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well good point. We are keeping an eye on this.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: More money going to wages for childcare workers. Isn't that a reason for whacking up their fees?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well come along to Box Hill today where we’re going to talk more about how we are going to look after early childhood educators. Early childhood educators, it is a 96 per cent female dominated industry.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If you put in price controls how can their wages go up?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well what we can do is we can make sure that if we are going to provide some support for the wages of early childhood educators, again we will say to the operators if Labor is providing some modest improvement in the wages of childhood educators, if Labor is providing a couple of thousand dollars a year for parents, what we say to the childcare operators is you don't get to pocket that. We want childcare to be sustainable, we want cost of living to be tackled and we want to see that the people working in the industry get a fair deal.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Isn’t the problem though that you’re trying to give something to everyone, and everyone can’t benefit. In the end someone has to pay for this and in this case it will be those childcare providers who will get less money?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No, not at all. What’s happening now is that this government is raising record taxes and they spend it on property investors on their sixth house with negative gearing.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let's go to that. How much are you raising in taxes over the next decade.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well we’ll release our figures before the election is concluded, but we’ve also made clear that we think we need to wind back what we give to negative gearing.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
