items.value: You should know some of this now though, what you are raising in negative gearing and capital gains tax, what you’re doing in franking credits, so could you give us a figure over if not the next 10 years, over the next four years as to what you expect to raise.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We will do that closer to the election but suffice to say we have done our maths and we are able to pay for the promises we are making. Once we have revealed all of our promises, then we will reveal the costings to back it up.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I understand that, but some of this stuff would be well known to you by now because these are policies you have been working on for six years so can you give us a figure on what you intend to raise by way of cutting tax concessions and raising taxes over the next 10 years?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We will once we have announced all of our policies. That will be very soon.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: OK, if you won't or can't give us a figure on what you are raising in taxes, well can you tell people today whose taxes are going to rise in order to pay for these programs?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: That's a really good point. First of all, the government loves to say that if we are not going to give a tax subsidy to a property investor, somehow that’s a property tax.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you’re saying it’s a big transfer of wealth from people’s pockets into government’s pocket. Why would you spend it any better than they will?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well it’s a matter of priorities. This is the truth in Australia at the moment.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Isn’t it a matter of priorities that you also then let people know as soon as possible where this money is coming from, because you are actually arguing for very big change in Australia and people have the right to have enough time to know where that money is coming from and where it is going to.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, the fact of the matter is we are arguing for a change in Australia. We don't want to - I mean, I think this Government is disgraceful in that they are offering a thread-bare policy agenda.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It's a big change and it's a big risk. Why should people trust you with that change?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Because for the last three years, and indeed six years, we have been united. We are putting all our policies out there.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Let's assume people weren't focused though, for example when you get asked through the course ..

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: You can't have it all ways, you can't say when will you tell people ..

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But when you were asked during the course of the campaign are you lifting taxes on super you should say yes, shouldn't you?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well I've explained that I didn't understand the question that was being asked.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But you were asked about whether or not workers on over $180,000 are going to pay more tax, that's true too isn't it?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Let's go through each of those points rather than rapid fire, let's have a conversation. First of all, we have outlined our policies for the last three years.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Sorry I will stop you there because you are not. If you are earning more than $180,000 a year, you are going to lift people's taxes, aren't you?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yes, for the vast bulk of people we are offering the same thing. You are quite right, for the three per cent of tax earners we still think we need a budget repair levy until 22-23.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A couple of other questions, were you aware of anyone at all who is acting on Labor's behalf who was talking about preference deals with Clive Palmer? Were you aware of anyone in the Labor Party or in the union movement that was talking on your behalf?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: There couldn't have been anyone who was committing me to a preference deal. No, not aware of that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Not committing you to but starting conversations about the possibility of a preference deal.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Hang on a second. As you would know as a seasoned journalist, there is always plenty of conversations.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Did anyone..

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Only one leader in this country has done a deal with Clive Palmer.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Absolutely. That's understood.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No. No.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: These are really good questions. Why don't you ask the Prime Minister himself on Nine News.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well first of all you know that we’ve offered Channel Nine the opportunity to do it through the Press Club. You have declined.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, that's not -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: You've declined. I am sorry if you are busy at lunchtime.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Why not prime time, that's when we have most eyes and ears.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: They have invented iView You know it is possible to do an interview at one point in the day -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: At night time -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: You know, it is possible to do an interview at one point in the day and replay it. I often see that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You've got a big program, why wouldn't you want to debate everyone and everywhere.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yeah, but do you know what? For the last six years we have been debating the Liberals. We are talking to the people.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten, we'll have to leave it there. Thanks for this debate.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I enjoyed the debate.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Right thanks mate.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: See you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Labor Leader Bill Shorten is this morning making his biggest funding announcement of the election campaign. It's $4 billion in additional funding for child care with 1 million families to get thousands in subsidies.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And Bill Shorten joins us live from Melbourne, good morning to you Mr Shorten. Let's get straight to the detail of this…

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Good morning Edwina.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Who qualifies for the money? How much will they get and is it paid to parents or to child care centres?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: The subsidy will be for parents. If your household income is up to $68,000 we will provide a 100 per cent subsidy up to the capped amount of $11.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That is a huge help. Mr Shorten on that last point is it paid to parents or to child care centres? How does it work?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well we want the subsidy to go to the parents and what we're going to say to child care operators though is that we don't want them ramping up the prices. I think this is important point to make.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Alright Mr Shorten it sounds terrific, $1200 a year saved by almost a million working families. On the surface as I said sounds terrific -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Up to $2000, yeah.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But where will the money come from? How are you going to pay for it?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We can afford to do this because we are making the tough economic decisions. We want multinationals to pay more tax.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Lots of families will be looking at that policy very closely this morning. I want you to have a look at this one, the Coalition is this morning announcing that it will cap Australia's refugee intake  at around 19,000 - that's half of Labor's planned increase.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well under Scott Morrison, immigration has gone up, not down. I mean, this is politics.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Alright Mr Shorten you both get the chance to be fair dinkum tomorrow across in Perth, the first leaders’ debate being broadcast on the Seven Network tomorrow and we’ll see you there.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Look forward to it, cheerio.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mr Shorten, yesterday, repeatedly, you refused to rule out reviewing the environmental approvals - the federal environmental approvals for Adani. Can you be fair dinkum with us and with voters and tell us do you rule out reviewing those approvals?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I have no plans to review the approvals. But if we want to be fair dinkum, let's be fair dinkum and let's tell the voters the truth here, all of us.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So well on that, Mr. Shorten, in the past you have said you don't support Adani, you said you're sceptical of it, and the CFMEU has issued this pledge which several of your candidates, including Mr.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: It doesn't matter if it's a union who comes to me or a business, an environmental activist. What I'll do if Prime Minister, is I'll work with all of those interests, but I'm not going to be the servant of any of those interests.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If you become the Prime Minister, will the CFMEU be allowed to enforce closed shops on construction sites, no ticket no work?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No. And let's just be clear on that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Could the resurrection of Clive Palmer cost you the election?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Listen I'm not going to get - sorry, there's only one person who has ever been resurrected and I'm not going to compare Clive Palmer to him. The point about it is, I'm not going to get distracted by Clive Palmer.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: On George Christensen, what do you think he was doing in the Philippines for 294 days?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I think that is one of the questions of the ages. The member for Manila, but Jason's been our representative in northern Australia so I might get him to talk further.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well I'll tell you what he wasn't doing, he wasn't doing his job. This bloke has to be the laziest politician in Australia.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: LNP candidate Gerard Rennick has been caught spreading conspiracy theories about climate change and some curious ideas about your preschool policy. What action, if any, should be taken against the candidate, and can you guarantee you would also apply that same standard to any of your candidates caught in a similar situation?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: To the best of my knowledge, no Labor candidate believes three year old child care is a political conspiracy. To the best of my knowledge, no Labor candidate is a supporting a 12 per cent corporate tax rate, which is a massive tax cut for the big end of town.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can I ask Mr Beers a question about the Adani project. Mr Shorten saying that he has no plans to review approvals is hardly ruling a review out.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: When we talk about projects like Adani, our position has always been clear. If it stacks up environmentally and financially, it should go ahead.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mr Shorten, I have a question for you and also a question for Mr Beers as well.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Oh, two questions, OK.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Related. So you are confirming that you are not going to sign this CFMEU pledge to not stand in the way of Adani.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: First of all on the pledge, no I am not going to sign it. But you can deduce from that nothing other than I am not going to sign a pledge.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: In relation to the pledge, I'm not sure how many people have actually read the pledge. But it talks about the very issues I just spoke about.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The ACTU wants to see the minimum wage rise by $50 a week. Is that the sort of increase you want to see?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I will get Brendan to supplement the answer. We are not going to pick a final number but I will state this.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How do you expect small businesses to cope with the costs that you're loading them up with, with these increases?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, first of all, we've always made clear that whatever outcome occurs should be after consultation and negotiation with business including small business.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can I ask you a question about costs because costs have started to become a theme of the press conference. We don't have an answer to the cost for small businesses when it comes to lifting wages because we don't know how much you would like to lift wages.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: OK let's go through each of those three points very briefly. There is a cost to Australian business when wage earners are experiencing wage stagnation.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Just on the Greens, they want to end coal mining by 2030. Some in Queensland would say that is an extreme policy.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: First of all it’s a silly policy and it’s a policy that isn't going to happen. In terms of the Greens, what I say to them next time they catch a tram - trams run on steel.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Any questions about this or other matters?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mr Shorten, the member for Solomon said that there would be a support package for the NT. Will the Federal Government or a Federal Labor Government be bailing out the Northern Territory from their current financial crisis?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well whilst I'm not running for Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, especially as Michael Gunner is doing such a good job, gee the new Gunner Government was left with a lot of problems by the outgoing administration, the CLP-run people. You know, the CLP managed to do the double - the daily double.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Will that include GST top-ups?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, what we'll do in our way is we’ll put more investment in the Territory. I get there's a legitimate concern to make sure that no one gets disadvantaged in GST, and it was Labor nationally, working with the McGowan Government in Western Australia, who ensured the West got their fair share.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Will there be any cost to business under Labor's climate change plans?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Our climate change plans will grow the economy, they'll create jobs and they'll lower power prices. I notice there's been a bit of a debate and a bit of a scare campaign by the News Limited papers talking about international offsets for carbon pollution reduction.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mr Shorten on the question of tax cuts, there's a report in newspapers this morning suggesting that Labor has taken a decision not to offer additional tax cuts for people on incomes between $90,000 and $120,000 or $125,000 a year. Can I – one – ask, can you confirm that Labor has taken that decision? And - two, if you can – what’s that say to people on those incomes? Doesn't it say, "You've got enough money and you're doing well"?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: they want to look after the top end of town by cutting services to everyone.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Australian is suggesting that your carbon credits policy would cost Australians $25 billion. I take it it's a figure you reject.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well first of all, it is just a nonsense claim. It is a nonsense claim and it is built upon the back of a big lie.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thank you. Isn't this issue starting to get a bit away from you? Is it a bit glib to blame News Limited? Shouldn't you announce the costings, bring that forward, bring voters in on your plans?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well first of all, the issue of climate change has been getting away from Australia for the last ten years. The people of Australia are fed up with politics.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you have a rough figure at least on how much it would cost?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, you keep going on cost. I want to say to you let's get this straight.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A report in the paper today states the McKibbin report estimates that it would cost businesses $25 billion by 2030 to buy the foreign carbon credits. Can you say how much money you believe Australian businesses will have to pay to buy these carbon credits over the next decade? Is this the $25 billion figure accurate? Is it more? Is it less?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: cement, steel, aluminium and other sectors. We have created a $300 million dollar fund to help them invest in new technology.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: $25 billion is a lie, Mr Shorten, you say, but isn't the problem here you don't have a number to put in its place? And as long as you don't have a number to put in its place, why should we be confident that you're taking the Australian economy somewhere where you know how it's going to be affected at the end of the line?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: When this government, when the current Prime Minister was the loyal Treasurer, of the previous Prime Minister - if you believe that I've got a bridge to sell you - but anyway, when the Prime Minister was the Treasurer, when the current Treasurer was the former Environment Minister and when Malcolm Turnbull was still on top, they said the National Energy Guarantee would deliver $550 in lower household prices on energy. The numbers we're using, are the numbers the experts are given, they're the publicly available numbers, and they're in some cases, Malcolm Turnbull's own numbers.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: On Indigenous Affairs, Bill Shorten, Labor has said it will abolish the Community Development Program, and is campaigning hard on that issue here in the Territory. What is your new plan, and if you can't tell us today, will that be outlined before the election?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yeah, I can, and I'm also fortunate to have people of the calibre of Senator Dodson here and I might give him a run on the ball, but I'll just make this. The current CDP's not working.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mr Shorten, regarding, on the-

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Just hang on, hang on, gentlemen, ladies, we've a fair go at this press conference, perhaps I'll allow one more question and then we got to finish up, we've got to go to Tiwi.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten, regarding your claim that with your climate policies, we'd have GDP growth of 23 per cent in the 2020s, is that business as usual, the same as if you didn't have the climate plan, and where did you get the numbers from, I understand it's from the McKibbin report, but isn't that a bit outdated?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Sorry what was the last bit of your question?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I understand that figure was from the McKibbin report, isn't that a bit outdated now?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, first of all, it's publicly available, now if we're saying, the campaign against climate change by this government is malicious and stupid. It's malicious because there are elements of this government, the right wing, who have undermined even people in the Liberal Party to take action on climate change, and whenever we talk about common sense on climate change, you just get a scare campaign run by the more extreme elements - just hang on- this is really important, cause climate change is an important issue in this election, and it's a malicious campaign by this government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten, welcome to Perth.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Great to be on the show.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Firstly, tell us why you’re here today?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We’re here to explain Labor’s great policies for this election. In particular, on this visit we’re talking about our exciting new ideas to improve health funding.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We have been asking our listeners this morning, Mr Shorten, to text through questions for you. I’d like to read you this text from Tim.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well you would love to know what business Tim is in, he obviously is having some business difficulties already, but let me just say this on climate change. First of all, taking action on climate change is good for the economy.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: People are looking at the hiccups and stumbles at a time like this when you are focusing on an upcoming election, and such was the case yesterday afternoon, where you were seen to not answer a question that was asked by a journalist, and we have another question from a listener from Owen, asking what are the costings for your renewables and greenhouse gas emission policies, you owe it to the people of Australia to be transparent on this.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, you made a preamble to this question. I have answered questions on climate change many times, many times.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So the costs are the same?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yeah. I would pick a more positive number than costs.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I mean, the thing with these climate change policies, these policies take time. You know, natural disasters are not going to stop the moment a good policy is agreed to.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I don’t think any of us that extreme weather events are getting less frequent, are they?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, but it may take a century to recover from that situation.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: If you don’t start – you are quite right, and what sort of world are we passing on to the next generation? We know this government is paralysed on climate change, and if they weren’t, Malcolm Turnbull would still be the Prime Minister, wouldn’t he?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Vote Compass is the online tool that ABC is using during the election campaign to gauge Australians’ views on the policies, taking the personalities out of it. The number one issue here in Western Australia is not the environment, but the economy, and that is the concern, and that is where they don’t trust you.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, I don’t accept that. First of all, the idea that the environment and the economy are two separate planets and separate solar systems is rubbish.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But electric cars actually cost more, at the moment.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, sorry, no, it’s actually been shown that over time when you pay for less petrol, it actually costs less. But I agree, at the moment the models are expensive, but this isn’t all about what happens next week and it’s not all about trying to take someone’s ute off them.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: (laughs) Not seeing what’s coming down over the road is quite an amazing analogy because I don’t think even you could have realised that electric cars were going to be the hot spot that it is. But the hot button issue –

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I just didn’t realise that we had a technophobic government who is afraid of new technology.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Every time we talk about it, we get loads of people talking about it, for and against.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: if you want to keep driving a petrol car, you can. Excellent.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But you would rather they didn’t.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No, I’m happy if you do. What car you choose to drive is your business.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten is our guest, I beg your pardon, on ABC Radio Perth and WA, the Leader of the Opposition. Let’s go back to questions from our listeners.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, let’s go back to this. When you give a tax credit to someone who is not paying income tax, that is a gift.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A lot of people make the point that $3000 or $2500 is what pays for their health insurance every year, they make arrangements years in advance based on what you call a gift so why don't you grandfather these arrangements?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Because it is costing $6 billion. The reality is that when you go to hospital it costs a lot more than $2000, I need to find money for our ageing population.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten there are a number of tightly held seats in Western Australia that you're fighting over at the moment. There are some that you would give up on and one of them would be Curtin but you did play a surprise hand I guess when came to delivering a candidate to Curtin for the ALP, and with it looked like the aim of disruption I guess, Melissa Parke, I am talking about and she of course now has stood down as the candidate for the ALP for the seat of Curtin over, some people would say, embarrassing comments that she made claiming that a Palestinian woman was forced to drink bleach at the Israeli border.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well I like Melissa. I think she is an accomplished woman and she was a good Member of Parliament when she was there and she's also worked overseas for the United Nations and refugees so, I like her.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So you didn't ask her to stand down?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No. And the point about it is that she is a strong person.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Are you embarrassed by it?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No, she has strong views. I like Melissa.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And now Josh Wilson supports a two-state solution in Israel and that is also causing you some tension?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No, he supports party policy and that is our party policy, a two-state solution - the right of Israel to exist behind secure borders but also recognising the legitimate aspirations of Palestinian people to their own country.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten, will any elected WA Labor members make their way onto a Government front bench if you win?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Who gets on the front bench is ultimately decided by the Caucus. But I think all things being equal that would be the case, yes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Pat Dodson?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well I have to let the Caucus members have a say, I don't run a top-down organisation, but I think personally Pat Dodson is an outstanding Australian, an outstanding West Australian. I personally approached him to run for the Senate and you know any room that he is in everyone else in the room always feel a bit better because he is such a significant father of reconciliation.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We have watched the Budget and your reply very, very closely. Why is the Newstart allowance, an increase, not an ALP commitment?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well we are going to review it. First things first - I do think Newstart is too low.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Would you look at changing it so that it, the annual indexation is similar to what happens with the pension?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I will let the review look at all of those issues, that is a legitimate issue. I think that some conservatives say that you should only be temporarily unemployed therefore keep it low and that way it gives incentive for people to get off it, but I don't think keeping it so low actually achieves anything other than is unfair to people very down on their luck.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It makes a lot of people very sad..

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We are up for reviewing it and we want to review it positively.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Substantially, I mean I know you can't commit but it needs a good hike..

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We get into the adjectives game, what I can say is it is too low.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Who do you imagine is on Newstart when you picture it in your mind's eye?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I think it is a range, I don't think it's one stereotype at all. You get people who are older who, the factory closes, they are thrown all of a sudden on the scrap heap and told they are not worth something.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We've been asking our listeners over the last couple of weeks about trust in regard to politicians and in particular who they trust more, you or Scott Morrison. 22 per cent of our listeners who took part in our survey said they didn't trust either of you.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I think there is disillusionment with institutions generally. I don't think a lot of people trust the media.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten just a final question for you talking about town halls, we read today that you have agreed with the Prime Minister Scott Morrison to a debate here in Perth on the April 29. Can you tell us what the arrangement of that is.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: My preference is questions from the audience, just direct. The media, of course, should be invited, they can film the interplay.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thank you very much for your time.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Lovely thank you very much for your interest.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But now to other news, a bit closer to home and Bill Shorten is promising to fund $200 million worth of free blood tests for cancer patients and older Australians on day six of the federal election campaign. The Opposition Leader has already pledged to invest $2.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Opposition Leader Bill Shorten joins us now from Melbourne. Good morning to you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: 52-48 two party preferred. Based on that, it would be a landslide to Labor.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Oh, I'm not getting ahead of myself. What we're going to do is not focus so much on the Government and the personalities but on our plan for the future.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Earlier today, we spoke to the Treasurer, Josh Frydenberg. What is your response to claims a Shorten Government would be the highest taxing government in Australian history?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well first of all, we don't accept that. This is the Government who's raised more taxes than anyone before us.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: All right. While we've got you Bill Shorten, the children of notorious terrorist Khaled Sharrouf have pleaded to be allowed to come back home to Australia after years living in Islamic State territory.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well I don't hold the children responsible for the mistakes of their parents. You know I don't know all the circumstances but I can understand why a grandmother wants to see her grandchildren safe at home.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But you'd like them back in?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well I think you've got to work on that. We've got to make the kids safe.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yep. All right Bill Shorten, thanks for joining us.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten is campaigning in Sydney this morning where he will reveal the latest details of the party's plans to cut cancer costs. He joins us from the Sydney Markets.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Good morning Michael.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Firstly, to the news of the morning, what is your response to the arrest of Julian Assange overnight?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: It will be a matter for the legal system to proceed, he should receive the support any other Australian citizens should receive, the matter is going before court so I don't think there is much more I can add.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What do you make of America confirming overnight that yes indeed it does want to extradite Julian Assange to the United States?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I have only read what you read. Mr Assange is entitled to his day in court.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Should the Australian Government, any Australian Government, Coalition or Labor seek to stop such move?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I think he should receive consular assistance beyond that, I don't know all the facts of the matter and he should deserve the ability to be able to represent it in court which he will be.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You're campaigning in Western Sydney this morning, Bill Shorten, how worried are you about the prospects of the Labor Party not just in Western Sydney but in Sydney generally after the disastrous performance of state Labor in the recent NSW election?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I think the state election had a range of state issues, there is always a lesson there and we're not complacent. What we are doing nationally is we're not relying on the fact we're the Government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The Prime Minister on the show half an hour ago released the Treasury costings pointing to $387 billion burden as the Coalition puts it of the Labor tax plan over the next decade. Can voters afford to elect the Labor Party?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Listen, the Liberals are lying about taxes. Let's just call it as it is.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It’s not the Government, it’s the Treasury figures. Are you saying the Treasury is lying? They are very similar to figures put out by Chris Bowen the Shadow Treasurer a few days ago.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No. Let's go to one.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: To another tax concession Labor is promising to wind back to some degree, negative gearing. The NAB has put out a report this week saying it expects house prices in Sydney to drop by 20 per cent before this fall is over from the peak in 2017.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: The fact that bank said this tells me a couple of things.  It tells me the biggest drop in housing prices has happened under the Coalition Government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Just about out of time so confirming there will be no change at all if you win government to the negative gearing plan?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: There will be no change to existing investors.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But no change to your future plan?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No, that's right. Someone's got to have the courage to stand up for the next generation, that's what we will do.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Just wanted to confirm that. The CFMEU is asking all Queenslanders to sign a pledge to support the coal industry.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Coal and our gas are important industries going forward. They are important to our exports and that will be part of our energy mix, but I am going to take real action on climate change.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Should the Labor MP's sign the pledge? Based on what you said?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: It is up to them.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Is the CFMEU bullying your Labor colleagues in Queensland?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: If you want to talk about bullying, how about that LNP trying to threaten Melissa Price's job?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I'm not talking about them, I am talking about the CFMEU. I am asking the question? Do you believe that union is bullying your QLD Labor colleagues?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No, I’ll tell you what my Labor colleagues they are adults, they can sign or not. Doesn't change our policy and our policy is as simple as this, we get that fossil fuel and coal is important to export and power generation but I promise Australian who are fed up with the dysfunction and disunity of the Government on climate change we need to act.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We will have to leave it there, Bill Shorten thank you very much.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Look forward to talking.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Hopefully many times over the course of the campaign.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Hope so, see you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Now, the man who wants the top job, Opposition Leader Bill Shorten, is also in the Emerald City. He joins us now from the Sydney Markets at Homebush.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, the bookies are the best bet of how things are going to play out and your odds of winning are better than you'll get with Winx at the track tomorrow.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yeah well, there is a way to go, things close up. But what I'm going to do is focus on the people.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, you are promising to make life easier for Australians, but new treasury costings which the Government has released show you'll hit households with $387 billion in extra taxes over the next decade. Do you really think voters will welcome paying $5,400 a year more in taxes under Labor than the Coalition? It is a potent argument.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: The Liberals are lying about tax. I don't want to talk too much about it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you deny that these costings from Treasury are correct?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: They are not correct. There you go, short answer too.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So no validity at all, you won't be taxing more -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Oh no. Listen, you and I know that, and more importantly Australians know, this is a Government who is going to run on fear and negativity.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A lot of retirees though, many of them who are on modest nest eggs are not millionaires, they’re worried about your changes to the franking credits. A lot of people who have got investment properties, a lot of them are not millionaires, are confused and concerned about your crack-down on negative gearing and capital gains tax.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: our tax system is making it harder for our young ones, our millennials, the younger people to be able to even buy their first home. We have got to start creating a level playing field.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Alright, Bill Shorten, we thank you for your time this morning. There's five weeks of this.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Cheerio, bye-bye.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten, welcome

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That concern, that if you punish the banks in a certain way then credit might dry up, is that a reasonable thing to keep in mind when you decide on penalties?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: There they go again, the government. They already sound like they're backpedalling on making the banks accountable.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: He wants an effective banking system, he doesn't want credit to dry up.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Barrie, is this Liberal government, this protection racket for the banks scandals and rip-offs we’ve seen, are they really telling Australians that the only way that we can have a banking sector is to have an unethical banking sector? I don't buy that, nor do thousands of farmers and small businesses and people who have been ripped off by the banks. I for one have been shocked.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So, do you commit to adopting all of the recommendations of the royal commission?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We will in principle. I mean it would have to be a pretty amazing reason not to.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You've come up with a recommendation of your own around the new protections for whistleblowers but it’s this financial incentive that’s thrown in as well. Why is that there?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, we have a look around the world and the Americans have been able to make some big breakthroughs in some financial scandals by basically encouraging some of the people involved to be able to come forward and get a reward. What our plan means for people who are doing the wrong thing is that just be aware of the person next to you because they might just want the reward and not put up with corruption.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But you talk about white collar criminals, and in this case that’s who you are targeting, and yet you oppose an ABCC in the area of industrial criminality.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I think there is a bit of a difference there Baz. First of all, what we are saying is that in workplace relations, just one set of laws.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Couldn’t that be the risk though, the reward. It could be quite large, it could be as much as $200,000 in big cases - could that lead to vexatious claims?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, if you think we're catching, if you think that we are hearing all of the insider deals that go on well I don’t share that view. Labor is going to pursue and make sure we restore faith in institutions, not just in the government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I want to ask you about housing prices now, housing prices have gone up in Sydney and Melbourne by close to 10% in the last 12 months. There are predictions - have fallen by 10%.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, prices go up and prices go down. It really depends if you're trying to buy or sell a house.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Because that might cause the house prices to fall even further?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, first of all let's look at where the house prices have fallen. They've fallen under this government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But will your changes to negative gearing mean that houses will be even cheaper?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: What our changes will mean is that it will be fairer, in terms of…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But cheaper?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I’ll come to cheaper in a second, first of all let’s deal with fair, this is the real reason we’re doing it. How is it fair, Barrie, that a couple have to compete to buy their first home with someone who is getting a taxpayer funded handout to buy their sixth or seventh home.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But by ‘modest impact’ it will cause a further decline in the price of houses.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Oh no I don’t accept that, I accept that what we are doing is creating fairness.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How can it not have that impact?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well first of all, the only way that you could follow the government’s logic is if you would stop investing in property in Australia. The reality is most people invest in property because it is a good deal.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: On the franking credit issue, you can see that it’s causing you more political harm because it's not grandfathered and you also can see that some of the people who will take the hit here are not wealthy.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well first of all, just on this issue of grandfathering, you are quite right, when it comes to negative gearing all of the people currently negatively geared will not be affected and you’ll still be able to negatively gear your houses…

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But that doesn't apply to the franking credit.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well the franking credits, that's still prospective. Without everyone being bored to tears about the issue, in 1987, Paul Keating introduced the scheme, basic principle of tax equity, he said you shouldn't pay tax twice.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But it does exist and a lot of people have relied on it for a long time and you are copping some backlash over this - the government is making quite something of it - are you prepared to have another look at it?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, first of all, the reason why we're doing it is there is no principle that says it is fair that a non-taxpayer gets a tax refund, a cash tax refund. But it is also not fair that we're spending $100 million a week paying non-taxpayers cash tax refunds.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: When you say you're not for turning, there will be no tweaking of the policy at all?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well if I can put it really directly, do people want a government or do they want a piece of plasticine. Do people want a government with tax principles and fairness at their core or do they just want  a lump of political putty.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We're just go to a package and we will come back to you. We’ve got a bit of a problem in the studio.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And just to explain what happened there, one of our cameramen had a bit of an episode. He seems fine but we've got an ambulance on the way.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, we'll be pursuing it. It really depends on what sort of pressure the government has brought on the crossbenchers.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Because of that development though, do you think that will have an impact on the thinking of some of the crossbenchers, and I’m thinking Cathy McGowan in particular and she might now be satisfied with that and she won't then support the Labor initiative?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Ms McGowan has always said she's concerned about all of the people in detention, not just the kids. But I’m not going to put any more pressure on her, I’ll leave that to the government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Thanks very much for coming in. I appreciate it.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Thank you very much.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well, in Victoria they are calling it the Danslide, the weekend election result that saw the Liberal Party receive an absolute drubbing, rewarding Daniel Andrews another term as Premier. So, does that result signal what is to come in next year's federal election and what will our next guest do if he becomes Prime Minister.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Measuring up the drapes for the Lodge?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No, not at all. There is still another perhaps up to five months before the election.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You must be very heartened by what occurred in Victoria at the weekend, it was a Labor landslide in your home state?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yes, I was pleased. I was pleased for the work of Dan Andrews and his team, nothing should take way from their success.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well the Prime Minister is holding crisis talks today with Victorian Federal MPs. Have you got any advice for him?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Actually, first things first - I am not going to spend my time bagging the current Prime Minister. What I would say, is focus on properly funding the schools and the hospitals.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What about today's Newspoll, the Coalition's primary vote down to a near-record low of 34 per cent. It really is unlosable for Labor, this next election?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I don't have that view. I have made the practice over five years now of not commenting on the polls - good, bad or indifferent.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You say you don't take any notice of polls but you do have a problem with your popularity. That Newspoll suggests that while voters want Labor in government, they don't think you are the right leader.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well I don't buy what you are selling there, but I will go to this point, I did say that I don't comment on polls - good or bad, but if Mr Morrison, if he thinks that he is doing really well at the moment go and ask his Victorian colleagues. Georgie, what matters is elections and I think on Saturday we saw a big tick for Dan Andrews but also Labor's brand - backing in the schools, backing in the hospitals, getting on with the job not the cuts, the chaos, the division, the scare tactics.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But does that not concern you, that you are continually dropping as preferred Prime Minister?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No. I have got to say that what concerns me is the waiting list that someone - the waiting time that someone has to get an elective surgery.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You mentioned that national anti-corruption watchdog, saying you will work with the Coalition but not wait for them. Just explain if you could how exactly that watchdog would work under Labor?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well first of all, we think that the Commonwealth and the politicians should have an anti-corruption commission. We want it to be a body which is created by law, that it is independent of government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: As you know, the Prime Minister has proposed tough new laws on terror, making it easy to strip Aussie citizenship from those convicted of terrorism offences. Do you back that proposal from the Prime Minister?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We will have a good look at them. We have backed 15 sets of changes.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It needs a multi-pronged approach, doesn't it? What else do you propose to do?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: In terms of national security?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yeah.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We want to make sure that our defence spending is up to 2 per cent of our national economy. We are committed to making sure that we properly fund our national security agencies and the Federal Police.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Can you repeat what happened in Victoria over the weekend?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, that will be up to the people of Australia, but I think our message is one which resonates. It is the same message that Dan Andrews offered in Victoria - better hospitals, better schools.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Are you -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yes, I am confident that we have got positive policies and we don't need to go down the negative divisive path. One difference between me and the current Government - we are united.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Are you our next Prime Minister?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: That will be up to the Australian people, Georgie but if I am, I won't let you or the Australian people down. We're going to focus on the people, not on ourselves.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We appreciate your time this morning, Bill Shorten. Thank you.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: All right, good chat. Thank you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well Federal Opposition Leader Bill Shorten joins us now. Mr Shorten, good evening to you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You’ve got to tell us, do you own a Burberry trench coat at this point, and if you do, I’d get rid of it very quickly.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No, I haven’t quite got around to that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Right, that's probably a very good move. It was a huge result though.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well first of all, full credit to Daniel Andrews and the State Labor Government. They submitted their record and got a renewed mandate, a bigger mandate, so nothing takes away from that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mr Shorten, you are in Canberra now. Let’s just be honest, are you measuring up the drapes in the Lodge? What’s going on?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No. You know I did the shopping today in Moonee Ponds where I live and people were saying bring on the Federal Election, and some people would say that Labor has it in the bag, Idon't think that at all.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But hypothetically, would you think about putting heat lamps in the bathroom?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yeah no, that’s somewhere with the Burberry trench coat.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Dan Andrews has said the Victorian State Government is the most progressive state government in the country. Does that mean that Matthew Guy would have had a better chance if his last name was Mathew non-binary?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Listen, I think what happened is that people just want you to get on with the job. I don’t think everyone agrees with everything that Labor says, and people don’t agree with everything the Liberals say.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill, I know you don’t want to get carried away with expectations ahead of next year’s election, but if things go on as they are, you will be our next Prime Minister and I feel bad asking you this, because I think we have to ask you every time you come on. You’re the least of the preferred Prime Ministers, what are you going to do between now and the election to make us all feel excited about you being the Prime Minister?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Oh Hamish, I think there is a little bit of excitement in your heart, you just need to find it. Only a little though, let's not really debate that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It is a little bit about you, you've got to admit that, and you know you've got not that much time until the next election.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well I tell you what the numbers on me were the same before the State Election as they are now, but we’re doing pretty well. We’re doing well because we focus on people.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Mr Shorten, well what about your sausage eating style, could that play into it? On Saturday, you know, you were doing a better job of it after going for the sideways bite. Do you think you can get it together before the next election? The important issues.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Sarah, you know, it’s about time we buried the sausage scandal of 2016. I did eat it sideways but, you know I had very good reasons.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten, thank you very much.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: See you guys. Thank you.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: It's about time we had the renewables revolution. We're proposing to make it easier for households to buy solar powered batteries.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay renewables revolution, so it will start with what, 100,000 homes?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yes. There's already 50,000 batteries installed around Australia.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: How much are the batteries?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: At the moment they can be north of $10,000, so they're certainly not cheap. Over the life of the battery installation people get the value back.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: This is going to take a while. It's not exactly a renewable revolution if only 100,000 people can do it?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, there's no doubt that it's going to take a while, but we've got to start. I think renewable energy and climate change is something where the Australian people are so far ahead of the politicians it's not funny.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: I just don't know how many people are going to be able to afford the $10,000. How long will it be before the batteries have paid back the initial investment?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, between five to six years, we've seen the recoup in the solar panels. They'll get cheaper, and also what we'll see is people - do you know,  in the next two or three weeks, Karl, we're going to pass the 2 million household mark who have got solar on the roofs? So, I've got no doubt this is the future and we're going to start steering the nation to the future and work with Aussie families.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: What difference will it make in terms of power supply on the grid?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, this is the other good news - what it's going to mean is if you can store the energy during the day - say the family watching the show this morning, the kids go off to school, mum and dad might go to work - what happens is at the moment, if you have just got solar panels, you don't get the energy when you need it which is in the evenings, when the kids turn computers on and you need the energy. The beauty of the batteries is that the energy is going to be there when you need it not just when the sun is shining.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Ok, this is 7 years. Have you thought about cheaper ways to reach your energy targets? Will there be a carbon tax under a government you lead?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No. What we will do though is we're going to pick up what Malcolm Turnbull proposed.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: South Australia made a big shift towards renewables and we all know how that ended and how reliable their power was - can you guarantee this power will be just as reliable as to what we have now.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: lower the prices, take real action on climate change and ensure reliability. Batteries for households is the missing link.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So power bills will be cheaper, will be less under Labor?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: There's no doubt that if we back renewable energy, renewable energy is cheaper than existing forms of power in the future.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Ok, let's move on. Scott Morrison is on electoral winner it seems regarding shrinking migration levels.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, there's two ingredients, aren't there? First of all, there's permanent migration. The current Prime Minister says that he will lower the cap from 190,000 to 160,000.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Finally and really quickly, the Prime Minister is trying to get together with Muslim leaders to try and sort through some of the angst and the division that is out there. Surely, it is upon Muslim leaders to get to the table with the Prime Minister otherwise those divisions will surely get worse?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, I've got a general rule in life that you’re always better talking than having a standoff. It would be better if the leaders turned up.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten, thanks for your time.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Good on you, Karl. Have a lovely day.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Labor has announced details of it's long awaited energy policy. Bill Shorten is looking to keep Malcolm Turnbull's National Energy Guarantee but with a higher emissions reduction target.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So even though conservative politicians bag renewables, the actual Australian public is adopting it.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Let's say it as it is, the Australian people are so far ahead of the politicians on renewable energy it's not a joke but what I am going to do if we get elected is we're backing renewables, we're backing the batteries, we want people to get between a 60 and 90 per cent reduction off their household bills. That's what you get over the lifetime of installing batteries and solar.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay so you put the $3000 to $10,000 battery in, you get $2000 back but it will cut your power bill by 80 to 90 per cent?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well all of the research we've seen and the evidence - between 60 and 90 per cent, I mean you heard that right. I don't own shares in a battery company or a solar company, I'm just interested in getting household power bills down.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Interesting policy. Alright Bill Shorten, thanks for joining us.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Fantastic to have you on and thank you for your time. We know you're a very busy man.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill, did you really think we would be here celebrating one year since the Yes result?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yes, I thought the vote would be successful but what I realised on the morning of the vote being declared was the amount of pressure that a lot of people - LGBTQ people felt because what it was is this silly process which got the right outcome. It put a lot of pressure on our fellow Australians.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well the people who bullied us at school - that's how I looked at, those people that bullied me were going to now make the decision.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: It was just madness. My view is that people's relationships are their own business.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Outrageous.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: listen, you're the reason why the vote is going to go down. Which wasn't necessarily diplomatic -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But that's hard not to when they're attacking your child.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Of course not. I just thought it was wrong and so, that was only a tiny taste.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: But we got the right outcome. That day, in front of the State Library was awesome.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Fantastic.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: And did you know since then - what is it? 5,420 marriages have occurred. That's good.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Correct. We will be talking to someone later on to actually talk about the financial impact that marriage equality has had.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill, originally the Marriage Act of 1961 had no definition of who could or couldn't get married in Australia. Why was it so easy for Prime Minister John Howard to amend the Marriage Act to prevent same sex marriages in 2004 yet it took so much effort and this public survey to change it back?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well good point. I think back in 2004, the then Labor Party in Parliament felt a bit stampeded.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, never.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Anyway, so we get the hypocrisy of the process but today's a good day. It's a year on.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Absolutely, the sky didn't fall in.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No but it was hard. And I'm going to say, you know, Wayne and I have been on TV on Gogglebox, we became poster boys for hate.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: It was a relief. That was the point.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Look we are going to thank you for it - getting the Labor Party on board as well as the trade unions. You really, guys coming out there, you were there at every rally we saw you.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well I made the decision, when they first proposed having the plebiscite I thought it was the wrong process, I thought it was an abdication of leadership but then I thought why on earth should we let some Australians go through this process on their own. And so that's why we decided to strongly encourage participation because we couldn't leave people on their own.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well you are the leaders of the country and we do look towards Canberra to lead us and thank you for standing up and doing it.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Occasionally we do.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well I mean that's what we're meant to do, that's what we stand there and do you know?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: That's right.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill there's some significant issues facing the world at the moment, climate change being one of the biggest. We wasted over a year being distracted by same sex marriage, what could have been done quite quickly you know there's Safe Schools, keeping people in detention, there's other preoccupations of this current government.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I think that we can miss out on what's happening around the world, you know climate change and the investment in renewables is one example but I think your question is going to a deeper point. Is change too hard in Australia and I don't think it is.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well when the politicians are talking to the average person we then feel part of the process, we then can move along with you, we understand what laws are changing, why we're moving in that direction, if we're just thrown stupid law at us we're going to fight them back.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well a good analogy I've always used because when I was a union rep sometimes we'd have to have change in workplaces was quite often  I saw corporate leaders say to everyone - use the analogy of a railway station - you're at railway station A and the corporate leaders would say righto to the workforce, you've got to get to railway station B.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay yeah.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: You've got to tell people where they fit in. Change is not too hard but you do have to make sure that you don't leave people behind.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And that's right people are scared.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: And if you don't have an explanation for how you're going to educate the kids or look after the sick or deal with our environment or make sure that we've got economic growth which is in the interests of everyone not just the lucky few, then people are going to say, they're going to look for more extreme solutions and just say no, we're not interested in this version of change which doesn't have a place for us in it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And then we ended up with the extremist political parties coming in who seem to be getting all the airtime. They seem to be the ones that cop it.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: It's always possible to get airtime if you're willing to say silly things but if you want to have a strong, sensible, centrist debate and this is what Mr Turnbull perhaps missed the opportunity to do, he came in with a lot of good will, is you have to lead but you can lead from the centre. You don't have to say extreme things to get things done.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: If people see a direction they're happy and that's what you said, you explain where you're taking us, why you're going and if it's not going to work in 12 months, 2 years, 3 years we reevaluate and move back through. We don't just go -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well we set up the National Disability Insurance Scheme when I was last in government.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well done. And that was fantastic.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: And it didn't exist before we got there but I spent a lot of time talking to people with disability and their careers and then we built up a coalition of people who really wanted to see a better deal.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And Australia always has been a country where we've taken care of the underprivileged or those who are unable to take care of themselves.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: But it's interesting, when you get off a plane at Tullamarine or at Mascot when you come from overseas, whilst you've enjoyed your visit overseas you know there's things about this country we're proud of, but we don't - when we get back to Australia - when we're overseas do we talk about our Medicare system or our tax deductions?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well we talk about Medicare.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Of course.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: We talk about the wonderful things that we do.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We talk about a strong minimum wage, we don't talk about the top two percent of Australians not having to pay tax. It's interesting what we're proud of.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill if elected you've committed $10 million towards construction of the Victorian Pride Centre.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yay well done!

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You've also promised $600,000 towards building new digital studios for this radio station.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yes, and you can see we've shown you Joy is falling apart, and I promise I won't spend that $600 grand on my shoes. It will go to proper things here at Joy.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: It mightn't be enough, I get that so -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Do you think the marriage equality debate highlighted the need for such community outlets?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yes, we've got to have more diversity in our media, got to hear more voices, can't just be the same old couple of large media companies in Australia. We've got to have more diversity.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Definitely. And that's - when you're talking about the ABC at moment, I mean, they're in a bit of shambles.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We need an independent national broadcaster.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And they were the most trusted news outlet in the country.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: They still are. They still are.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Are we still trusting them?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: I think we are, but I think some of the shenanigans at the top level and the personality conflicts has left people disillusioned, but the way we will get around that is that we'll just go back to a more independent process to pick the senior leadership of the ABC.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Excellent.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Politicians out, independent transparent process in.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You've likened political interference in the ABC to a dictatorship, we're sick of the ABC bias towards Playschool. We want Mr Squiggle back.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Oh really? Are you about getting (inaudible)?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yep, absolutely.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Maybe we need to have a plebiscite  - I don't know.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No, let's waste some more money -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: That's an issue for a plebiscite.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But I was reading this morning on the train that your lovely Deputy, Tanya Plibersek, actually is putting through a Senate Bill to actually try and remove the discrimination for the religious schools.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yes, she and Penny and myself, we think that the time has come to revisit that. What's happened is that over time we've started to provide protection against sex discrimination.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Well we do need to do something because our now Prime Minister, what's his name again? I can't keep up with which one we've got.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Scott Morrison?

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yes, who promised that during the Wentworth election that he would have that removed within two weeks after that there. Hasn't happened.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, maybe - but he hasn't moved to embassy either, so -

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: So, I mean as you are going to be Australia's next Prime Minister -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Oh, we don't know that yet. We're working very hard on it.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: In the latest Newspoll Labor is ahead of the Coalition on a two party preferred basis, 55-45 meaning you and Labor would win any election held today. We've got Scott Morrison, he's got his bus up in Queensland, are you going to have a bus with -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We had a bus long before Scott had it, and we've even been on the bus!

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You have been on the bus.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: That's really good, but -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: But we don't take this election for granted at all.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We want to put forward positive views. Some people say the Government's such a disorganised shambles, just sit back and buy a box of popcorn, but the point is that puts more pressure on us, because people think the system is broken.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: 1, that you'll have a different Prime Minister that you'll be going up against. What's the bet that he'll still be there when the time comes?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: The place would erupt if if they rolled him.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: But is this true, this is what we want  to see -

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Mind you, I didn't think they'd roll Malcolm, so what would I know.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: No.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill, importantly, according to a La Trobe University study, 80 per cent of homophobic bullying involving LGBTI young people occurs at schools, and has a profound impact on their wellbeing and education as you can imagine, let alone the ongoing impact on their adult life. Will you be open to funding a national Safe School's program again?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We're committed to putting in place anti-bulling programs. Keeping kids safe shouldn't be the matter of the politics that it is.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yep. Very much true.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Absolutely.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Super. Thank you.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Look, the money is fantastic, you know you've got my vote - well you've definitely got out vote.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: That's good.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And it's not just that, but the Pride Centre is going to be a very important thing.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: It'll be great. Long overdue.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Yes. Look thank you so much for your time.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Bill Shorten, thanks for your time this morning on this important one year anniversary of the "yes" result.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Yes it's good. It's really good.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: And thank you for your help.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No, it was everyone. It was a collective effort.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: With an election looming and the Prime Minister's approval rating at an all time low, Labor has launched its bidding for your vote. Opposition Leader Bill Shorten joins me now live from Melbourne.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay, let's start with the business end of things. You've promised to crack down on multinational tax loopholes for companies and individuals.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, it is certainly easier said than done, but we have got to do it. I don't think most Australians waking up this morning realise that some corporations and some high net wealthy - very wealthy, wealthy individuals are dodging about $5 billion in tax over the next ten years by basically going to tax havens.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: A lot of these wealthy individuals get themselves lawyered up and you're talking about international boundaries and international laws here. I think it's unfair Aussie businesses pay full freight as well but it's been like that for a long time.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: We're going to change the laws and we're going to put the resources to enforce the laws. If you want to crack down on multinationals and very, very wealthy people not paying their tax, who do you trust? The Liberal Party who spent most of their time in government wanting to give them tax cuts, or the Labor Party who wants to properly fund our schools and hospitals? When it comes to this, there's only one party you can trust to clean it up and that's the Labor Party.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: Okay, and nothing specific though?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well we are putting forward a series of recommendations. Changing the law on whistleblowers, changing the ability of companies to mask or hide what they are doing.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: It would be good to clean up those multinationals who are using those loopholes, it would be a good thing. Okay, there are reports also this morning you are going to increase the dole after you get elected, is that true?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: What we have said is that we are going to review the Newstart allowance. It is, in my opinion too low.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The flip side will be that people out there say, hang on a second you don't want to encourage people to be on the dole.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Of course we want people to get off the dole and get a job. But you know, this sort of simple view that you either starve people in order to make them get off the dole, it's just not as straightforward as that.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You are aren't spending too much already are you?

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No, what we are able to do is we are prioritising schools and hospitals over creating richer multinationals and more tax minimisers in you know, Caribbean Islands. That's how we pay for our promises.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: The reality is Bill, you don't actually need to do anything. You don't need to be on our show, you don't need to say anything, you just need to be quiet and you will win the next election.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: Well, some people say that to me. But with the division and the instability of the government, the fact that the Liberals sacked Malcolm Turnbull nine weeks ago, then they have got to send him to Bali to clean up the new Prime Minister's foreign policy mess, the chaos has got to end.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
items.value: You don't want to run the risk of bringing yourself undone though, I mean you're in the box seat, you've basically won the race.

items.speaker: SHORTEN
items.value: No, it's still got a long way to go. That would be too arrogant to just assume that the election is over.

items.speaker: INTERVIEWER
